revision.text:
{{about||the village in Iran|Askal, Iran|Philippine national soccer team|Philippines national football team}} {{redirect|Aspin (dog)|other uses|Aspin (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Dogbreed | country= [[Philippines]] | image =File:Askal (aspin) dog Masinloc, Zambales.jpg|Askal | name = Askal
Aspin
''Irong Bisaya'' | image_caption = A female aspin in [[Masinloc, Zambales]]. | notes = Not recognized by any major kennel club }} '''Askals''' or '''aspins''' are [[mongrel]] dogs in the [[Philippines]]. ==Names== The name "''askal''" is a [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]]-derived [[portmanteau]] of ''asong kalye'' or "[[street dog]]" as these dogs are commonly seen wandering the streets. The [[Philippine Animal Welfare Society]] (PAWS) has suggested the alternative term ''aspin'', short for ''asong Pinoy'' ([[Pinoy]] dog) probably to avoid the stigma associated with the term "''askal''".{{cite news |first=Alya |last=Honasan |title=‘Hey, pare, let’s save the whales’ |url=http://services.inquirer.net/print/print.php?article_id=78027 |publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=2007-07-22 |accessdate=2007-10-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090215173312/http://services.inquirer.net/print/print.php?article_id=78027 |archivedate = February 15, 2009|deadurl=yes}} In [[Cebuano language|Cebuano]], mongrel dogs are called '''irong Bisaya''', which literally means "[[Visaya]]n dog" or "native dog" (note that the word "Bisaya" doesn't explicitly mean "Visayan" but it is a term pertaining people and animals native to a specific locale. For example, "''manok bisaya''" simply means a breed of chicken native to a locality), implying that these are not thought of as a mixed-breed dog so much as unbred mongrels with no purebred ancestors.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/47835/Irong-bisaya-magamit-sa-bomb-sniffing|title=Irong ‘bisaya’ magamit sa bomb sniffing|publisher=[[GMA Network|GMA News.TV]]|accessdate=2007-10-07}} This is only from a Bisayan point of view since Irong Bisaya don't differ in character or physical appearance from the other Askals found in the entire Philippine archipelago. Physically, the dogs have "all shapes, configurations and sizes."{{cite news|url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/48067/in-praise-of-the-%E2%80%98asong-pinoy%E2%80%99|title=In praise of the ‘asong Pinoy’|last=Alya B. Honasan|date=May 15, 2012|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|accessdate=10 June 2015}} ==Appearance== Females' height usually ranges from 12-16 inches while Males can be between 14-19 inches. The coat can be short haired or rough. Coat colors ranges from Black, Brown, Brindle, Gray, Cream and White. Spots are commonly found at the base of the tail and at the back in semi circular fashion. The snout sometimes appears black if the coat color is brown. The tail is usually held high and the ears can be floppy, semi-floppy or fully pointing upwards. The bone structure of a native Askal is on the medium range, never heavy like in Rottweilers. In an opinion piece for the Inquirer, Michael Tan writes that Askals are often more resilient and street-smart than purebreds.{{cite web|url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view_article.php?article_id=62750 |title=Askal |first=Michael |last=Tan |publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |accessdate=2007-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215173540/http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view_article.php?article_id=62750 |archivedate=February 15, 2009 }}{{unreliable source?|date=June 2015}}PAWS reports that at one point, 98% of the calls it received about cruelty and abuse involved askals. ==Interactions with humans== Askals have been raised traditionally as guard dogs of the home and farm. They are naturally suspicious of strangers, independent and protective of family members. They are also good to very young children as companions due to their devotion to family members. They are usually trusted by their Filipino owners to roam around town markets or the neighborhood to socialize with other dogs which is why these dogs are seen by the Western people as stray dogs when, in fact, they are not. They are, however, expected to be home before dusk especially the males who would always be looking for females in heat. Female dogs usually stay home and are excellent watch dogs. Aspins were allowed to compete in the First Philippine Dog Agility Championships in 2013.{{cite news |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/415039/aspin-to-compete-in-national-dog-show |title=Aspin to compete in national dog show |last=Jose Santino S. Bunachita |date=May 25, 2013 |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |accessdate=10 June 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://archive.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/local-news/2013/05/26/5-cities-canines-come-bow-wow-284205 |title=From 5 cities, canines come to bow, wow in Philippine Dog Agility Association |work=Sun.Star |last=Jujemay G. Awit |date=May 26, 2013 |accessdate=10 June 2015}} At the 2015 Pet Express Doggie Run in [[Pasay City]], aspins were the featured type of dog.{{cite news |url=http://www.interaksyon.com/lifestyle/pet-life-pet-express-doggie-run-2015-aspins-shine-and-get-second-chances-at-life |title=Pet Express Doggie Run 2015: ‘Aspins’ shine and get second chances at life |last=Melissa G. Bagamasbad |date=March 17, 2015 |accessdate=10 June 2015}} The dogs featured in an essay by [[Gilda Cordero-Fernando]].{{cite book |last=Ventura |first=Sylvia Mendez |title=A Literary Journey with Gilda Cordero-Fernando |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWdzSUyRYhcC&pg=PA94 |accessdate=10 June 2015 |year=2005 |publisher=UP Press |isbn=978-971-542-483-7 |pages=94–}} Aspins have been trained by the Coast Guard to identify bombs and drugs by scent.{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/01/27/1417222/20-bomb-sniffing-dogs-us-secure-apec-meet|title=20 bomb-sniffing dogs from US to secure APEC meet|last=Non Alquitran|date=January 27, 2015|work=The Philippine Star|accessdate=10 June 2015}} ==Notable aspins== *[[Kabang]], an aspin who lost a [[snout]] while saving two young children{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rUnCBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA87|title=Daisy to the Rescue: True Stories of Daring Dogs, Paramedic Parrots, and Other Animal Heroes|last=Campbell|first=Jeff|date=2014-10-07|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=978-1-936976-62-1|pages=87–|accessdate=10 June 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/277446/pinoyabroad/news/phl-s-hero-dog-kabang-soon-to-undergo-20-000-facial-surgery-in-us |title=PHL's hero dog Kabang soon to undergo $20,000 facial surgery in US |date=2012-10-09 |newspaper=GMA News Online |accessdate=18 August 2016}} * Dagul (won the Lewyt Award for Heroic Compassionate Animals, of the North Shore Animal League of America) {{cite news|url=http://www.animalpeoplenews.org/LEWYT/lewyt9.03.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040505165655/http://www.animalpeoplenews.org/LEWYT/lewyt9.03.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 May 2004 |title=FORMER FILIPINO STREET DOG WARNS 16 YEAR OLD MASTER OF IMPENDING AVALANCHE: Dagul's Bravery Merits North Shore Animal League America's Lewyt Award (September 2003) |accessdate=9 March 2014 |newspaper=Animal People }} ==See also== *[[List of dog breeds]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Domestic dog}} {{Breed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Dog Breeds}} [[Category:Dog types|Dog types]] page.title: Bigelow v. RKO Radio Pictures, Inc.

revision.comment: added library of congress source for scan of U.S. Reports; citation tweaks
revision.text:
{{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=Bigelow v. RKO Radio Pictures, Inc. |ArgueDate=February 7 |ArgueYear=1946 |DecideDate=February 25 |DecideYear=1946 |FullName=Bigelow v. RKO Radio Pictures, Inc. |USVol=327 |USPage=251 |ParallelCitations=66 S. Ct. 574; 90 [[L. Ed.]] 652 |Prior= |Subsequent=Rehearing denied, {{ussc|327|817|1946|el=no}}. |Holding=A damage award does not need to be mathematically precise, but it must be a just and reasonable estimate based on the evidence presented, and not based on speculation. Can use yardstick or before & after, but must be careful to use comparable data. |SCOTUS=1945-1946 |Majority=Stone |JoinMajority= |Concurrence= |Concurrence2= |Dissent=Frankfurter |JoinDissent= |NotParticipating=Jackson |LawsApplied=[[Sherman Antitrust Act|Sherman Act]], 15 U.S.C. §§ 1, 2 and 7; [[Clayton Antitrust Act|Clayton Act]], §§ 4 and 16 }} '''''Bigelow v. RKO Radio Pictures, Inc.''''', 327 U.S. 251 (1946), was a decision by the [[United States Supreme Court]] allowing an action to recover [[Compensatory damages#Compensatory damages|compensatory damages]] under the antitrust statutes. The jury had returned a verdict for $120,000 in petitioner's favor, covering a five-year period where plaintiff suffered due to respondents' antitrust conspiracy. The trial court, sitting in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois|Northern District of Illinois]], gave judgment for treble damages, as prescribed by § 4 of the [[Clayton Antitrust Act|Clayton Act]]. The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit|7th Circuit]] reversed on the sole ground that the evidence of damage was not sufficient for submission to the jury, and directed the entry of judgment for respondents ''non obstante veredicto'' (notwithstanding the verdict).<ref>150 F.2d 877 (7th Cir. 1945)</ref> The Supreme Court granted [[certiorari]] to determine whether the evidence of damage was sufficient to support the verdict. Respondents argued that any measure of damages would be too speculative and uncertain to afford an accurate measure of the amount of the damage.<ref>327 U.S. 251, 263</ref> The Supreme Court disagreed, not wanting to let the respondent defeat a remedy because its antitrust violation was so effective and complete. The Court held that the jury could return a verdict for the plaintiffs, even though damages could not be measured with the exactness which would otherwise have been possible, so long as the jury made a "just and reasonable estimate of the damage based on relevant data".<ref>''Id''. at 264</ref> The judgment of the district court was affirmed and the judgment of the court of appeals was reversed.
==Facts== Petitioners, owners of the Jackson Park motion picture theatre in Chicago, alleged that respondents, some of whom, like [[RKO Pictures]], were distributors of films, and some of whom owned or controlled theatres in [[Chicago]], entered into a [[Sherman Antitrust Act#Inference of conspiracy|conspiracy]] which continued from some time before November 1936 to the date the suit was brought, July 28, 1942. During the conspiracy, films were distributed among cinemas in Chicago in such a manner that theatres owned by some of the conspirators were able to show movies before independent theater operators. Independent exhibitors were not able to show new movies until the conspirators had finished with a "[[First run films|first run]]".
The first question was whether there was an unlawful conspiracy, and the second question was how to measure the damages for any loss, given the difficulty of knowing how many people might have attended different films.
==Judgment== The Supreme Court found that it was "indisputable that the jury could have found that ... a first run theater possessed competitive advantages over later run theaters" and that this discriminatory release was "damaging to petitioners".<ref>''Id''. at 260</ref> The problem, however, was the uncertainty in determining to what amount those damages should total. The petitioners submitted two methodologies for calculating damages. The first was the '''yardstick method''', which compared the earnings from petitioner's theater, Jackson Park, during the conspiracy to the earnings of its competitor, the Maryland Theater. The two theaters were comparable in size, although the Jackson Park theater was "superior in location, equipment, and attractiveness to patrons."<ref>''Id''. at 258</ref> The Maryland Theater, however, was owned by [[Paramount Pictures]], and benefited from the conspiracy. The evidence showed that during the five-year period, Maryland's profit exceeded petitioner's like profit by $115,982.34.
The second measure was the '''before & after method'''. Here, the Court looked to the years 1933-1937, where the petitioner had successfully showed at least some first run movies, to the five-year period where the conspiracy was established to have happened, and petitioner was completely shut out of first run movies despite its best efforts. This comparison showed a falling off of petitioners' profits during the five-year period aggregating $125,659.00.
The 7th Circuit concluded that the jury had adopted the before & after method, but that this proof did not furnish a proper measure of damage for the reason that it could not be proved what petitioner's earnings would have been in the absence of the illegal distribution of films. The Supreme Court reversed, holding that a damage award does not need to be mathematically precise, but it must be a just and reasonable estimate based on the evidence presented, and not based on speculation. Petitioners are able to submit yardstick or before & after estimates, but they must be careful to use comparable data.
==See also== * [[United States antitrust law]] * ''[[United States v. Paramount Pictures, Inc.]]'', 334 U.S. 131 (1948), deciding the fate of movie studios owning their own theatres and holding exclusivity rights on which theatres would show their films. * [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 327]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{caselaw source | case = Bigelow v. RKO Radio Pictures, Inc., {{ussc|327|251|1946|el=no}} | findlaw = https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-supreme-court/327/251.html | justia = https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/327/251/ | loc =http://cdn.loc.gov/service/ll/usrep/usrep327/usrep327251/usrep327251.pdf }}

{{cleanup|date=January 2013|reason=May contain too many 'opinions' but may need more encyclopaedic information.}}
'''Cantonese slang''' is a type of [[slang]] used in areas where [[Cantonese|Cantonese language]] is spoken.
==History== {{expand section|date=January 2013}} As ties with Hong Kong and [[Mainland China]] increased, usage of Cantonese slang and adaptations of Cantonese slang into other Chinese dialects increased within the Mainland.<ref>Hsing, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=py6kE5SeoL8C&pg=PA33&dq=Hong+Kong+Cantonese+Slang&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wPXlUNDBEYyu8AS2xYDACA&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Hong%20Kong%20Cantonese%20Slang&f=false 33].</ref>
==Usage== [[Linda Lai Chiu-han|Linda Chiu-han Lai]], author of "Film and Enigmatization," said that it is not possible to translate Cantonese slang, like how slang in other languages cannot be translated.<ref name=Lai242>Lai, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Bmihe5fRwV4C&pg=PA242&dq=Hong+Kong+Cantonese+Slang&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wPXlUNDBEYyu8AS2xYDACA&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Hong%20Kong%20Cantonese%20Slang&f=false 242].</ref>
Wong Man Tat Parco wrote a thesis on the usage of Cantonese slang by young people in [[Hong Kong]]. He said "[i]n terms of the frequency of slang use, the present research findings suggest that females are by no means passive slang users nowadays. Therefore the traditional belief that males are slang dominators and females slang eschewers... does not hold true at present time any longer."<ref>Adams, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UrrCoCUiW3gC&pg=PA85&dq=Hong+Kong+Cantonese+Slang&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wPXlUNDBEYyu8AS2xYDACA&ved=0CFgQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Hong%20Kong%20Cantonese%20Slang&f=false 85].</ref>
==Types of slang== {{expand section|date=January 2013}} {{see also|Cantonese profanity}} "[[Triad (organized crime)|Triad]] language" is a type of Cantonese slang. It is censored out of television and films, and triad language. Kingsley Bolton and Christopher Hutton, the authors of "Bad Boys and Bad Language: Chòu háu and the Sociolinguistics of Swear Words in Cantonese," said that regardless of official discouragement of the use of triad language, "[T]riad language or triad-associated language is an important source of innovation in Hong Kong Cantonese."<ref name=BoltonHutton300>Bolton and Hutton, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=AGivRsg7ZjAC&pg=PA300&dq=Hong+Kong+Cantonese+Slang&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wPXlUNDBEYyu8AS2xYDACA&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Hong%20Kong%20Cantonese%20Slang&f=false 300].</ref>
''Chòu háu'' (粗口, Jyutping: cou1 hau2, Mandarin Pinyin: ''Cūkǒu'', Lit: Coarse Mouth) refers to sexually explicit taboo words. In Hong Kong print media, feature fils, and television, such words are censored. Bolton and Hutton said "[t]he use of ''chòu háu'' is often seen as a marker of criminality of triad-membership, and official agencies tend to view the spread of ''chòu háu'' into the mainstream of Hong Kong society and its media as indicating a general crisis, as being symptomatic of a rising tide of social disorder and alienation."<ref name=BoltonHutton300/>
Two way of talking in Cantonese slang is "[[Moh lei tau]]." [[Chow Sing Chi]], a comedy actor, started the slang in the 1990s. "Moh lei tau" became popular with younger people and secondary school students, and the groups began to use it. The slang made Chow well-known and financially prosperous. Some prominent members of Hong Kong society believed that the slang was lowering the quality of the language and asked youth to stop using it. Sue Wright, author of ''One Country, Two Systems, Three Languages: A Survey of Changing Language Use in Hong Kong'', said in 1997 that "The rage is over now; the role of television in starting it remains indisputable."<ref>Wright, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=uys1QNq4t-AC&pg=PA14&dq=Hong+Kong+Cantonese+Slang&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wPXlUNDBEYyu8AS2xYDACA&ved=0CGoQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Hong%20Kong%20Cantonese%20Slang&f=false 14].</ref>
==Attitudes towards slang== {{expand section|date=January 2013}} The authorities in [[Hong Kong]] monitor film and television for slang, removing what is considered to be inappropriate. Kingsley Bolton and Christopher Hutton, the authors of "Bad Boys and Bad Language: Chòu háu and the Sociolinguistics of Swear Words in Cantonese," said that Hong Kong authorities have far less tolerance of vulgar words than in western societies such as the [[United Kingdom]] and that aspect is "seems to distinguish the situation" in Hong Kong.<ref name=BoltonHutton300/>
==Slang terms== {{expand section|date=January 2013}} There are a lot of slang terms in Hong Kong, for example there are terms for members of minority groups include "鬼佬[[gweilo]]," (ghost man) refers to [[White people]] (mainly US and UK) because of the eye, hair and skin color differences, "ga tau", "ga jai", and "蘿白頭 lo baat tau" ([[radish]] head) meaning [[Japanese people]], "bak gwei" (white ghost) meaning Caucasians, "黑鬼 hak gwei" (black ghost) refers to [[Black people]] while the "ghost" part is inherited from "鬼佬[[gweilo]]" (ghost man) in a sense meaning foreigners, "bun mui/jai" meaning [[Philippine people|Filipina/Filipino]] domestic employees, and "阿差ah cha" or "阿星 ah sing" meaning [[Indian people]] and [[Pakistani people]].<ref>Lo, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=I0kvN9LDHP0C&pg=PA69&dq=Hong+Kong+Cantonese+Slang&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wPXlUNDBEYyu8AS2xYDACA&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Hong%20Kong%20Cantonese%20Slang&f=false 69].</ref>
==Significance of slang== [[Linda Chiu-han Lai]], author of "Film and Enigmatization," said that "The power of Cantonese slang is instantaneously differentiating at the moment of utterance: it distinguishes not only Cantonese from [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] speakers, but also Cantonese speakers in Hong Kong from those who live in places like [[Singapore]], [[Malaysia]], [[Guangzhou|Canton]], [[Canada]], and so on—part of the [[Cantonese diaspora]]."<ref name=Lai242/>
==See also== {{wiktionary|Category:Cantonese slang}} {{Portal|China|Hong Kong|Languages}} * [[Mandarin Chinese profanity|Chinese slang]] * [[Cantonese profanity]] * [[Diu (Cantonese)]] * [[Hong Kong slang]]
==References== * Adams, Michael. ''Slang: The People's Poetry''. [[Oxford University Press]], 2009. {{ISBN|0195314638}}, 9780195314632. * Bolton, Kingsley and Christopher Hutton. "Bad Boys and Bad Language: ''Chòu háu'' and the Sociolinguistics of Swear Words in Cantonese." In: Evans, Grant and Maria Tam Siu-mi (editors). ''Hong Kong: The Anthropology of a Chinese Metropolis''. [[University of Hawaii Press]], 1997. {{ISBN|0824820053}}, 9780824820053. * Hsing, You-Tien. ''Making Capitalism in China: The Taiwan Connection''. [[Oxford University Press]], 1998. {{ISBN|0195103246}}, 9780195103243. * Lai, Linda Chiu-han. "Chapter Ten: Film and Enigmatization: Nostalgia, Nonsense, and Remembering." in Yau, Esther Ching-Mei. ''At Full Speed: Hong Kong Cinema in a Borderless World''. [[University of Minnesota Press]], 2001. {{ISBN|0816632359}}, 9780816632350. * Lo, Kwai-Cheung. "Invisible Neighbors: Racial Minorities and the Hong Kong Chinese Community." In: Kerr, Douglas. ''Critical Zone 3: A Forum of Chinese and Western Knowledge''. [[Hong Kong University Press]], April 30, 2009. {{ISBN|9622098576}}, 9789622098572. * Wright, Sue. ''One Country, Two Systems, Three Languages: A Survey of Changing Language Use in Hong Kong''. [[Multilingual Matters]], 1997. {{ISBN|1853593966}}, 9781853593963.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Christopher Hutton, Kingsley Bolton. ''A Dictionary of Cantonese Slang: The language of Hong Kong M, Street Gangs and City Life''. [[Hurst & Company]], January 1, 2006. {{ISBN|1850654190}}, 9781850654193.

{{Multiple issues| {{cleanup|reason=Large portions of this article are more like a business directory than an encyclopedia article. This article should not be a list of individually non-notable businesses.|date=March 2018}} {{lead too short|date=April 2016}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} [[File:Catsrepublic.jpg|thumbnail|275px|Cat cafe "Cats Republic" [[Saint Petersburg, Russia]]]] A '''cat café''' is a theme [[Coffeehouse|café]] whose attraction is [[cat]]s that can be watched and played with.{{Cite web|url=https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/cat-cafe|title=cat café Meaning in the Cambridge English Dictionary|website=dictionary.cambridge.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-10}} == Etymology == ''Cat café'' has been officially recognized in the online edition of the [[Oxford Dictionary of English]] since August 2015.{{cite web|title=New words in oxforddictionaries|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/aug/27/hangry-bants-fatberg-new-words-in-oxforddictionaries|accessdate=28 August 2015}}
{{Cite news|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/27/us-life-manspread-idUSKCN0QW1Y620150827|title = Manspreading, hangry, Grexit join Oxford online dictionary|date = 27 August 2015|work = |access-date = |publisher = Reuters}} ==History== The world's first cat café, "Cat Flower Garden" (貓花園[[Nihon Keizai Shimbun|Nikkei BP]] : [http://trendy.nikkeibp.co.jp/article/column/20080422/1009762/ Article on 2 May 2008] {{jp icon}}), opened its doors in [[Taipei]], Taiwan, in 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/travel/story/20120402-worldwide-weird-feline-fun-in-japans-cat-cafes|title=BBC - Travel - Feline fun in Japan's cat cafes|first=Lindsey | last=Galloway|publisher=|accessdate=7 January 2016}} The Taiwanese cat café eventually became a tourist destination, attracting tourists from Japan as well as all over the globe.{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/56592/brief-history-cat-cafe|title=A Brief History of the Cat Café|work=Mental Floss|accessdate=7 January 2016}} Although the origin of cat café is in Taiwan, the concept blossomed in Japan, where the first one named "Neko no Jikan" (lit. "Cat's Time") was opened in [[Osaka]] in 2004. Due to the Japan's land size and population, many residents live in small apartments or condominiums which do not allow pets, making a cat café a very popular destination for young workers looking for the companionship and comfort offered. Tokyo's first cat café, named "Neko no mise" (Shop of Cats), opened in 2005. After this, the popularity of cat cafés boomed in Japan. From 2005 to 2010, seventy-nine cat cafés opened across the country.{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/read/meow-meow-meow-329-v17n2|title=Meow Meow Meow|first=Tomo | last=Kosuga|work=VICE|accessdate=7 January 2016}} ==Controversy== In the United Kingdom animal charities disagree on whether cat cafés are a suitable environment for cats with the [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals|RSPCA]], [[Cats Protection]] and the [[Celia Hammond#Celia Hammond Animal Trust|Celia Hammond Animal Trust]] criticizing them for keeping large numbers of cats in a confined space with a revolving population of people. International Cat Care takes a more positive view saying "It is a difficult environment to get right but it's not impossible by any means". However, all the charities agree that cat cafés need to be properly regulated.{{cite news|title=Are cat cafes good for cats?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-37199653|accessdate=14 September 2016|work=BBC News|date=13 September 2016}} == Asia == ===India=== India's first cat café, Cat Café Studio, opened in 2010 in [[Mumbai]].{{cite web|first=Anju | last=Maskeri|title=This Versova cafe is home to adorable cats |url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/this-versova-cafe-is-home-to-adorable-cats/16272150 | date=7 June 2015 | accessdate=18 May 2017 }} ===Japan=== [[File:Nekokaigi, a cat cafe in Kyoto - March 16, 2010.jpg|thumb|''Nekokaigi'', a small cat café in [[Kyoto]].]] [[File:Roo Female Somali in Cat Café Tokyo.jpg|thumb|left|Female [[Somali cat|Somali]] in cat Café in Tokyo]] Cat cafés are quite popular in Japan, with [[Tokyo]] being home to 58 cat cafés {{as of|2015|lc=y}}.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/tokyo-cat-cafe-shut-down-animal-neglect-063457497.html?ref=gs|title=Tokyo cat cafe shut down for animal neglect|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}} The first was {{nihongo|''Cat's Store''|猫の店|Neko no Mise}}, by Norimasa Hanada, which opened in 2005. The popularity of cat cafés in Japan is attributed to many apartments forbidding pets, and to cats providing relaxing companionship in what may otherwise be a stressful and lonesome urban life. Other forms of [[pet rental]], such as rabbit cafés, are also common in Japan."[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120216f2.html?fb_ref=article_japantimes Tokyo's rabbit cafes hopping with customers]." ''[[The Japan Times]]''. 16 February 2012. Retrieved on 13 July 2013. There are various types of cat cafés in Japan. Some feature specific categories of cat such as [[black cat]]s, fat cats, rare [[cat breed|breed]] cats or ex-[[feral cat|stray cat]]s. Every cat café in Japan is required to obtain a license and comply with the strict requirements and regulations of the nation's Animal Treatment and Protection Law.Iwata, Mamiko, [[About.com|All About]] : [http://allabout.co.jp/pet/cat/closeup/CU20100051A/ Article on 7 March 2010] {{jp icon}} Japanese cat cafés feature strict rules to ensure cleanliness and animal welfare, in particular seeking to ensure that the cats are not disturbed by excessive and unwanted attention, such as by young children or when sleeping. Many cat cafés also seek to raise awareness of cat welfare issues, such as abandoned and stray cats and many often have cats from local animal shelters to help them lose any fear of humans and advertise them for possible adoption. From 2012 the cats could be displayed until 8 pm, but in 2016 the guidelines of the [[Ministry of the Environment (Japan)|environment ministry]] state that they may visit and play with customers until 10 pm.[http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/real-life/wtf/cats-at-japans-cat-cafes-now-allowed-to-stay-up-till-10pm/news-story/ab6955ba24d2af012438cd4c6b999c4a Cats at Japan's ‘cat cafes’ now allowed to stay up till 10pm 28 April 2016] ''News.com.au'' Retrieved 3 May 2016 One café in Tokyo added goats as a way of having a unique element."[https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2013/jul/11/tokyo-cafe-goats-video Tokyo cafe employs goats to add 'wow factor' - video]." ''[[Reuters]]'' at ''[[The Guardian]]''. 11 July 2013. Retrieved on 13 July 2013. === South Korea === South Korea also has several cat cafés, most in Seoul, the capital city of South Korea. Cat cafés in South Korea have been very successful among both residents and tourists in South Korea. It is quite easy to find a cat café at Seoul these days. Customers can even adopt a cat at the cat cafés if they want. {{Cite news|url=http://groovekorea.com/article/cat-cafe-express/|title=Cat Café Express - Groove Magazine|date=2016-05-17|work=Groove Magazine|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}} There are also rules that Customers must follow before they hang out with cats like they need to take off their shoes and wash their hands. === Singapore === The first cat café in Singapore is Cat Café Neko no Niwa (Japanese for ‘Cat Garden’). As of today, there are at least five cat cafés in the city.{{cite web|title=Cat cafés in Singapore: boon or bane for cats?|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/cat-caf%C3%A9s-in-singapore--boon-or-bane-for-cats-092913198.html|accessdate=23 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Which of the 3 cat cafes in S’pore is the best?|url=http://mothership.sg/2014/07/which-of-the-3-cat-cafes-in-spore-is-the-best/|accessdate=23 September 2015}} The cat cafés are namely Neko no Niwa, The Cat Cafés, The Company of Cats, Meomi Cat Café and Cuddles Cat Café. Neko no Niwa, The Company of Cats and The Cat Café feature cats who were rescued.{{Cite web|title = Five Cat Cafés That Have Taken Over Singapore And Why You Need To Visit Them - MustShareNews.com|url = http://mustsharenews.com/singapores-cat-cafes/|website = MustShareNews.com|accessdate = 29 October 2015}} The Singaporean Cat Cafes are regulated and licensed by [[Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore|AVA]] and they are all bound to a 'code of conduct'. Individuals having questions with their cat needs, can join the Cat Welfare Society, which helps with medical fees, sterilization costs or adopting of the cats. Cat Cafes usually have their own/specific houserules.{{cite web|title=The Cat Cafe Houserules|url=http://thecatcafe.sg/cat-cafe-rules/T|accessdate=4 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Cat Cafe Neko no Niwa|url=http://www.catcafe.com.sg/cafe-rules/|accessdate=4 September 2015}} Cuddles Cat Cafe was investigated by [[Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore]] (AVA) in December 2014.{{cite web|title=AVA investigates allegations of animal deaths at cat cafe|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/ava-investigates-allegations-animal-deaths-cat-cafe|accessdate=3 September 2015}} === Taiwan === Cats are popular pets in Taiwan, with the cat population increasing rapidly in recent years.{{cite web|url=http://taiwantoday.tw/ct.asp?xItem=242246&ctNode=2183|title=Taiwan's love affair with cats purrs ahead|publisher=}} The world's first cat café, named "Cat Flower Garden", opened in [[Taipei]] in 1998,{{cite web|last=Galloway |first=Lindsey |url=http://www.bbc.com/travel/story/20120402-worldwide-weird-feline-fun-in-japans-cat-cafes |title=Travel - Feline fun in Japan's cat cafes |publisher=BBC |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=19 June 2016}} where there is also a luxurious "Cathy Hotel" especially for cats. The Taiwanese cat café concept next spread to Japan, and later to most other countries around the world.{{cite web|last=Lemmin |first=Ulrike |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/06/16/travel/cat-cafes-world/ |title=Cat-ching! Cat cafes take over world - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=16 June 2014 |accessdate=19 June 2016}} === Thailand === Thailand has several cat cafés, most in Bangkok. Cat Cafe by Dome, Cat Up Cafe, Caturday, Cataholic Cafe, The Coffee Cat, Mohu Mohu Cafe and Purr Cat Cafe Club are all located in Bangkok.{{Cite web|title = Dogs, Cats, Lattes: Bangkok's Best Pet Cafes|url = http://bk.asia-city.com/city-living/article/bangkoks-top-cafe-pets|website = BK Magazine Online|accessdate = 24 November 2015}} Each serves baked goods with a small menu of main dishes and coffee and tea. Many have special pricing for petting time with a specific cat. Prices are usually higher than at most cafés but not unreasonably so. They all have rules regarding the behavior of guests towards the cats and often have purebred cats. Catmosphere Cat Cafe and Maewmoth cafés are located in Chiang Mai.{{Cite web|title = Cats With Your Cappuccino?|url = http://www.chiangmaicitylife.com/citylife-articles/cats-with-your-cappuccino/|website = Chiang Mai Citylife|accessdate = 24 November 2015}} ==Europe== [[File:Cat Cafe (Cat Caffe).jpg|thumb|Cat cafe in [[Ljubljana]], Slovenia.]] === Austria === According to local legend, the world's first cat café opened in Vienna in the summer of 1912 and ceased operation approximately two years later. It is said that Vladimir Lenin was a regular for a period in 1913, finding the feline companionship a comfort during his time of exile. The cat café is known to have ceased operation shortly after the beginning of the First World War, although the much repeated story that the closure was due to its patriotic owner's donating all the cats to a factory making fur-lined boots for the war effort may be apocryphal.{{cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/uk/the-oldie/20151209/282218009716840|title=PressReader.com - Connecting People Through News|website=www.pressreader.com}} In 2012 cat café Neko was opened in Vienna. === Belgium === Le Chat Touille opened up in [[Brussels]] in 2014.{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} DreamCATchers opened in [[Ghent]] in 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://wearedreamcatchers.be|title=We Are DreamCATchers|website=wearedreamcatchers.be|language=nl|access-date=2018-01-24}} It takes in cats from shelters, rehabilitates them if necessary with the aid of volunteers and a cat behavioural therapist, to then allow them to be adopted by customers. It runs entirely off of donations and money customers spend in the café or on products from their sponsors. === Czech Republic === Kočkafé Freya opened in Prague in 2014. It was followed by three other cafes in [[Prague]], along with cat cafes in [[Olomouc]], [[Pardubice]], and other Czech cities. === Denmark === Cafe Miao opened up in Copenhagen in 2014, but closed in 2017. === Estonia === The first cat café in Estonia, Kassikohvik Nurri, opened in October 2014 in [[Tallinn]]. === Finland === The first cat café in Finland, Kissakahvila Purnauskis, opened in November 2014 in [[Tampere]]. It is a permanent home for seven cats. The second cat café, Kissakahvila Helsinki, opened in July 2015 in [[Helsinki]]. It is a permanent home for six cats.{{cite web|title=Cats, Home, People|url=http://www.kissakahvilahelsinki.fi/|website=Official website: Kissakahvila Helsinki|accessdate=6 October 2016}} === France === Le Café des Chats is a cat café located on 16 Rue Michel le Comte in Paris in 2013. This café is a diner that includes desserts, tea, and, of course, cats.{{cite news |url=http://www.francetvinfo.fr/animaux/video-les-matous-ont-leur-havre-de-paix-a-paris-le-cafe-des-chats_419527.html |title=Vidéo: A Paris, le Café des chats invite les clients à un moment de ronron |publisher=[[France TV]] |date=24 September 2013 |language=French }} Kafelin is a cat cafe in Montpellier. ===Germany === Stubentiger Cafe in [[Hannover]] opened in August 2015 with a varied menu, including vegetarian, gluten-free and vegan.{{cite web|url=http://www.stubentigercafe.de/|title=STUBENTIGER CAFE - Café|work=Stubentiger Cafe Hannover|accessdate=18 April 2016}} In Munich, there is Café Katzentempel. Cologne has Cafe Schnurrke.{{cite web|url=http://www.cafeschnurrke.de/index.htm|title=Cafe Schnurrke - erstes und einziges Katzencafe in Köln|publisher=|accessdate=18 April 2016}} In Berlin there is Pee Pees Katzencafe,{{cite web|title=In Neukölln, Drink Your Latte With The House Cat|url=http://www.nprberlin.de/term/cat-cafes-germany#stream/0|publisher=NPR Berlin Morning Edition|accessdate=27 April 2016|date=14 November 2013}} BaristaCats,{{cite web|url=http://www.katzencafe-berlin.de/|title=BaristaCats }} and Zur Mieze.{{cite web|url=http://www.zur-mieze.de|title=Katzenmusikcafe Zur Mieze }} === Hungary === Cat Café & Gallery is located in downtown Budapest near St. Stephen's Basilica at Révay utca 3.{{cite web|url=http://catcafebudapest.hu/|title=CatCafe Budapest|publisher=|accessdate=18 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161122193836/http://catcafebudapest.hu/#|archive-date=22 November 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Cat Café is located on Damjanich utca 38.{{cite web|url=http://catcafe.hu/en|title=Catcafe - Macska kávézó|publisher=|accessdate=18 April 2016}} === Italy === The first Italian cat café opened in [[Turin]] in March 2014; at first it hosted six cats. Its name is MiaGola Café,{{cite news | title = Sei gatti "seduti" al MiaGola Café a intrattenere i clienti | first = Antonella | last = Mariotti | journal = [[La Stampa]] | date = 21 March 2015 | url = http://www.lastampa.it/2014/03/21/societa/lazampa/sei-gatti-seduti-al-miagola-caf-a-intrattenere-i-clienti-OC7GPfL46fd1WNj4WKaKLO/pagina.html |language = it }} which in Italian can be interpreted as a [[language game]]: literally ''mia gola'' can be translated ''my throat'', while ''miagola'' ([[Stressed syllable|stressed]] on the first syllable: miàgola) means ''(he or she) [[Cat communication#meow|meows]]''. The Neko Cat Cafe was opened in [[Turin]] on 5 April 2014.{{cite web|title=Get the Purrr-fect Snack in These Cat Cafés Around the World|url=https://www.yahoo.com/style/get-the-purrr-fect-snack-in-these-cat-cafes-around-the-101432148032.html|publisher=Yahoo Travel|accessdate=18 April 2016|date=3 November 2014}}{{cite web|author1=Alessandra Magliaro|title=Cat cafe, from Japan to Italy was born the trend|url=http://www.ansa.it/web/notizie/specializzati/lifestyle/2014/01/02/Cat-cafe-Giappone-Italia-nasce-trend_10231867.html|publisher=ANSA LIfestyle|accessdate=18 April 2016}} The resident cats are all adopted from animal welfare organizations. ===Latvia=== The cat café in Latvia, MINKA cat cafe, opened in Riga in February 2015 and was closed in September 2016. MINKA Cat Cafe was located near the center at Meža street 4a.{{cite news|title=Durvis vērusi Latvijā pirmā kaķu kafejnīca|url=http://www.delfi.lv/izklaide/dzivesstils/stils/foto-durvis-verusi-latvija-pirma-kaku-kafejnica.d?id=45591742|accessdate=2 May 2016|newspaper=Delfi|date=18 February 2015}} ===Lithuania=== The cat café in Lithuania "Cat Cafe Kačių kavinė" opened in Vilnius in October 2014. Cat Cafe is located in center at Jasinskio str 1. It is one of the biggest cafes with cats in the world. 15 cats live there.{{cite news|title=Vilniaus centre kurs kačių kavinę|url=http://vz.lt/article/2014/2/6/vilniaus-centre-kurs-ka..|accessdate=6 February 2014|newspaper=Time Out|date=6 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304064000/http://vz.lt/article/2014/2/6/vilniaus-centre-kurs-ka..|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} ===Netherlands=== The cat café ''Kopjes'' opened in [[Amsterdam]] in April 2015.{{cite news |first=Janene |last=Pieters |url=http://www.nltimes.nl/2015/04/22/amsterdam-cat-cafe-opens-today/ |title=Amsterdam Cat Cafe Opens Today |newspaper=NL Times |date=22 April 2015 }} In [[Groningen]] ''Kattencafé Op z'n Kop'' opened in February 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.nu.nl/groningen/4212881/kattencafe-opent-deuren-.html|title=Kattencafé opent de deuren|work=NU|accessdate=18 April 2016}} and cat café ''Poeslief'' opened in October 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvhn.nl/groningen/Tweede-kattencaf%C3%A9-in-Groningen-opent-deuren-21714435.html|title=Tweede Kattencafé in Groningen opent deuren|work=Dagblad van het Noorden|accessdate=19 October 2016}} The cat café ''Miespoes'' opened in [[Den Bosch]] in 2016, as did cat café ''Katdeau'' in [[Hengelo]]. In August 2016 ''kattencafé Ditjes & Katjes'' opened in [[The Hague]].{{cite news|title=Kroelen bij opening nieuw kattencafé in Den Haag|url=http://www.ad.nl/den-haag/kroelen-bij-opening-nieuw-kattencafe-in-den-haag~a837774f/|accessdate=26 March 2017|publisher=AD|date=9 August 2016}} Shortly afterwards Pebbles opened its doors as the first cat café in [[Rotterdam]].{{cite news|last1=Post|first1=Ilja|title=Knuffels en cupcakes in Rotterdams eerste kattencafé|url=http://www.metronieuws.nl/nieuws/rotterdam/2016/09/eerste-kattencafe-van-rotterdam-opent-deuren|accessdate=26 March 2017|publisher=Metro|date=24 September 2016}} In 2017, the cat cafe ''Jippies'' opened in [[Haarlem]].{{cite news|last1=Post|first1=Ilja|title=Nieuw in Haarlem: lunchen met 8 katten op schoot|url=https://haerlemsbodem.nl/nieuw-haarlem-lunchen-8-katten-op-schoot/|accessdate=24 April 2018|publisher=Haerlems Bodem|date=14 October 2017}} ===Poland=== "Kociarnia", the first cat café in Poland opened in [[Kraków]] in June 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/594557637354587/photos/a.599527883524229.1073741828.594557637354587/678863572257326/|title=Timeline Photos - Kocia Kawiarnia Kociarnia - Facebook|publisher=|accessdate=7 January 2016}} The name is a combination of Polish words ''kocia'' (of a cat) and ''kawiarnia'' (a café). A second cat café, "Miau Café", opened in [[Warsaw]] in January 2016.{{cite web|title=Miau Cafe|url=http://www.warsawinsider.pl/miau-cafe/|publisher=Warsaw Insider|accessdate=17 June 2016|date=3 February 2016}} This is a coffee and cake cafe that is also a shelter for homeless cats. It has vegan items on the human menu.{{cite web|title=Miau Cafe|url=https://www.happycow.net/reviews/miau-cafe-warsaw-71466|website=[[HappyCow]]|accessdate=17 June 2016}} The Miau Café came to life thanks to the crowdfunding campaign on the Polish platform, wspieram.to where the 1 700 residents of Warsaw pulled in the financial resources to make the idea of the first cat café in Warsaw come true.{{cite web|url=http://www.thealternativetravelguide.com/2016/07/11/when-are-you-going-for-a-coffee-with-cats-cat-cafe-warsaw/|title=WHEN ARE YOU GOING FOR A COFFEE WITH CATS ? - CAT CAFE WARSAW|date=11 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}} [[File:Kocia Kawiarnia Lublin.jpg|thumb|Signboard of Mrau Cafe, [[Lublin]], Poland]] In 2016, another cat café has been opened in Lublin. After one day of activity it has been closed by local sanitary inspection. It launched a lot of controversies in local, and general public media.{{Cite news|url=http://www.lublin112.pl/wojna-sanepidu-z-mrau-cafe-trwa-zadna-ze-stron-nie-poddaje-sie/|title=Wojna Sanepidu z Mrau Cafe trwa. Żadna ze stron nie poddaje się|date=2016-01-07|work=Lublin112.pl Wiadomości z Lublina i regionu. Lublin, Lubelskie, Lubelszczyzna|access-date=2017-11-09|language=pl-PL}} Affair also has been mentioned in popular TV show "Sprawa dla reportera" ("Matter for the reporter"). Eventually, cafe is opened nowadays. ===Romania=== ''Miau Cafe'' opened in Spring 2015 in [[Bucharest]].{{cite news |url=http://www.click.ro/news/bucuresti/aici-vii-sa-bei-cafeaua-si-pleci-cu-mata-la-pachet-foto-exclusiv |title=Aici vii să bei cafeaua şi pleci cu mâţa la pachet |trans-title=You come to have a coffee, you leave with a cat to go |work=[[Click!]] |publisher=[[Adevărul Holding]] |language=Romanian |date=3 July 2015 |accessdate=26 March 2016}} The second cat café in Romania, ''La Pisici Cafe'' opened in September 2015 in Timișoara.{{Cite news|url=http://www.romaniatv.net/idee-inedita-a-doi-tineri-prima-cafenea-cu-pisici-a-fost-deschisa-in-romania-video_245572.html#n|title=Idee inedită a doi tineri. Prima cafenea cu PISICI a fost deschisă în România VIDEO|date=2015-09-19|work=romaniatv.net|access-date=2017-11-05}} A coffee house named ''Lady Cat'' also opened in [[Cluj-Napoca]] in March 2016.{{cite news |url=http://transilvaniareporter.ro/esential/nou-in-cluj-lady-cat-o-cafenea-inchinata-mariei-sale-pisica/ |title=Nou în Cluj: Lady Cat, o cafenea închinată Măriei Sale, pisica |trans-title=New in Cluj: Lady Cat, a coffe house dedicated to Her Royal Highness, the cat |work=Transilvania Reporter |first=Radu |last=Hângănuț |publisher=Transilvania Reporter Media |language=Romanian |date=10 March 2016 |accessdate=26 March 2016}} ===Russia=== [[File:Murchim, cat café 01.jpg|thumb|Cat café in [[Novosibirsk]], Russia.]] The first cat cafe in Europe and in Russia "Cats Republic" was opened in the center of [[Saint Petersburg]] in 2011. There are living 25 cats.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2221118/Feline-like-coffee-St-Petersburg-cafe-offers-customers-chance-enjoy-hot-drink--patting-house-cats.html|title=Feline like a coffee? St Petersburg cafe offers customers the chance to enjoy a hot drink... while patting the in-house cats|date=21 October 2012|work=Mail Online|accessdate=7 January 2016}} === Slovakia === The first cat café in Slovakia, ''Pradúce klbko'' (previously as "Cafe Cats klub") was opened in [[Martin, Slovakia|Martin]] in April 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://myturiec.sme.sk/c/7726943/martin-ma-ako-prvy-na-slovensku-macaciu-kaviaren.html|title=Martin má ako prvý na Slovensku mačaciu kaviareň|last=a.s.|first=Petit Press|work=myturiec.sme.sk|access-date=2017-11-05|language=sk}} The next one, ''Mačkafé'' opened in [[Bratislava]] in May 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://www.modrykocour.cz/kockocteni/zajimavosti/v-kocici-kavarne-dil-sesty-mackafe-bratislava|title=V kočičí kavárně, díl šestý: Mačkafé, Bratislava - Zajímavosti - Modrý kocouř.cz|website=www.modrykocour.cz|access-date=2017-11-05}} The second one in Bratislava, ''Mačinézy'' opened in October 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://refresher.sk/25953-Prva-macacia-kaviaren-v-Bratislave-pomoze-aj-opustenym-zvieratkam|title=Prvá mačacia kaviareň v Bratislave pomôže aj opusteným zvieratkám|last=REFRESHER.sk|access-date=2017-11-05|language=sk}} A cat café named ''Mňaukafé'' also opened in [[Prešov]] in June 2017 as actually fourth in Slovakia.{{Cite news|url=http://presovskyden.sk/spolumajitelka-prvej-macacej-kaviarne-na-vychodnom-slovensku-zakaznici-u-nas-uz-aj-zaspali/|title=Spolumajiteľka prvej mačacej kaviarne na východnom Slovensku: Zákazníci u nás už aj zaspali - presovskyden.sk|date=2017-09-12|work=presovskyden.sk|access-date=2017-11-05|language=sk-SK}} A ''Cat Café Club'' was opened in Poprad in February 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www1.pluska.sk/Regiony/Vychodne-Slovensko/Kavickari-tomto-podniku-zarucene-oddychnete-POZRITE-kto-vas-tu-bude-rozmaznavat|title=Kávičkári, v tomto podniku si zaručene oddýchnete: POZRITE SA, kto vás tu bude rozmaznávať!|access-date=2018-04-02|language=sk}} === Slovenia === The first cat café in Slovenia, ''Cat Caffe Ljubljana'' opened in [[Ljubljana]] in February 2015.{{Cite news|url=http://fashion.si/lifestyle/kulinarika/prva_slovenska_macja_kavarna/|title=Prva slovenska mačja kavarna|access-date=2017-11-05}} === Ukraine === ''Cat Cafe Lviv'' is located in [[Lviv]].{{Cite web|url=http://destinations.com.ua/coffee-breakfast/cat-cafe-lviv|title=Cat Cafe Lviv|website=destinations.com.ua|language=en|access-date=2017-11-05}} ===United Kingdom=== ====England==== The first British cat café opened in [[Totnes]], Devon in June 2013.{{cite news|title=Purrfect! Britain's first cat cafe opens in England's 'Narnia'|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/weird/416380/Purrfect-Britain-s-first-cat-cafe-opens-in-England-s-Narnia|accessdate=14 September 2016|work=Express.co.uk|date=21 July 2013}} However it closed in May 2014 due to staff illness and the need to safeguard the owner's health.{{cite web|title=Closure of Totnes Cats Café (see most recent entry)|url=https://www.facebook.com/Totnes-Cats-Cafe-169555099886252/|website=Facebook, Totnes Cats Café group timeline|accessdate=14 September 2016}} [[File:Manchester Cat Cafe 2016 005.jpg|thumb|The Manchester Cat Café]] In 2014 Lady Dinah's Cat Emporium opened to significant media attention{{cite web|url=http://news.instyle.com/2014/03/12/lady-dinahs-cat-emporium/|title=What's Right Meow: This London Café Has Us Feline Groovy - InStyle.com|work=InStyle.com|accessdate=7 January 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://now-here-this.timeout.com/2013/02/18/funding-secured-for-cat-cafe-to-open-in-east-london/|title=Funding secured for cat café to open in east London|work=Time Out Blog|accessdate=7 January 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cntraveller.com/news/2013/february/cat-cafe-london|title=Lady Dinah's Cat Emporium, Shoreditch - London's cat café (Condé Nast Traveller)|work=Traveller|accessdate=7 January 2016}} and a two-month waiting list.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-26437881 | work=BBC News | title=London cat cafe opens to two-month waiting list | date=6 March 2014}} Newcastle upon Tyne is home to Mog on The Tyne Cat Café,{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/meet-moggy-family-newcastle-city-9626443|title=Meet the moggy family at Newcastle city centre's new cat cafe Mog on the Tyne|first=Coreena | last=Ford|date=10 July 2015|work=nechronicle|accessdate=7 January 2016}} Catpawcino{{cite web|url=https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/business/business-news/newcastle-gets-second-cat-cafe-10135684.}} and Willow Cat Cafe.{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2814062/Newcastle-animal-shelter-opens-cat-cafe-raise-funds-homeless-moggies-popular-introduce-booking-service.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | title=Moggie-lover opens cat cafe to raise funds for feline shelter | date=31 October 2014}} Nottingham has a cat café called Kitty Café.{{cite web|title=Cat Café|url=http://www.leftlion.co.uk/articles.cfm/title/cat-caf-/id/7350|publisher=Left Lion UK|accessdate=7 January 2016}} In 2015, several other UK cafes were in planning.{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/features/the-rise-of-cat-cafes-the-perfect-solution-for-animal-lovers-who-cant-have-pets-10119850.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Camilla | last=Brugrand | title=The rise of cat cafes: the perfect solution for animal lovers who can't have pets | date=20 March 2015}} The Bag of Nails in Bristol is a cat [[pub]], and has had as many as 24 cats.{{cite news |first=Lee |last=Moran |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/cat-pub-bristol_5644b801e4b060377347ebec |title=Move Over Cat Cafes, This Cat Pub Is Taking Over |website=[[Huffington Post]] |date=12 November 2015 }}{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Garrett |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-bristol-34871580 |title=The pub full of cats bringing feline fans to Bristol |publisher=BBC |date=21 November 2015 }} A cat cafe opened in the Northern Quarter of Manchester on 30 July 2016.{{cite news | url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/cat-cafe-manchester-opening-date-11478159 | title=Cat Cafe Manchester announces opening date - and you can book your visit NOW | work=[[Manchester Evening News]] | date=17 June 2016}} Pause cat cafe will open its doors in [[Bournemouth]] later on in the year and will become the first on the South coast. After a crowdfunding campaign, the cafe, at Old Christchurch Road, will have 12 resident rescue cats roaming the two floors. Rescuing felines will be promoted.{{cite web|title=World getting you down? Bournemouth's getting its first-ever cat cafe to help you relax|url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/14881099.World_getting_you_down__Bournemouth_s_getting_it_s_first_ever_cat_cafe_to_help_you_relax/|publisher=Daily Echo|accessdate=16 November 2016|date=11 November 2016}} ====Scotland==== Maison de Moggy is the first cat café in Scotland and opened in January 2015.{{cite news |first=Sarah |last=Vesty |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/weird-news/pictures-scotlands-first-cat-cafe-4989909 |title=In pictures: Scotland's first cat cafe Maison de Moggy opens its doors in Edinburgh |newspaper=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] |date=16 January 2015 }}{{cite news |first=Claire |last=White |url=http://edinburgh.stv.tv/articles/316291-edinburgh-cat-cafe-maison-de-moggy-opening-permanently-in-west-port/ |title=Cat cafe Maison de Moggy finds purr-fect home in West Port |publisher=STV Edinburgh |date=7 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411030205/http://edinburgh.stv.tv/articles/316291-edinburgh-cat-cafe-maison-de-moggy-opening-permanently-in-west-port |archivedate=11 April 2015 }} Purrple Cat Cafe is planning to be Glasgow's first cat cafe, and was due to open in the summer of 2017 but was delayed due to prolonged works, until it was finally near the end of the year. {{Cite news|url=http://www.glasgowlive.co.uk/whats-on/food-drink-news/cat-cafe-opening-glasgow-heres-12577514|title=There is a cat cafe opening in Glasgow - here’s everything we know so far|last=Loney|first=Gillian|date=8 February 2017|work=glasgowlive|access-date=4 March 2017}} There was also a cat café in Aberdeen called The Cat In The Window which opened in 2016 but had faced closure in 2017 {{Cite news|url=https://www.eveningexpress.co.uk/fp/news/local/aberdeens-cat-cafe-facing-closure-fighting-back1/|last=Cameron|first=Ewan|title=Aberdeen's only cat cafe is facing closure ... but it's fighting back|access-date=3 August 2017}} In early 2017, another cat café had opened called Cats Meow Kittea Café in Stirling. {{Cite news|url=https://www.stirlingnews.co.uk/news/15216805.stirling-cafe-offers-cake-coffee-and-the-company-of-cats/|title=Stirling café offers cake, coffee and the company of cats|last=Burns|first=Ashleigh|access-date=11 April 2017}} ==North America== Cat cafés have been spreading across North America since 2014. The goal in North America generally is to help get cats adopted by partnering with local cat rescues.{{cite web|url=https://stevedalepetworld.com/windy-city-to-windy-kitty-help-cat-cafe-to-help-cats/|title=Cat expert Steve Dale supports the Windy Kitty Cat Cafe coming to Chicago|website=stevedalepetworld.com}} ===Canada=== The first cat café to open in Canada was Le Café des Chats/Cat Café Montreal{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/travel/2014/10/18/crazy-cat-ladies-rejoice-the-first-two-kitty-cafes-north-america-now-open-montreal/bVIcWnIkM1bYn50mO6rl3L/story.html|title=Crazy cat ladies rejoice: The first two kitty cafes in North America now open in Montreal - The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com|accessdate=7 January 2016}} in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, which opened its doors to the public in August 2014. Le Café des Chats in August 2014; Café Chat L'Heureux (also in [[Montreal]]) opened in September 2014 with 8 cats adopted from local shelters. Saturday, 17 October 2015 saw the opening of Ontario's first cat café located in [[Guelph]], [[Ontario]].{{cite web|url=http://www.guelphtribune.ca/community-story/5972997-guelph-s-first-kitty-caf-is-open-for-business/|title=Guelph's first Kitty Café is open for business|publisher=|accessdate=7 January 2016}} Catfe opened in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] on 14 December 2015 {{cite web|url=http://www.vancouverobserver.com/news/vancouvers-first-cat-cafe-opens-international-village|title=Vancouver's first cat cafe opens in International Village|first=Jordan | last=Yerman |accessdate=2 March 2016}} and Kitty Cat Café and Pet Me Meow are both planning cafés for [[Toronto]] to open in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://torontoist.com/2014/11/whatever-happened-to-those-rival-cat-cafes/|title=Whatever Happened to Those Rival Cat Cafés?|author=Torontoist|publisher=|accessdate=7 January 2016}} The Siberian Cat Café opened in 2015 [[Chelsea, Quebec|Chelsea]]. This cat café has only [[Siberian cat]]s, making it the first [[Hypoallergenic cats|hypoallergenic]] cat café in the world.{{cite news | title=World's first hypoallergenic cat cafe opening in Chelsea, Quebec | location=Toronto | newspaper=Metro | date=10 June 2015 | url=http://www.metronews.ca/news/canada/2015/06/10/the-worlds-first-hypoallergenic-cat-cafe-is-opening-in-chelsea-quebec.html | accessdate=14 August 2016}} ===United States=== [[File:TCCC01.jpg|alt=The Charming Cat Cafe in Vista Ridge mall, Lewisville, TX|thumb|The Charming Cat Cafe in [[Vista Ridge Mall]], [[Lewisville, Texas]]]] [[File:Cat petting store in lower east side nyc.jpg|thumb|A cat café in the [[Lower East Side]], [[New York City]]]] In the United States, most health departments require special steps to separate the cafe area from area where the cats are housed. In some cases, this even extends to areas that cats pass through only briefly (e.g. an adopted cat must leave through a separate door without passing an area that prepares food).{{cite web|title=What's a Cat Cafe?|url=http://www.catcafesd.com/us/whats-a-cat-cafe/|accessdate=14 April 2016}} Gaining regulatory approval can be difficult, as with KitTea of San Francisco.{{cite web|url=https://www.eater.com/2014/1/23/6293059/san-franciscos-first-cat-cafe-is-in-the-works|title=San Francisco's First Cat Cafe Is In the Works|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://time.com/2280/heres-an-inside-look-at-japans-best-cat-cafes/|title=Here's An Inside Look at Japan's Best Cat Cafes|website=Time}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/kittea-cat-cafe-welcomes-feline-friends/|title=KitTea cat cafe welcomes feline friends|date=23 January 2014|publisher=}}{{Cite web|title = BREAKING: Cat Cafe Coming To San Francisco|url = http://sfist.com/2014/01/22/breaking_cat_cafe_coming_to_san_fra.php|website = SFist|access-date = 1 February 2016|first = Brock|last = Keeling|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160316113426/http://sfist.com/2014/01/22/breaking_cat_cafe_coming_to_san_fra.php|archivedate = 16 March 2016|df = dmy-all}} Starting the process in November 2013,{{cite web|url=https://www.citylab.com/design/2014/01/long-regulatory-road-americas-first-cat-cafe/8200/|title=The Long Regulatory Road to America's First Cat Cafe|publisher=}} KitTea's design was finally approved in August 2014{{cite web|url=https://sf.curbed.com/2014/8/14/10060348/phew-sfs-first-cat-cafe-inks-lease-construction-begins-asap|title=Phew: SF's First Cat Café Inks Lease, Construction Begins ASAP|publisher=}} after extensive negotiation with San Francisco's Health Department. Oakland's Cat Town has the distinct honor of being the first cat cafe to open its doors to customers, signing a lease in July 2014 and opening just months later in October.{{cite news|title=The Race For America's First Cat Cafe Heats Up As Oakland's Cat Town Cafe Signs Lease|url=http://sfist.com/2014/07/02/the_race_for_americas_first_cat_caf.php|work=SFist|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170723141217/http://sfist.com/2014/07/02/the_race_for_americas_first_cat_caf.php|archivedate=23 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} These timelines highlight not only the regulatory hurdles for cat cafes that prepare food on premises, but also differences between local governments that are mere miles from one another. In contrast to Japanese cat cafés, US cafes typically focus on adoptions. Within seven months of being open, Cat Town reported that "the euthanasia rate at its partner shelter has declined from 41 to 21 percent, and 184 cats have made the transition from the cafe's Cat Zone to permanent homes".{{cite news|title=Only Seven Months In, Oakland's Cat Town Cafe Plots an Expansion|url=https://sf.eater.com/2015/5/19/8626289/cat-town-cafe-oakland-expansion-more-space|work=Eater SF}} Similarly, The Cat Cafe in San Diego has facilitated adoptions for more than 250 cats (January 2015 - October 2017){{Cite web|url=https://www.catcafesd.com/updates/2017/10/05/cat-cafe-sends-five-cats-home/|title=The Cat Cafe Sends Five Cats Home in September|last=|first=|date=October 5, 2017|website=The Cat Cafe|accessdate=11 October 2017}} and KitTea of San Francisco has adopted 203 (June 2015 - February 2018).{{cite web|url=https://www.kitteasf.com/adopted-cats/|title=Adopted Cats|website=KitTea}} In June 2015, [[Crumbs and Whiskers]] opened its first cat café in [[Washington, D.C.]], where it partnered with the local chapter of the [[The Humane Society of the United States|Humane Society]]; this café provides a boarding space for around 15–25 cats at a time, all of which are provided by the Humane Society and made available for adoption.{{cite web|author1=Caroline Tucker|title=Cat cafe pounces forward in D.C.|url=http://www.wjla.com/articles/2015/03/cat-cafe-pounces-forward-in-d-c--112694.html|publisher=ABC7|accessdate=29 March 2015|date=28 March 2015}}{{cite web|author1=Courtney Pomeroy|title=D.C.'s Cat Cafe, Crumbs and Whiskers, Makes Strides Toward Opening This Year|url=http://washington.cbslocal.com/2015/03/23/d-c-s-cat-cafe-crumbs-and-whiskers-makes-strides-toward-opening-this-year/|publisher=CBS|accessdate=29 March 2015|date=23 March 2015}}{{cite web|author1=Rachel Nania|title=Founder shares plans for D.C.'s first cat café, Crumbs and Whiskers|url=http://wtop.com/food/2015/02/plans-continue-d-c-s-first-cat-cafe/|website=WTOP|publisher=Washington's Top News|accessdate=29 March 2015|date=18 February 2015}}{{cite news|author1=Perry Stein|title=Meet the woman who left her consulting job to open D.C.'s first cat cafe|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/local/wp/2015/02/06/meet-the-woman-who-left-her-consulting-job-to-open-d-c-s-first-cat-cafe/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=29 March 2015|date=6 February 2015}}{{cite news|author1=Perry Stein|title=Not-yet-open D.C. cat cafe raises serious money in 1 day|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/local/wp/2015/03/09/not-yet-open-d-c-cat-cafe-raises-serious-money-in-1-day/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=29 March 2015|date=9 March 2015}}{{cite news|author1=Maura Judkis|title=So, how would a cafe crawling with adorable kittens pass a D.C. health inspection?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/going-out-guide/wp/2014/11/20/so-how-would-a-cafe-crawling-with-adorable-kittens-pass-a-d-c-health-inspection/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=29 March 2015|date=20 November 2014}} Crumbs and Whiskers subsequently opened its second café in Los Angeles, California in September 2016.{{cite web|author=Megan Moureaux|title=Cats Looking for Furever Homes at LA's First Cat Cafe|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Cats-Looking-Furever-Homes-LA-Cat-Cafe-397474921.html|publisher=NBC Los Angeles|accessdate=1 January 2017|date=18 October 2016}}{{cite web|author=Suzanne Sproul|title=Everything you need to know about LA’s first cat cafe Crumbs & Whiskers|url=http://www.dailynews.com/lifestyle/20160923/everything-you-need-to-know-about-las-first-cat-cafe-crumbs-amp-whiskers|publisher=Los Angeles Daily News|accessdate=1 January 2017|date=23 September 2016}}{{cite web|author=Sarah Le|title=Los Angeles’ First Cat Cafe Is Cat-Lover Heaven|url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2164439-los-angeles-first-cat-cafe-is-cat-lover-heaven/|publisher=Epoch Times|accessdate=1 January 2017|date=30 September 2016}} In September 2015, a second café opened in New York City, called [[Koneko (cat cafe)|Koneko]]. It will be supporting felines from Anjellicle Cats Rescue.{{cite news|author1=Olivia B. Waxman|title=Another Cat Cafe Is Opening in New York City|url=http://time.com/3987579/new-york-city-second-cat-cafe/|publisher=Time|accessdate=12 August 2015|date=8 August 2015}} In October 2015, the Blue Cat Cafe opened in [[Austin, Texas]], partnering with the Austin Humane Society as a cafe and adoption center. It has live music.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytexanonline.com/2015/10/18/ut-alumna-opens-texas%E2%80%99-first-cat-cafe|title=UT alumna opens Texas’ first cat cafe|publisher=|accessdate=7 January 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bluecatcafe.com/?gclid=CIb0yY2Dj8oCFYI_aQodn9EODA|title=Cat For Adoption - Cats To Adopt - Luxury Cat Beds|work=Blue Cat Cafe|accessdate=7 January 2016}} In December 2015, [[Seattle, Washington]], opened its first cat café, called Seattle Meowtropolitan.{{cite web |first=Rachel |last=Belle |title=Seattle Meowtropolitan Cafe is the city's very first cat cafe |url=http://mynorthwest.com/874/2871989/Seattle-Meowtropolitan-Cafe-is-the-citys-very-first-cat-cafe |website=My Northwest.com |publisher=[[KIRO-FM|KIRO radio]] |date=16 December 2015 }} In December 2015, the first cat cafe in [[Dallas, Texas]]—The Charming Cat Cafe—opened in [[Vista Ridge Mall]], showcasing kitties from Kitty Save.{{Cite web|title = Cat Café Helps Connect Felines to Forever Families|url = http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Cat-Cafe-Helps-Connect-Felines-to-Forever-Families-363962501.html|website = NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth|accessdate = 9 February 2016}}{{Cite web|title = Cat café offers hands-on adoption right meow {{!}} North Texas Daily|url = http://ntdaily.com/cat-cafe-offers-hands-on-adoption-right-meow/|website = ntdaily.com|accessdate = 9 February 2016}}{{Cite web|title = Charming Cat Corner opens at Vista Ridge Mall - Local News, Notes and Events - News and Opinion - The Lewisville Texan Journal|url = http://lewisvilletexan.com/xoops/modules/news/article.php?storyid=4087|website = lewisvilletexan.com|accessdate = 10 February 2016|first = The Lewisville Texan|last = Journal}} In March 2016, Cat Cafe Mad opened in Madison, Wisconsin{{cite web|title=Attention cat lovers: "Cat café" set to open on Monroe Street in Madison on March 21st|url=http://fox6now.com/2016/03/14/attention-cat-lovers-cat-cafe-set-to-open-on-monroe-street-in-madison-on-march-21st/|publisher=Fox News: Fox6Now|accessdate=27 April 2016|date=14 March 2016}}, but was set to close the next year{{cite news |title=Cat Cafe Mad set to close in July |url=https://www.channel3000.com/news/cat-cafe-mad-set-to-close-in-july/749611822 |accessdate=1 October 2018 |work=Channel3000 (WISC-TV) |date=5 June 2018}}. In December 2016, Ashley Brooks opened "Pounce Cat Cafe + Wine Bar" in [[Charleston, South Carolina]]. Pounce has partnered with the largest animal shelter in South Carolina, Charleston Animal Society.{{cite web|url=http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/Eat/archives/2015/09/28/yes-charleston-might-get-a-cat-cafe|title=Yes, Charleston might get a cat cafe|work=Charleston City Paper|accessdate=7 January 2016}} In 2017, The Cafe Meow became the first cat café to open in Minnesota.{{Cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-s-first-cat-cafe-could-open-soon-in-uptown/449431493/|title=Minnesota's first 'cat cafe' signs a lease in Uptown Minneapolis|work=Star Tribune|access-date=2018-02-05}} In 2017 The Purrfect Roast became Chicago's first cat café.{{cite news|url= https://chicago.eater.com/2017/7/12/15956342/first-cat-cafe-chicago-treehouse-shelter-purrfect-roast-opening|title=First cat cafe|website=chicago.eater.com}} It has since shut down. In 2018 The Windy Kitty Cat Cafe opened in Chicago.{{cite web|url=https://chicago.eater.com/2017/12/18/16790822/windy-kitty-cat-cafe-open-bucktown-gallery-cafe|title=Chicago Cat Cafe Alert: Bucktown’s Windy Kitty is Open|publisher=}} ===Mexico=== Cat cafés have been established in the capital, [[Mexico City]], and in the State of [[Baja California]]. "Bastet Cafe" opened its doors on 30 August 2015 in [[Tijuana]].{{cite web|first=Elizabeth | last=Rosales|title=Inauguran el primer "Cat Café" de Tijuana|url=http://www.sandiegored.com/noticias/66938/Inauguran-el-primer-Cat-Cafe-de-Tijuana/}} == Oceania == ===New Zealand=== New Zealand's first cat café, The Cat Lounge, opened in November 2015 in [[Auckland]].{{cite web|first=Nicole | last=Lawton|title=What's New Zealand's first cat cafe really like?|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/73986567/whats-new-zealands-first-cat-cafe-really-like.html | date=13 November 2015 | publisher=Stuff.co.nz | accessdate=23 April 2017 }} ===Australia=== The first cat café in Australia opened in 2014 as Cat Cafe Melbourne in the city of Melbourne. ==See also== *[[Petting zoo]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == Further reading == {{Commons category|Cat cafés}} === News stories === * [http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/japan/090406/tokyos-cat-cafes Tokyo's cat cafes], [[Global Post]] * [https://www.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUST34914420071204 Cat cafe soothes Tokyo's busy feline lovers], [[Reuters]] * [http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-Pacific/2008/0425/p20s01-woap.html Tokyo's cat cafes offer serenity in the city], [[Christian Science Monitor]] * [http://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/San-Diego-Cat-Cafe-Could-Be-First-in-Country--253610061.html San Diego Cat Cafe Could be First in Country], [[NBC 7 San Diego]] * [http://player.ooyala.com/iframe.html#ec=swZG5vcjrUXLlupJSUtmerPm5vmOUEIz&pbid=7f13b2020e924f7bb1bc00c770ee5d24&docUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.catcafesd.com%2Fnews%2Fmedia-reports%2F Cat Cafe Opens In San Diego], [[Fox 5 San Diego]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150110054409/http://www.sandiego6.com/news/seen-on-6/San-Diegos-very-own-Cat-Cafe-287810391.html San Diego's Very Own Cat Cafe], [[San Diego 6]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140224004002/http://www.vancouverobserver.com/news/cat-caf%C3%A9-vancouver-fuzzy-face-economic-diversity A cat café in Vancouver: The fuzzy face of economic diversity], [[The Vancouver Observer]] * [http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/cat-cafe-maison-de-moggy-moves-to-grassmarket-1-3785624 Edinburgh Cat Cafe gets new home] * [http://www.grnow.com/the-happy-cat-cafe-a-prrrfect-fit-for-grand-rapids/ Is Happy Cat Cafe a prrrfect fit for Grand Rapids?] * [http://www.grbj.com/articles/82331-is-grand-rapids-purrrfect-for-a-cat-caf Is Grand Rapids purrrfect for a Cat Cafe?] * [http://www.metropolitan.fi/entry/first-cat-cafe-opens-in-helsinki First Cat Cafe opens in Helsinki] * [http://catcafe.online/how-to-open-a-cat-cafe/ How to open a Cat Cafe?] {{Types of coffeehouses}} {{Domestic cat|state=uncollapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cat cafe}} '''China International Technology Transfer Center''' ([[Simplified Chinese]]: 中国国际技术转移中心; [[pinyin]]: ''Zhōngguó guójì jìshù zhuǎnyí zhōngxīn'') (CITTC), is a platform set up by the [[Ministry of Science and Technology of the People's Republic of China]], the Beijing Municipal Commission of Science and Technology and the [[Haidian District]] Government. It is devoted to promote and facilitate global [[technology transfer]] between universities, research centers, science parks, competitive clusters, public organizations, as well as the Chinese industry.
==Functions and mission== China International Technology Transfer Center was established in 2011 by the [[Ministry of Science and Technology of the People's Republic of China]], Beijing Municipal Commission of Science and Technology and [[Haidian District]] Government. Created in China's innovation and technology hub – [[Zhongguancun]], [[Beijing]], CITTC is the only all-China agency that provides comprehensive promotion services in high technology and innovation exchange fields.
CITTC specializes in matchmaking events, training, seminars, conferences, incubation for start-ups, concrete project collaboration and others; it further provides business domiciliation, as well as assists with the facilitation of easy market access and partnering solutions with Chinese entities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bj.xinhuanet.com/bjyw/2014-09/23/c_1112595832.htm#/|title=北京市科委：国际技术转移中心开拓千条国际渠道|work=[[Xinhua]]|accessdate=November 25, 2014}}</ref>
CITTC also offers [[Business-to-business|B2B]] online system, an internet-based interactive connection platform, that allows to browse a database of thousands of Chinese companies that have posted tech requests, and connects automatically to potential Chinese partners. B2B Online System enables companies to establish partnership with target Chinese licensee, buyer, investor, distributor or joint research partner.
CITTC is the main organizer of China (Beijing) International Technology Transfer Convention (China ITTC), China's largest technology transfer forum, matchmaking event and an important international platform for supporting Beijing's “World City” and “City of Innovation” effort that has facilitated the securing of a series of major international technology transfer projects in Beijing. ITTC has played a significant role in moving nationwide international technology transfer forward by attracting governmental agencies, hi-tech enterprises, research institutes and universities from nearly 20 provinces and regions throughout China. In 2014, more than 4,000 representatives from over 40 foreign countries and 20 provinces and cities of China were present at the conventions. Through the previous three events, over 500 cooperation intentions have been reached, and contracts of 60 projects worth over CNY 50 billion have been signed.
==Location== [[File:CITTC Beijing.jpg|thumb|right|CITTC Beijing Headquarters]] CITTC is located in Ding Hao Mansion in Beijing's [[Haidian district]] right in the heart of the innovation center [[Zhongguancun]]. It is surrounded by famous universities and research institutes like the [[Peking University]], [[Tsinghua University]], and the [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]] with direct access to the metro Line 4.
==Structure and organization== On a daily basis, the CITTC is managed by the Beijing Technology Exchange and Promotion Center (BTEC).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctmnet.com.cn/|title=中国技术交易网|accessdate=November 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://baike.baidu.com/view/864606.htm/|title=北京技术交易促进中心|work=百度百科|accessdate=November 24, 2014}}</ref> It consists of several departments including legal, scientific and international relations.
==China International Technology Transfer Convention== CITTC is the main organizer of the China (Beijing) International Technology Transfer Convention (China ITTC),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinaittc.org/language.php?language=en|title=百度百科：北京技术交易促进中心|publisher=China International Technology Transfer Convention Official Website|accessdate=November 24, 2014}}</ref> China's largest technology transfer forum and matchmaking event, which builds an important international platform for supporting Beijing's “World City” and “City of Innovation” effort and has facilitated the landing of a series of major international technology transfer projects in Beijing. ITTC has played a significant role in moving nationwide international technology transfer forward by attracting governmental agencies, hi-tech enterprises, research institutes and universities from nearly 20 provinces and regions throughout China. In 2014, more than 4,000 representatives from over 40 foreign countries and 20 provinces and cities of China were present at the conventions. Through the previous three events, over 500 cooperation intentions have been reached, and contracts of 60 projects worth over CNY 50 billion have been signed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinaworth.net/en/index.php?optionid=155&auto_id=77|title=2014 China (Beijing) International Technology Transfer Conference|date=January 20, 2010|work=China Worth|accessdate=November 24, 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Technology readiness level]] *[[Technology transfer]] *[[Technology Transfer Program]] *[[Comparative Technology Transfer and Society]] *[[National Technology Transfer and Advancement Act]] *[[Association of European Science and Technology Transfer Professionals]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cittc.net/sites/ittncenter/index.html/ CITTC Official Website]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{en icon}} * [http://www.linkedin.com/company/china-international-technology-transfer-center-cittc-/ CITTC LinkedIn profile] {{en icon}} * [http://www.chinaittc.org/ China International Technology Transfer Convention Official Website] {{en icon}}
