Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/174.4.232.131|174.4.232.131]] ([[User talk:174.4.232.131|talk]]): We need a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] to back this up. Reddit comments are unreliable. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{good article}} {{Infobox video game | title = P.T. | image = P.T. cover.jpg | caption = Cover art as published on [[PlayStation Network]] | developer = [[Kojima Productions|7780s Studio]] | publisher = [[Konami]] | director = [[Hideo Kojima]]
[[Guillermo del Toro]] | producer = | designer = | programmer = | artist = | writer = | composer = Ludvig Forssell | series = ''[[Silent Hill]]'' | engine = [[Fox Engine]] | platforms = [[PlayStation 4]] | released = {{Video game release|WW|12 August 2014}} | genre = | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''P.T.''''' (acronym for "playable teaser") is a [[First-person (video games)|first-person]] [[psychological horror]] [[video game]] developed by [[Kojima Productions]], under the pseudonym "7780s Studio", and published by [[Konami]]. The game was directed and designed by [[Hideo Kojima]], in collaboration with film director [[Guillermo Del Toro]]. Released for the [[PlayStation 4]] on 12 August 2014 as a free download on the [[PlayStation Network]], ''P.T.'' served primarily as an interactive [[Teaser campaign|teaser]] for the game ''[[Silent Hills]]'', a cancelled installment in the ''[[Silent Hill]]'' series. After the cancellation, Konami removed ''P.T.'' from the [[PlayStation Store]] and eliminated re-installing the game, a decision that later spawned criticism and fan efforts to allow ''P.T.'' to be re-downloaded.{{cite web|last1=Frank|first1=Allegra|title=You can re-download P.T., and here's how|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/12/16/10296546/pt-hideo-kojima-silent-hills-re-download-ps4|website=Polygon|publisher=[[Vox Media Inc]]|accessdate=24 January 2016}} ''P.T.'' received critical acclaim for its direction, visuals, story complexity, and its supernatural horror tension build, but was both criticized and acclaimed for the puzzles and solutions. ==Gameplay== [[File:P.T.Lisa.png|thumb|Unlike in the ''Silent Hill'' games, the player character has no means of defense against the hostile ghost Lisa (pictured).{{cite web|last1=Ryan|first1=John|title=7 terrifying moments in the Silent Hills playable teaser|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/16/7-terrifying-moments-in-the-silent-hills-playable-teaser|website=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[j2 Global]]|accessdate=20 May 2015|date=16 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140818070722/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/16/7-terrifying-moments-in-the-silent-hills-playable-teaser|archivedate=18 August 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Reynolds|first1=Matthew|title=Is Silent Hills teaser PT the scariest game ever?|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/feature/a591627/is-silent-hills-teaser-pt-the-scariest-game-ever.html#~pdbfxOnkbIH742|website=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation|Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=20 May 2015|date=22 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018114050/http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/feature/a591627/is-silent-hills-teaser-pt-the-scariest-game-ever.html#~phjx16ytBOMU2T|archivedate=18 October 2014}} Her design has drawn comparisons to the ''[[yūrei]]'' and ''[[ubume]]'' in [[Japanese folklore]].{{cite web|last1=Kollar|first1=Philip|title=Silent Hills' future is up in the air, but we're still trying to figure out P.T.|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/4/8/8373759/silent-hills-pt-p-t-kojima-konami-story-analysis-ps4-playstation-4 |website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]] |accessdate=29 May 2015|date=8 April 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702193159/http://www.polygon.com/2015/4/8/8373759/silent-hills-pt-p-t-kojima-konami-story-analysis-ps4-playstation-4|archivedate=2 July 2015}}]] Unlike the [[Virtual camera system#Third-person view|third-person perspective]] in ''Silent Hill'' games, ''P.T.'' uses a [[First-person (video games)|first-person perspective]], which centers on an unknown protagonist, whom the player controls, who awakens in a haunted [[suburban]] house and experiences supernatural occurrences.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-08-12-hideo-kojima-and-guillermo-del-toro-are-making-silent-hills|title=Hideo Kojima and Guillermo del Toro are making Silent Hills|date=13 August 2014|last=Matulef|first=Jeffrey|website=[[Eurogamer]]|publisher=Gamer Network Ltd.|accessdate=29 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814004128/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-08-12-hideo-kojima-and-guillermo-del-toro-are-making-silent-hills|archivedate=14 August 2014}} Available areas to explore in the home consist of an L-shaped corridor with two rooms adjacent to it: a bathroom, and a staircase which leads to the room in which the player starts a loop, or a continuous reincarnation of the corridor. The only actions the player can use are walking and zooming. To progress, the player must investigate frightening events and solve cryptic puzzles. Each time a loop is successfully completed, changes appear in the corridor. Additionally, the player encounters a hostile ghost named Lisa. If she catches the protagonist, the player has a random chance of triggering a startling [[jump scare]] when turning the camera horizontally and is sent back to the beginning of the current loop. After the player solves the final puzzle, a cryptic and unrevealed puzzle that allows the player to escape, a trailer reveals that ''P.T.'' is a "playable teaser" for a new game in the ''Silent Hill'' series, called ''[[Silent Hills]]'', directed by [[Hideo Kojima]] and [[Guillermo del Toro]], with the protagonist portrayed by [[Norman Reedus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/13/hideo-kojima-and-guillermo-del-toro-are-teaming-up-for-a-new-silent-hill|title=Hideo Kojima and Guillermo del Toro Are Teaming Up for a New Silent Hill|last=O'Brien|first=Lucy|website=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[j2 Global]]|accessdate=29 December 2014|date=12 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813091918/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/13/hideo-kojima-and-guillermo-del-toro-are-teaming-up-for-a-new-silent-hill|archivedate=13 August 2014}} ==Plot== ''P.T.'' centers on an unnamed protagonist who awakens in a concrete-lined room and opens a door to a haunted corridor,{{efn|The concept of being trapped in a home had been seen earlier in [[Silent Hill 4: The Room|the fourth installment of the ''Silent Hill'' series]]; its premise is that the protagonist Henry Townshend finds himself imprisoned in his apartment and unable to contact the outside world.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/loss-silent-hills-would-be-biggest-tragedy-kojimakonami-fallout-2/|title=The loss of Silent Hills would be the biggest tragedy of the Kojima/Konami fallout|date=27 April 2015|last=Laverde|first=Jake|website=[[GamesRadar]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]|accessdate=30 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150531102524/http://www.gamesradar.com/loss-silent-hills-would-be-biggest-tragedy-kojimakonami-fallout-2/|archivedate=31 May 2015}} Like ''P.T.'', it featured a first-person perspective when exploring Townshend's apartment.{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2015/04/29/7440210.aspx?PostPageIndex=2|title=Ranking The Entire Silent Hill Series|page=2|last=Turi|first=Tim|date=28 April 2015|website=[[Game Informer]]|publisher=[[GameStop]]|accessdate=30 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702195500/http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2015/04/29/7440210.aspx?PostPageIndex=2|archivedate=2 July 2015}}}} in which he can only walk through a hallway which continuously loops and redecorates itself. The first time he passes, a radio reports on a [[familicide]], which was committed by the father and later mentions two other cases exactly like it. Later on, the protagonist encounters a hostile and unstable female apparition, presumably named Lisa. Upon entering the bathroom and being locked inside, he obtains a flashlight and finds a creature resembling an underdeveloped fetus crying in the sink.{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=Iain|title=P.T./Silent Hills demo walkthrough (Page 2)|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/pt-silent-hills-demo-walkthrough-guide/?page=2|website=[[GamesRadar]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]|accessdate=30 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229035731/http://www.gamesradar.com/pt-silent-hills-demo-walkthrough-guide/?page=2|archivedate=29 December 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=Iain|title=P.T./Silent Hills demo walkthrough (Page 3)|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/pt-silent-hills-demo-walkthrough-guide/?page=3|website=[[GamesRadar]]|publisher=[[Future plc]] |accessdate=30 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101192022/http://www.gamesradar.com/pt-silent-hills-demo-walkthrough-guide/?page=3|archivedate=1 January 2015}} He soon gets out but finds out that the apparition is watching him. While it is possible to avoid the ghost completely, if the protagonist is attacked by the ghost he reawakens in the first room of the game, beginning the loop again. In this room there is a bloody moving [[paper bag]] that speaks to him, telling him of a disturbing experience and stating the same quote seen at the start of the game: "Watch out. The gap in the door... it's a separate reality. The only me is me. Are you sure the only you is you?" The next few loops feature a refrigerator hanging from the ceiling, leaking blood. The muffled sound of a hysterically crying baby can be heard from the refrigerator, which violently shakes and moves. This happens several times, each time being more severe than the last. As it{{Clarify|reason=What is "it"? What transitions?|date=September 2018}} transitions, the radio issues a Swedish message referencing the 1938 radio drama ''[[The War of the Worlds (radio drama)|The War of the Worlds]]''. In the next loop, the lamps turn completely red, the player's vision blurs, the character moves abnormally quickly, and there is a set of disturbing illusions. Eventually, the protagonist listens to a murder being committed in the bathroom through the bathroom peephole. After the audio{{Clarify|reason=Which audio? Has the Swedish audio been playing through these loops as well?|date=September 2018}} ends, the bathroom door opens by itself and the player enters upon the fetus-like creature telling the protagonist that ten months earlier, he lost his job and turned to [[alcoholism]]. His wife then worked as a part-time cashier job to financially support the family, but the manager was sexually attracted to her, implying a motive for the familicide.{{cite video game |title=P.T. (Silent Hills Playable Teaser) |developer=7780s Studio |publisher=[[Konami]] |date=12 August 2014 |platform=[[PlayStation 4]] |scene= |level=The bathroom |quote='''Fetus''': You got fired, so you drowned your sorrows in booze. She had to get a part-time job working a grocery store cash register. Only reason she could earn a wage at all, is the manager liked how she looked in a skirt. You remember, right? Exactly ten months back.}} The corridor then corrects itself and the protagonist eventually hears a voice uttering "204863" repeatedly. The player's perspective distorts, and the game displays a false [[Crash (computing)|crash message]]. When the game is restarted, the protagonist awakens in the beginning room and continues the loop with only the flashlight as a light source. He discovers the torn pieces of a photograph scattered throughout the hall and reassembles it in its frame. After the picture is completed and a set of tasks are done, a telephone rings and the radio's voice says "You've been chosen." The protagonist sees a door unlock and leaves the building. In the subsequent [[cutscene]], the radio's voice remarks about having lived a life of regularity until his father killed him and his family without any creativity; he then voices his intention to return with his "new toys".{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=Iain|title=P.T./Silent Hills demo walkthrough (Page 5)|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/pt-silent-hills-demo-walkthrough-guide/?page=5|website=[[GamesRadar]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]|accessdate=30 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530224805/http://www.gamesradar.com/pt-silent-hills-demo-walkthrough-guide/?page=5|archivedate=30 May 2015}}{{cite video game |title=P.T. (Silent Hills Playable Teaser) |developer=7780s Studio |publisher=[[Konami]] |date=12 August 2014 |platform=[[PlayStation 4]] |scene=The end |level=|quote='''Voice''': ''[amid radio static]'' Dad was such a drag. Every day, he'd eat the same kind of food, dress the same, sit in front of the same kind of games... Yeah, he was just that kind of guy. But then one day, he goes and kills us all! He couldn't even be original about the way he did it. I'm not complaining—I was dying of boredom, anyway. ''[Radio static ends.]'' But guess what? I ''will'' be coming back, and I'm bringing my new toys with me.}} The protagonist steps out into the streets of a deserted city and is revealed to be portrayed by [[Norman Reedus]]. The credits then reveal the nature of the Playable Teaser. ==Development== [[File:Hideo Kojima 20100702 Japan Expo 1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Hideo Kojima]], the designer of ''P.T.'']] [[Kojima Productions]] used their [[game engine]], the [[Fox Engine]], to develop ''P.T.''. Hideo Kojima's intention when creating ''P.T.'' was to scare people in a unique way, as well as to deliver an interactive teaser experience instead of releasing trailers and [[screenshot]]s of ''Silent Hills''. ===Game design=== ''P.T.'' was designed to take players at least a week to complete, and Kojima intended the puzzles to be very enigmatic and difficult. Despite this, a few gamers reportedly finished the game within hours after the release, surprising him.{{cite web|last1=Grant|first1=Christopher|title=Why 'P.T.' is more exciting than 'Silent Hills,' and the future of the video game demo 'P.T.' |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/8/21/6039889/why-pt-is-more-exciting-than-silent-hills-and-the-future-of-the-video-game-demo|website=[[The Verge]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|accessdate=22 May 2015|date=21 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140822100227/http://www.theverge.com/2014/8/21/6039889/why-pt-is-more-exciting-than-silent-hills-and-the-future-of-the-video-game-demo|archivedate=21 August 2014}} Kojima also intended for ''P.T.'' to be a mystery in order to make it a more frightening experience. There is little, if not cryptic, information given in the game on events that take place, and there are few clues as to how to solve the puzzles.{{cite web|last1=Coskrey|first1=Jason|title=Kojima's terrifying world of the unknown|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/life/2014/09/26/digital/kojimas-terrifying-world-unknown/#.VVuhd_lVikr|website=[[The Japan Times]]|publisher=The Japan Times, Ltd|accessdate=19 May 2015|date= 26 September 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150322074611/http://www.japantimes.co.jp/life/2014/09/26/digital/kojimas-terrifying-world-unknown/#.VZWcQvlVikr|archivedate=22 March 2015}} He chose the corridor as the setting as opposed to "a ruin" because he wanted the teaser to emotionally affect the player regardless of "cultural background".{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/hideo-kojima-and-shinji-mikami-talk-horror-games-1641562015 | title=Hideo Kojima and Shinji Mikami Talk Horror Games | website=[[Kotaku]] |publisher=[[Gawker Media]] |accessdate=29 April 2015 | last=Nakamura | first=Toshi|date=2 October 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150507182010/http://kotaku.com/hideo-kojima-and-shinji-mikami-talk-horror-games-1641562015|archivedate=7 May 2015}} Kojima elaborated that ''P.T.'' and ''Silent Hills'' have no canonical and direct relation, and that ''Silent Hills'' would have been enhanced by elements that were never in ''P.T.'' He based his concept of ''P.T.'' on [[horror film]]s and other media that he found frightening. When creating the game, Kojima refrained from using [[graphic violence]] to build up suspense, as he felt that too many [[Horror fiction|horror]] games rely on the trope. He wanted to elicit a more "genuine, thoughtful and permeating" type of fear. ==Release== ''P.T.'' was originally announced at [[Gamescom]] 2014 as a demo for an eponymous mystery horror video game.{{cite web | url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/8/12/5995459/pt-interactive-horror-teaser-playstation-4-demo | title=P.T. is a new interactive horror game for PlayStation 4 and you can try it now (update) | website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |publisher = [[Vox Media]] |accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=McWhertor | first=Michael|date=12 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150604011905/http://www.polygon.com/2014/8/12/5995459/pt-interactive-horror-teaser-playstation-4-demo|archivedate=4 June 2015}}{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/video-game-previews/11038331/Hideo-Kojima-and-Guillermo-del-Toros-Silent-Hills-playing-the-playable-trailer.html | title=Hideo Kojima and Guillermo del Toro's Silent Hills: playing the playable trailer | website=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]] |accessdate=19 May 2015 | last=Hoggins|first=Tom|date=16 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150325215040/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/video-game-previews/11038331/Hideo-Kojima-and-Guillermo-del-Toros-Silent-Hills-playing-the-playable-trailer.html|archivedate=25 March 2015}} It was released on 12 August 2014, on the [[PlayStation Network]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/12/gamescom-2014-pt-announced-for-playstation-demo-available-now|title=Gamescom 2014: P.T. Announced for Playstation 4|date=12 August 2014|website=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[j2 Global]]|accessdate=29 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007112815/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/12/gamescom-2014-pt-announced-for-playstation-demo-available-now|archivedate=7 October 2014}} Instead of formally announcing a new ''Silent Hill'' game, director Hideo Kojima decided to release ''P.T.'' as a game demo from a nonexistent gaming studio called 7780s Studio.{{cite web | url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/8/15/6006477/pt-silent-hills-ps4-guillermo-del-toro-hideo-kojima | title=Guillermo del Toro's 'Silent Hills' teaser is the scariest thing you can play this weekend | website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]]| accessdate=29 April 2015 | last=Miller | first=Ross|date=15 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150529082642/http://www.theverge.com/2014/8/15/6006477/pt-silent-hills-ps4-guillermo-del-toro-hideo-kojima|archivedate=29 May 2015}}{{efn|7780s Studio refers to the area, in [[Square kilometre|square kilometers]], of [[Shizuoka Prefecture]]; a literal translation of the prefecture's name is "Quiet Hills", and in Japan, the ''Silent Hill'' series is often nicknamed "Shizuoka".}} In September 2014, Sony announced during its pre-[[Tokyo Game Show]] press conference that ''P.T.'' had been downloaded over a million times.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/01/playstation-4s-pt-silent-hills-demo-downloaded-1-million-times |title=PlayStation 4's PT Silent Hills Demo Downloaded 1+ Million Times |last=Moriarty |first=Colin |date=1 September 2014 |website=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[j2 Global]]|accessdate=2 September 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629034213/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/01/playstation-4s-pt-silent-hills-demo-downloaded-1-million-times|archivedate=29 June 2015}} ===Critical reception=== {{Quote box | quote = The photorealistic quality of ''P.T.''{{'}}s singular, tormented hallway lulls one into a familiar and emotionally disarming place. We've all been in a hallway like that. We've all wondered if something was around the corner. In ''P.T.'', there is. | source = —Patrick Klepek from ''[[Kotaku]]'' | align = left | width = 30em }} Erik Kain of ''[[Forbes]]'' enjoyed the game for its anxiety-inducing horror, and wrote that it succeeded as marketing for the upcoming ''Silent Hills''.{{cite web|last1=Kain|first1=Erik|title=Hideo Kojima's 'P.T. Demo' For The New 'Silent Hills' Is Terrific And Terrifying|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/erikkain/2014/08/15/hideo-kojimas-p-t-demo-for-the-new-silent-hills-is-terrific-and-terrifying/|website=[[Forbes]]|publisher=Forbes Inc. |accessdate=22 May 2015|date=15 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629075714/http://www.forbes.com/sites/erikkain/2014/08/15/hideo-kojimas-p-t-demo-for-the-new-silent-hills-is-terrific-and-terrifying/|archivedate=29 June 2015}} David Houghton of [[GamesRadar]] praised it for its immersive, well-executed horror and for how the game's difficulty created online discourse: "By spreading out into the real world, by forcing solutions by way of hearsay, internet whispers, and desperate, rumoured logic, it has become its own urban myth."{{cite web | url=http://www.gamesradar.com/why-pt-first-real-horror-game-years-and-best-game-ps4/ | title=P.T. is the first REAL horror game in years, and the smartest game on PS4 | website=[[GamesRadar]] |publisher=[[Future plc]] |accessdate=29 April 2015 | last=Houghton | first=David|date=28 April 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150627174702/http://www.gamesradar.com/why-pt-first-real-horror-game-years-and-best-game-ps4/|archivedate=27 June 2015}} ''[[Eurogamer]]''{{'}}s Jeffrey Matulef wrote that, through its emphasis on "sound effects, visual design, choreography, and difficult to decipher enemy placements" over traditional progress, the game became immersive and terrifying.{{cite web|last1=Matulef|first1=Jeffrey|title=P.T. is more than a teaser - it's a great game in its own right|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-08-15-p-t-is-more-than-a-teaser-its-a-great-game-in-its-own-right-version-2|website=[[Eurogamer]]|publisher=Gamer Network Ltd |accessdate=3 June 2015|date=15 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612201635/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-08-15-p-t-is-more-than-a-teaser-its-a-great-game-in-its-own-right-version-2|archivedate=12 June 2015}} However, the puzzles in ''P.T.'' received criticism. Klepek panned the puzzles, describing them as an "exercise in frustration". Matthew Reynolds of [[Digital Spy]] wrote that the final puzzle was a "source of frustration" which lacked a clear solution. In contrast, Matulaf stated that, while the puzzles ranged in cleverness and difficulty, they added to the horror of the game by being emotionally "uncomfortable". ''P.T.'' was also placed on some "best-of" lists in 2014. [[GameSpot]] awarded it the "Game of the Month" for August 2014.{{cite web | url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/game-of-the-month-august-2014-pt/1100-6422175/ | title=Game of the Month | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|website=[[GameSpot]] | accessdate=18 May 2015|date=August 2014}} [[IGN]]'s Marty Sliva chose ''P.T.'' as an honorable mention on his list of the best video game trailers of the year, describing it as "one of the most interesting, gorgeous, and terrifying" games he played that year.{{cite web | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/12/11/the-14-best-game-trailers-of-2014 | title=The 14 Best Game Trailers of 2014 | website=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[j2 Global]] |accessdate=29 April 2015 | last=Sliva | first=Marty|date=11 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213093137/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/12/11/the-14-best-game-trailers-of-2014|archivedate=11 December 2014}} Another reviewer for IGN, Lucy O'Brien, described the game as "the most genuinely frightening interactive experience in recent years", making it her choice for game of the year.{{cite web | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/12/17/my-game-of-the-year-wasnt-a-game-at-all | title=My Game of the Year Wasn't A Game At All | website=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[j2 Global]]| accessdate=29 April 2015 | last=O'Brien | first=Lucy|date=16 December 2014}} [[Giant Bomb]] gave the Best Horror Game of the year award to ''P.T.'', saying that "''P.T.'' reminded us what happens when unlimited resources are thrown at a horror experience."{{cite web | url=http://www.giantbomb.com/articles/giant-bomb-s-2014-game-of-the-year-awards-day-five/1100-5126/ | title= Giant Bomb's 2014 Game of the Year Awards: Day Five Text Recap| website=[[Giant Bomb]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=29 April 2015|date=30 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128202012/http://www.giantbomb.com/articles/giant-bomb-s-2014-game-of-the-year-awards-day-five/1100-5126/|archivedate=28 January 2015}} ''P.T.'' won "Scariest Game" at ''[[Bloody Disgusting]]''{{'}}s FEAR Awards.{{cite web | url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3324839/fear-awards-best-worst-horror-games-2014/ | title=Your Picks for the Best & Worst Horror Games of 2014! | website=[[Bloody Disgusting]] |publisher=The Collective |accessdate=29 April 2015 | last=Dodd | first=Adam|date=16 January 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629051055/http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3324839/fear-awards-best-worst-horror-games-2014/|archivedate=28 June 2015}} The game also won ''Innovation in Game Technology'' at the 2014 [[National Academy of Video Game Trade Reviewers]] (NAVGTR) awards.{{cite web|title=NAVGTR Awards (2014)|url=http://navgtr.org/archives/2445|website=National Academy of Video Game Trade Reviewers}} ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' ranked it as the tenth best game of the year,{{cite web|last1=Grant|first1=Christopher|title=Polygon's Games of the Year 2014 #10: P.T.|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/12/22/7435249/polygons-games-of-the-year-2014-10-p-t|date=22 December 2014|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]] |accessdate=3 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150416051221/http://www.polygon.com/2014/12/22/7435249/polygons-games-of-the-year-2014-10-p-t|archivedate=16 April 2015}} and ''[[Slant Magazine]]''{{'}}s staff ranked it as the eighth best video game of the year.{{cite web | url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/features/article/the-25-best-video-games-of-2014/P4 | title=The 25 Best Video Games of 2014 | date=8 December 2014 | website=[[Slant Magazine]] | accessdate=6 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417062104/http://www.slantmagazine.com/features/article/the-25-best-video-games-of-2014/P4|archivedate=17 April 2015}} Patrick Klepek of ''[[Kotaku]]'' originally listed the game as number one on a list of the ten best easily available horror games in 13 February, describing it as "the new king of horror." The game was replaced by ''[[Amnesia: The Dark Descent]]'' as number one when ''Silent Hills'' was cancelled and ''P.T.'' removed.{{cite web | url=http://thebests.kotaku.com/the-10-best-horror-games-1685727700 | title=The 10 Best Horror Games |website=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]] | accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=Klepek | first=Patrick|date=13 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526191919/http://thebests.kotaku.com/the-10-best-horror-games-1685727700|archivedate=26 May 2015|deadurl=no}} In 2017, GamesRadar ranked ''P.T.'' the 4th best horror game of all time in a list of 20.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/best-horror-games/|title=The 20 best horror games of all time|author=GamesRadar Staff|date=27 March 2017|website=[[GamesRadar]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]}} ==Themes and analysis== [[File:P.T. Baby.jpg|thumb|left|Danielle Riendeau from ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' compared ''P.T.''{{'}}s fetus in the sink (pictured) to the deformed baby in [[David Lynch]]'s film ''[[Eraserhead]]'' (1977).]] Reviewers have identified several themes in ''P.T.'' According to ''[[Eurogamer]]''{{'}}s Jeffrey Matulef, the game's main theme is "cyclical mental anguish", supported by the obscure and confusing nature of the puzzles. Danielle Riendeau of ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' wrote that ''P.T.'' uses two primary themes from the ''Silent Hill'' series, "a sense of family trauma and domestic violence and the duality of the 'real world' and the nightmare world." She suggested that ''P.T.'' and ''[[Eraserhead]]'' shared thematic content, writing that both included a crying, deformed infant and that the film's protagonist journeyed from reality into a terrifying world.{{cite web|last1=Riendeau|first1=Danielle|title=Silent Hills 'pants soiling' scares won't measure up to P.T.|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/8/18/6033001/silent-hills-pt-horror-films|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]] |accessdate=20 May 2015|date=18 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528220622/http://www.polygon.com/2014/8/18/6033001/silent-hills-pt-horror-films|archivedate=28 May 2015}} ''P.T.''{{'}}s ceaselessly looping hallway has been a source of critical discussion. Rob Crossley of GameSpot wrote that it induced "mild [[claustrophobia]]" and "a familiarity with your surroundings". He remarked that while the length of the first part of the corridor worked to create tension, the design of the second part intentionally prevented the player from being able to keep everything in view, causing the player to feel vulnerable.{{cite web | url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/in-memory-of-the-unbearable-enigma-p-t/1100-6426967/ | title=In Memory of the Unbearable Enigma, P.T. | website=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=Crossley | first=Rob}} David Houghton of GamesRadar described the looping corridor as "the conduit for everything that it builds", along with saying that "it fills that structure with an unbroken feedback loop of 'horror' ... every time you leave is a monumental relief, and every simultaneous instance of returning is a moment of primal foreboding at how things might, and almost certainly will, escalate, compounded by the knowledge of the seemingly countless iterations before." Houghton felt that the game understood how to evoke horror by working "within the realm of [[psychology]]". ''Polygon'' quoted a game player who said that "''P.T.''{{'}}s greatest asset is its looping hallway", elaborating that it not only invokes fear, but also "curiosity, or a desire to know what will happen next".{{cite web|last1=Riendeau|first1=Danielle|title=Why we can't stop talking about P.T.|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/10/3/6904453/p-t-silent-hills-kojima|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|accessdate=21 May 2015|date=3 October 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612214808/http://www.polygon.com/2014/10/3/6904453/p-t-silent-hills-kojima|archivedate=12 June 2015}} Matulef said that the claustrophobic and repetitive environment displayed in the game can hypnotize the player into a sense of vulnerability. The majority of what is said and depicted in the game is open to interpretation, leading fans to develop and discuss theories about the nature of the events that occur in the game.{{cite web|last1=Hernandez|first1=Patricia|title=The Next Silent Hill Already Has Bonkers Fan Theories|url=http://kotaku.com/the-next-silent-hill-already-has-bonkers-fan-theories-1621737836|website=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]] |accessdate=3 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150603150006/http://kotaku.com/the-next-silent-hill-already-has-bonkers-fan-theories-1621737836|archivedate=3 June 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Hernandez|first1=Patricia|title=Wow, People Are Still Coming Up With Wild Silent Hills Theories|url=http://kotaku.com/wow-people-are-still-coming-up-with-wild-silent-hills-1637043267|website=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]|accessdate=2 July 2015|date=19 September 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150603150002/http://kotaku.com/wow-people-are-still-coming-up-with-wild-silent-hills-1637043267|archivedate=3 June 2015}} [[Let's Play (video gaming)|Let's Players]] Voidburger and Bob from the video-game related podcast ''The Grate Debate'' opined that the open-ended nature of the game is one of its greatest aspects. They also said that there may be something in the game that has not been discovered yet. They noted the colored lights as something they still had not figured out, and they felt that the game hinted that the radio may be the main culprit behind the father's killing. The game also contained a Swedish line in the radio describing a radio drama from 1938 being true, which gamers suggested may be a nod to [[Orson Welles]]'s radio adaptation of ''[[The War of the Worlds (radio drama)|The War of the Worlds]]''.{{cite web|last1=McWhertor|first1=Michael|title=P.T.'s secret radio transmissions may point to a returning Silent Hill tradition|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/8/20/6049367/pt-radio-transmissions-translation-silent-hills|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]] |accessdate=2 June 2015|date=20 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150522174054/http://www.polygon.com/2014/8/20/6049367/pt-radio-transmissions-translation-silent-hills|archivedate=22 May 2015}} This possible reference to alien invasions was noted as a continuation of a ''Silent Hill'' tradition of having secret endings that included aliens. Another theory commonly discussed is deciphering the identity of the player character. The fetus talking to the player character about his remembering moments "ten months back" seems to imply that he is the father who killed Lisa and the kids, although Voidburger and Bob believe that the player character may be the protagonist that was to be in ''Silent Hills'', as shown in the trailer following the ending of ''P.T.'' ==Media description== {{Quote box | quote = ''P.T.'' stands on its own. It's a [[novella]] or a [[short story]], not a [[Chapter (books)|chapter]] out of a longer work. It's a form that hasn't really existed in video games before. | source = —Christopher Grant from ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' | align = left | width = 25em }} Journalists have expressed confusion about whether the game should be described as a teaser, video game, or demo. Despite ongoing debate, the game won awards for best trailer while also winning game of the month and best horror game of the year awards. While naming ''P.T.'' as an honorable mention for best trailer, Marty Sliva from [[IGN]] felt that ''P.T.'' was more of an "interactive experimental film/[[puzzle game]]". "[[Technology demonstration|Demo]]" has been one of the more common descriptions, though [[GameSpot]] was reluctant to categorize it as such. Despite it being commonly called a demo of ''Silent Hills'', there is no evidence that it was going to be a part of ''Silent Hills'' aside from the reveal of the trailer and title after the end of the game. Hideo Kojima himself explained that it was not a demo of ''Silent Hills'' and described it as a "teaser" in a [[Twitter|tweet]]. Christopher Grant from ''Polygon'' likened ''P.T.'' to [[Pixar]]'s [[List of Pixar shorts|animated shorts]] shown before its full-length [[List of Pixar films|animated feature film]]s. ==Legacy== Following news of the cancellation of ''Silent Hills'', it was announced that ''P.T.'' would be removed from the [[PlayStation Network]] on 29 April 2015.{{cite web | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/04/26/konami-removing-silent-hills-pt-from-playstation-store | title=Konami Removing Silent Hills P.T. from Playstation Store | website=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[j2 Global]] |accessdate=29 April 2015 | last=Osborn | first=Alex|date=25 April 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427183524/http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/04/26/konami-removing-silent-hills-pt-from-playstation-store|archivedate=27 April 2015}} Originally, it was reported that the demo could be re-downloaded,{{cite web | url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/4/30/8521741/pt-re-download-playstation-store-delisted | title=P.T. delisted from PlayStation Store, but you can re-download it if you already had it | website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] | accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=Sarkar | first=Samit|date=30 April 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519022838/http://www.polygon.com/2015/4/30/8521741/pt-re-download-playstation-store-delisted|archivedate=19 May 2015}} but in May 2015 it was no longer re-downloadable from the [[PlayStation Store]].{{cite web | url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/5/5/8557807/pt-silent-hills-demo-pulled | title=Konami pulls P.T. from PlayStation Store, no longer available for re-download (update) | website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |publisher = [[Vox Media]] |accessdate=18 May 2015 | last1=McWhertor | first1=Michael | last2=Sarkar | first2=Samit|date=5 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519035901/http://www.polygon.com/2015/5/5/8557807/pt-silent-hills-demo-pulled|archivedate=19 May 2015}} Cancellation of the game led to criticism of Konami. Patrick Klepek from ''[[Kotaku]]'' stated "It's fine that Konami doesn't want to make ''Silent Hills''" but that the deletion of ''P.T.'' was wrong since the demo had become part of gaming culture.{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/konami-sucks-1702695162 | title=Konami Sucks | website=[[Kotaku]] | publisher= [[Gawker Media]] | accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=Klepek | first=Patrick|date=6 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518121636/http://kotaku.com/konami-sucks-1702695162|archivedate=18 May 2015}} Nick Robinson of ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' described Konami's removal as the "most irresponsible, cowardly decision possible", but that the subsequent unavailability had also made the demo "one of the coolest, most fascinating games in the history of our medium".{{cite web | url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/5/7/8564283/opinion-konami-pt-removal-just-made-p-t-one-of-the-greatest-games-of-all-time | title=Konami accidentally just made P.T. the coolest game of all time | website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] | publisher=[[Vox Media]] | accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=Robinson | first=Nick|date=7 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519054646/http://www.polygon.com/2015/5/7/8564283/opinion-konami-pt-removal-just-made-p-t-one-of-the-greatest-games-of-all-time|archivedate=19 May 2015}} After the cancellation, [[PlayStation 4]] consoles with P.T. installed were listed on [[eBay]] for over $1000;{{cite web | url=http://www.vg247.com/2015/04/29/ps4-with-silent-hills-demo-p-t-installed-listed-for-1000-on-ebay/ | title=PS4 with Silent Hills demo P.T. installed listed for £1000 on eBay | website=[[VG247]] | accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=Saed | first=Sherif|date=29 April 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519145916/http://www.vg247.com/2015/04/29/ps4-with-silent-hills-demo-p-t-installed-listed-for-1000-on-ebay/|archivedate=19 May 2015}} eBay later pulled the auctions down.{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/ebay-taking-down-auctions-selling-ps4s-with-p-t-1702917689 | title=eBay Taking Down Auctions Selling PS4's with ''P.T.'' | website=[[Kotaku]] | publisher=[[Gawker Media]] | accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=Klepek | first=Patrick|date=7 May 1015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518125023/http://kotaku.com/ebay-taking-down-auctions-selling-ps4s-with-p-t-1702917689|archivedate=18 May 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/playstation-4-pt-silent-hills-ebay/ | title=eBay sellers charging over $1,000 for PlayStation 4 with Silent Hills PT demo installed | website=[[Digital Trends]] | accessdate=18 May 2015 | last=Wouk | first=Kristofer|date=9 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150522015701/http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/playstation-4-pt-silent-hills-ebay/|archivedate=22 May 2015}} The incident has been compared to the mass selling of [[iPhone]]s containing ''[[Flappy Bird]]'' after that game's removal from the [[App Store (iOS)|iOS App Store]]. [[Guillermo del Toro]], the intended future director of ''Silent Hills'', commented on ''P.T.''{{'}}s popularity, speculating that there were people who still have a passion for the ''Silent Hill'' series.{{cite web | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/05/15/guillermo-del-toro-laments-what-silent-hills-couldve-been | title=Guillermo Del Toro Laments What Silent Hills Could've Been | website=[[IGN]] | publisher=[[j2 Global]] | accessdate=19 May 2015 | last=Krupa |first=Daniel|date=15 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150529141818/http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/05/15/guillermo-del-toro-laments-what-silent-hills-couldve-been|archivedate=29 May 2015}} ''P.T.'' has also been alluded to in other video games. The antagonist, Lisa, made a [[Cameo appearance|cameo]] in another video game directed by Kojima, ''[[Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain]]'' (2015).{{cite web|last1=Fahey|first1=Mike|title=P.T.'s Unfriendly Ghost Pops Up In Metal Gear Solid V|url=http://kotaku.com/p-t-s-unfriendly-ghost-pops-up-in-metal-gear-solid-v-1637422072|website=[[Kotaku]]| publisher=[[Gawker Media]] |accessdate=21 May 2015|date=21 September 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702181958/http://kotaku.com/p-t-s-unfriendly-ghost-pops-up-in-metal-gear-solid-v-1637422072|archivedate=2 July 2015}} The radio monologue from the beginning of P.T. can also be found playing on a radio as an easter egg. Additionally, the first-person survival-horror video game ''[[Allison Road (video game)|Allison Road]]'' was heavily inspired by ''P.T.'' ''Allison Road'' is to take place in a haunted [[townhouse]] in the United Kingdom and feature a male protagonist who attempts to unravel the mystery behind his missing family over five nights.{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/7/1/8876559/allison-road-pt-horror|title=P.T.-like horror game Allison Road is creepy, creepy, creepy and we love it|author=Farokhmanesh, Megan|date=1 July 2015|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|accessdate=3 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702151015/http://www.polygon.com/2015/7/1/8876559/allison-road-pt-horror|archivedate=2 July 2015}} In the demo, some wall graffiti directly alludes to ''P.T.'' by repeating a statement made in the game.{{cite web|last1=Hernandez|first1=Patricia|title=Fans Are Making A Spiritual Successor To P.T., And It Looks Terrifying|url=http://kotaku.com/fans-are-making-a-spiritual-successor-to-p-t-and-it-l-1715045419|website=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]] |accessdate=2 July 2015|date=30 June 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701112714/http://kotaku.com/fans-are-making-a-spiritual-successor-to-p-t-and-it-l-1715045419|archivedate=1 July 2015}} ''[[The Park (video game)|The Park]]'', a spin-off game from ''[[The Secret World]]'', has a sequence inspired by ''P.T.'',{{cite web|last1=Whitehead|first1=Dan|title=The Park review|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-10-29-the-park-review|website=[[Eurogamer]]|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=31 October 2015|date=29 October 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Cork|first1=Jeff|title=The Park Review|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/the_park/b/pc/archive/2015/10/28/the-park-review-a-short-and-unnerving-ride.aspx|website=[[Game Informer]]|publisher=[[GameStop]]|accessdate=31 October 2015|date=28 October 2015}} and the horror games ''[[Layers of Fear]]'' and ''[[Visage (video game)|Visage]]'' were heavily inspired by ''P.T.'' as well.{{cite web|title=Layers of Fear: Dev laments Konami's Silent Hills PT cancellation|first=Anthony|last=Chapman|website=''[[Sunday Express]]''|url=http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/gaming/639998/Layers-Of-Fear-PS4-Silent-Hills-PT-Konami-Cancelltion|accessdate=13 March 2016|date=1 February 2016}}{{cite web|last=Guarino |first=Mike |url=http://attackofthefanboy.com/news/new-horror-game-kickstarter-visage-inspired-p-t-silent-hill/ |title=New Horror Game Kickstarter Visage Inspired By P.T. And Silent Hill | AOTF |website=Attackofthefanboy.com |date=2016-02-08 |accessdate=2017-06-23}}{{cite web|last=Priestman |first=Chris |url=http://www.siliconera.com/2016/01/31/horror-game-visage-follows-footsteps-p-t-now-kickstarter/ |title=Horror Game Visage Follows In The Footsteps Of P.T., Now On Kickstarter |website=Siliconera.com |date=2016-01-31 |accessdate=2017-06-23}} In February 2016, the YouTube channel known collectively as "Oddest of the Odd", released a [[short film]] titled "Silent Hills P.T. in real life". The film draws heavily from its source material, as an unseen protagonist explores a two-story hallway loop in the first person camera perspective. The short film was featured by IGN describing it as "incredible" while GameRant's Alexander Pan described the video as being "complete with the demo's much-touted disturbing content and eerie atmosphere."{{cite web|title=Silent Hills’ P.T. Demo Brought to Life in Short Film|first=Alexander|last=Pan|url=http://gamerant.com/silent-hills-pt-short-film-612/|accessdate=3 April 2016|date=1 March 2016}}{{cite web|title=Silent Hills, PT-Inspired Short Film is Incredible|first=Naomi|last=Kyle|url=http://www.ign.com/videos/2016/03/29/silent-hills-pt-inspired-short-film-is-incredible|accessdate=3 April 2016|date=29 March 2016}} ''[[Resident Evil 7: Biohazard]]'' was also compared with ''P.T.'' during its announcement at [[E3 2016]] thanks in part to the Beginning Hour Demo, its first-person perspective, and its photo-realistic graphics. Jordan Amaro, the level designer of ''Silent Hills'' was responsible for the creation of ''Resident Evil 7''{{'}}s design and setting{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/resident-evil-7-goes-back-to-horror-roots-will-be-/1100-6439896/|title=Resident Evil 7 Goes Back to Horror Roots, Will Be Announced at E3 - Analyst|date=17 May 2016|accessdate=30 April 2017|website=gamespot.com}}, although he has denied that his work on ''Resident Evil 7'' was influenced by ''P.T.'', claiming that he "wasn’t part of the core team of ''P.T.''" and that "''Silent Hills'' would have been quite different from ''Resident Evil 7'' anyway"{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/glixel/features/splatoon-2-hideo-kojima-nintendo-japanese-games-w501322/|title=Nintendo Dev On Working With Kojima,'Splatoon 2,' Rise of Japanese Games - Rolling Stone|date=6 September 2017|accessdate=13 November 2017|website=rollingstone.com}} On 4 July 2018, Qimsar, a 17-year-old developer and fan of P.T., remade the playable teaser for the PC and released it for free.Frank, Allegra. [https://www.polygon.com/2018/7/2/17519118/pt-remake-windows-pc-free-download P.T. PC remake is playable, perfectly scary]. [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]. Retrieved on 20 July 2018.Usher, William. [https://www.cinemablend.com/games/2444440/you-can-play-a-fan-remake-of-pt-for-free You Can Play A Fan Remake Of P.T. For Free]. Cinemablend. Retrieved on 20 July 2018 On 13 July 2018, Konami shut down the project due to legal issues.Good, Owen. [https://www.polygon.com/2018/7/13/17570252/pt-on-pc-fan-remake-cease-desist-pulled Fan remake of P.T. on PC gets shut down by Konami]. [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]. Retrieved on 20 July 2018. However, Konami offered Qimsar an internship to work with its development offices.Usher, William. [https://www.cinemablend.com/games/2450779/the-pt-fan-remake-was-just-killed-by-konami The P.T. Fan Remake Was Just Killed By Konami]. Cinemablend. Retrieved on 20 July 2018 ==Notes and references== ===Notes=== {{Notelist}} ===References=== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.konami.jp/pt/certification.php5}} {{portal bar|2010s|Horror|Sony PlayStation|Speculative fiction|Video games}} {{Silent Hill}} {{Hideo Kojima}} {{Guillermo del Toro}} [[Category:2014 video games]] [[Category:Family in fiction]] [[Category:Ghost video games]] [[Category:Konami games]] [[Category:Mass murder in fiction]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4-only games]] [[Category:Psychological horror games]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:Suicide in fiction]] [[Category:Video game controversies]] [[Category:Video game marketing]] [[Category:Video games directed by Hideo Kojima]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]]

revision.comment: There was a question inside the text between mention of sport found in Socrates work. Indeed, Socrates had never written anything, but Plato wrote what Socrates (supposedly) said.
revision.text:
'''Philosophy of sport''' is an area of [[philosophy]] that seeks to conceptually analyze issues of sport as human activity. These issues cover many areas, but fall primarily into five philosophical categories: metaphysics, ethics and moral philosophy, philosophy of law, political philosophy, and aesthetics. The philosophical perspective on sport originated in Ancient Greece, having experienced a revival in the latter part of the 20th century<ref name= "Reid">{{cite book | last1 = Reid | first1 = Heather | title = Introduction to the Philosophy of Sport (Elements of philosophy) | publisher = Rowman & Littlefield Publishers |date=September 2012 | pages =
| isbn = 0742570622 }}</ref> with the work of Paul Weiss and Howard Slusher.<ref> Quinton, Anthony (August 21, 1969) [http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1969/aug/21/locker-room-metaphysics/?pagination=false Locker Room Metaphysics]. nybooks.com</ref><ref name= "Kretchmar">{{cite book | editor1-last = Massengale | editor1-first = John D. | editor2-last = Swanson | editor2-first = Richard A. | title = The History of Exercise and Sport Science | publisher = Human Kinetics Publishers |date=November 1996 | author = Kretchmar, R. Scott | chapter = Chapter Six: Philosophy of Sport | pages = 181 | isbn = 0873225244 }}</ref>
A philosophical perspective on sports incorporates its metaphysical relationships with art and play, ethical issues of virtue and fairness and more broadly sociopolitical.<ref name="Reid" />
==Sport and philosophy in ancient Greece==
Ancient Greece is considered the birthplace of both [[ancient philosophy]] and [[Olympic sport]]. Hellenistic philosophies hung great significance on athletic performance. A leader's athletic prowess, according to the view of the times, reflected their ability to lead.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.cambridgescholars.com/download/sample/59965 |title=Philosophy of Sport|editor1 = Hardman, Alun |editor2=Jones, Carwyn |isbn=1-4438-2516-6|year=2010|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing}}</ref> (Games of the [[Phaeacians]] in [[Homer]]'s ''[[Odyssey]]'') Sport was seen as an [[epistemic]] inquiry, a methodological process by which we learn the objective truth of a person's athletic potential by actualizing it in athletic competition. Athletics as a measure of individual worth was seen as a cure to social inequality. Sport was even seen as moral education, with Plato advocating the participation of women in sport for their moral enrichment. Aristotle emphasized physical activity as an ethical responsibility. Mentions of sport were also found in the work of [[Plato]].<ref name="Reid" />
==Contemporary philosophy of sport==
The resurgence of interest in philosophy of sport was marked by Yale philosopher [[Paul Weiss (philosopher)|Paul Weiss]]' book publication ''Sport: A Philosophical Inquiry (1969)'', considered the first book-length text in philosophy of sport. In it, Weiss explains the dearth of work in philosophy of sport as a reflection of academic elitism. Sport was always considered vulgar or common, according to Weiss.<ref>Shouler, Kenneth (2003) [http://philosophynow.org/issues/41/If_Life_is_Finite_Why_am_I_Watching_this_Damn_Game If Life is Finite, Why am I Watching this Damn Game?] ''Philosophy Now''</ref>
Long before this, however, philosophical considerations of sport and physical and activity were discussed as a subset of educational reform in the late 19th century as the link between physical education and health and well-being gained appreciation among scholars. To many of the time, the health and educational benefits of physical activity were a component of public life. Inadvertently, many non-philosopher proponents of physical education took on philosophical positions on teleology, mind-body dualism and metaphysics as part of their model of human agency and personhood. In a broader context, political philosophy entered the picture as thinkers of the time, in response to pressing social and political issues of the day associated civic duty, responsible citizenship and other political features to sport.<ref name="Kretchmar" /> While much of the focus has been on the work done in the West, philosophers of sport acknowledge the importance of work done in the East, particularly Japan.<ref name="heacademy.ac.uk">[https://web.archive.org/web/20090206052502/http://www.heacademy.ac.uk/assets/hlst/documents/resources/philosophy_ethics_sport.pdf Resource Guide to the Philosophy of Sport and Ethics of Sport]. Hospitality, Leisure, Sport and Tourism Network, October 2008</ref>
Important questions in philosophy of sport are concerned with the social virtues of sport, the aesthetics of sporting performances and display, the epistemology of individual and team strategy and techniques, sporting ethics, the logic of rules in sport, metaphysics of sport as a component of human nature or instinct, etc.<ref name="heacademy.ac.uk"/> However, some writers have composed a philosophy of sport in terms of the body, art and its intersections with generation X sports, such as bouldering, surfing, skateboarding.<ref>{{cite book|author=Sanzaro, Francis |title=The Boulder: A Philosophy for Bouldering|isbn=0954877993}}</ref>
Other areas of intersection with contemporary areas of philosophy include [[philosophy of education]], [[philosophy of law]], [[philosophy of mind]], philosophy of rules, [[philosophy of science]], [[social philosophy]] and [[political philosophy]].
==Issues in philosophy of sport==
===Ethics=== Ethical issues in philosophy of sport predominantly center on athlete behavior in relation to rules of the game, other athletes, spectators, external factors such as socioeconomic issues among supporters and communities, and issues of doping.
Issues of [[doping in sport]] focus on the ethics of medical intervention on athletic performance: what is acceptable versus what is not, and how boundaries can be drawn. Particular attention is given to the question of what factors ought to be taken into consideration when banning certain medical interventions.
These and other issues are usually compared and contrasted through the lenses of three significant moral theories: [[consequentialism]], [[deontology]] and [[virtue ethics]].<ref>McNamee, Mike. [https://web.archive.org/web/20110629055955/http://www.philosophyofsport.org.uk/resources/ethsport.php Ethics and Sport]. philosophyofsport.org.uk</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * [http://www.tandf.co.uk/journals/RSEP Sport, Ethics & Philosophy (Routledge)] * [http://iaps.net/journal/ Journal of the Philosophy of Sport (Routledge)]
==External links== * [http://www.philosophyofsport.org.uk/about.php British Philosophy of Sport Association] * [http://philosophyofsport.eu/ European Association for the Philosophy of Sport] * [http://iaps.net/ International Association for the Philosophy of Sport] * [http://www.webpages.uidaho.edu/center_for_ethics/About%20Us/aboutus.htm University of Idaho Center for Ethics]
{{Philosophy topics}} {{Supporter Culture}}
[[Category:Applied ethics]] [[Category:Philosophy by topic|Sport]] [[Category:Sports culture]] [[Category:Sportsmanship]]
[[de:Sportphilosophie]]

Wakana Okamura | writer = [[Gen Urobuchi]] | music = [[Yugo Kanno]] | studio = [[Production I.G]] | licensee = {{English anime licensee | AUS = [[Madman Entertainment]] | UK = [[Manga Entertainment]] | NA = [[Funimation]] }} | network = [[Fuji TV]] ([[Noitamina]]) | network_en = | first = October 12, 2012 | last = March 22, 2013 | episodes = 22 | episode_list = List of Psycho-Pass episodes }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | title = Inspector Akane Tsunemori | author = Hikaru Miyoshi | publisher = [[Shueisha]] | publisher_en = | demographic = ''[[Shōnen manga|Shōnen]]'' | magazine = [[Jump Square]] | first = November 2, 2012 | last = October 4, 2014 | volumes = 6 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = light novel | title = | author = Makoto Fukami | illustrator = | publisher = [[Mag Garden]] | demographic = ''[[Seinen manga|Seinen]]'' | magazine = | first = February 4, 2013 | last = April 4, 2013 | volumes = 2 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | title = Inspector Shinya Kogami | author = Midori Gotou | illustrator = Natsuo Sai | publisher = Mag Garden | publisher_en ={{English manga publisher|NA=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} | demographic = ''Shōnen'' | magazine = [[Monthly Comic Blade]] | first = June 30, 2014 | last = | volumes = 6 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = tv series | title = Psycho-Pass 2 | director = Naoyoshi Shiotani
