Makoto Fukami {{small|(Case.2-3)}} | music = Yugo Kanno | studio = Production I.G | licensee = | released = January 25, 2019 {{small|(Case.1)}}
February 15, 2019 {{small|(Case.2)}}
March 8, 2019 {{small|(Case.3)}} | runtime = }} {{Infobox animanga/Other | title = Anime film | content = * ''[[Psycho-Pass: The Movie]]'' (2015) }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{nihongo|'''''Psycho-Pass'''''|サイコパス|Saiko Pasu|lead=yes}} is a Japanese [[cyberpunk]] [[anime]] television series produced by [[Production I.G]]. It was co-directed by Naoyoshi Shiotani and [[Katsuyuki Motohiro]] and written by [[Gen Urobuchi]], with character designs by [[Akira Amano]] featuring music by [[Yugo Kanno]]. The original Japanese cast includes [[Kana Hanazawa]] as [[Akane Tsunemori]], [[Tomokazu Seki]] as [[Shinya Kogami]], and [[Takahiro Sakurai]] as [[Shogo Makishima]]. The series was aired on [[Fuji TV]]'s [[Noitamina]] programming block between October 2012 and March 2013. A second season began airing in October 2014, with an [[Psycho-Pass: The Movie|animated film]] released in January 2015. In 2018, it received a new anime, along with a compilation film trilogy from January to March 2019. The story takes place in an authoritarian future [[dystopia]], where omnipresent public sensors continuously scan the mental states of every passing citizen. ''Psycho-Pass'' originated from Production I.G.'s interest in making a successor to [[Mamoru Oshii]]'s achievements. The series was inspired by several live-action films. Chief director Katsuyuki Motohiro aimed to explore psychological themes in society's youth using dystopian storylines. Multiple books and movies influenced ''Psycho-Pass'' with the most notable being the 1982 American [[science fiction film]] ''[[Blade Runner]]''. The series was licensed by [[Funimation]] in North America. A [[manga]] adaptation has been in serialization in [[Shueisha]]'s ''[[Jump Square]]'' magazine and several novels, including an adaptation and prequels to the original story, have been published. An episodic video game adaptation called ''Chimi Chara Psycho-Pass'' was developed by [[Nitroplus]] Staffers in collaboration with Production I.G. New novels and another manga were serialized in 2014. The first anime, ''Psycho-Pass'', has garnered critical acclaim in both Japan and the west with critics praising the characters' roles and interactions set in the dystopia. The animation has also been praised despite issues in latter episodes which required fixing in the DVD volumes of the series. On the other hand, the second series, ''Psycho-Pass 2'', received mixed critical response stemming from its heavy use of gore as well as the new villain. ==Plot== ===Setting=== ''Psycho-Pass'' is set in a futuristic era in Japan where the {{nihongo|Sibyl System|シビュラシステム|Shibyura Shisutemu}}, a powerful network of psychometric scanners, actively measures the minds and mentalities of civilised populations using a "cymatic scan" of the brain. The resulting assessment is called a {{nihongo|Psycho-Pass|サイコパス|Saikopasu}}. When the calculated likelihood of an individual committing a crime, measured by the {{nihongo|Crime Coefficient|犯罪係数|Hanzaikeisū}} index, exceeds an accepted threshold, he or she is pursued, apprehended, and killed if necessary by police forces. Elite officers labelled "Enforcers" are equipped with large handguns called "Dominators"{{mdash}}special weapons that only activate when aimed at suspects with higher-than-acceptable Crime Coefficients. Enforcers are themselves selected for innately high Crime Coefficients, marking them as "latent criminals"; they are overseen by police Inspectors, who have the jurisdiction to shoot them with their Dominators should they pose a danger to the public. ===Story=== {{main article|List of Psycho-Pass characters}} The series starts with [[Shinya Kogami]], an Enforcer under Akane's watch during her first mission. [[Akane Tsunemori]] is a new police Inspector at Unit One of the Public Safety Bureau's Criminal Investigation Division. Akane is ashamed of shooting Kogami under her watch during her first mission when she judges him a threat to an apprehended criminal's life. Kogami thanks her for intervening in what could've been a murder, which influences Akane to stay. She is accompanied by veteran Inspector Nobuchika Ginoza, a strict man who looks down on Enforcers; Tomomi Masaoka, a middle-aged Enforcer who used to be a detective; Shusei Kagari, a carefree young man who was marked as a latent criminal in childhood; and Yayoi Kunizuka, a former musician turned into a latent criminal stemming from a relationship with a terrorist. Over the course of Akane's early investigations, the group uncovers the works of Shogo Makishima, a prolific criminal mastermind. Makishima is a {{nihongo|Criminally Asymptomatic|免罪体質|Menzai Taishitsu}} – he is persistently assessed as having a low crime coefficient by the Sybil System in spite of his actions and plans, thus protecting him from Dominator shots. The Enforcers and Inspectors start hunting Makishima, who aims to destroy the society created by the Sybil System. To do this he causes riots in the city to draw the police away from the Health and Welfare Ministry's Nona Tower facility, where Sibyl is located. Akane and Kogami stop Makishima's forces while Enforcer Shūsei Kagari follows one of Makishima's allies to the tower where Bureau Chief Joshu Kasei kills Makishima's ally and Kagari to keep the true form of Sibyl a secret. Kasei tells Makishima that Sibyl is a hivemind of similarly asymptomatic individuals and wishes him to join the system but Makishima escapes. Realizing the truth behind Makishima's escape, Kogami leaves the group to kill him. Akane is later directly contacted by the Sibyl system, which orders her to capture Makishima alive. She agrees to do this on the condition that they withdraw the execution order for Kogami. Learning that Makishima plans to commit [[bioterrorism]] to weaken Japan's economy and bring the system down, the Criminal Investigation Division searches for both Makishima and Kogami. There, Makishima tries killing Ginoza but Masaoka sacrifices his life to save him. Despite Akane's efforts, Kogami kills Makishima and the former's erstwhile comrades never see him again. In season two, Akane, now leader of a restored Unit One including rookie inspector Mika Shimotsuki, Ginoza, who is demoted to an enforcer, Yayoi and two new enforcers, Sakuya Togane and Sho Hinakawa, face a new threat in the form of Kirito Kamui, another criminal mastermind who, just like Shogo, intends to bring down the Sybil System by exploiting its flaws instead of just wreaking havoc. Skilled in avoiding all forms of detection and capable of helping his supporters to keep their Crime Coefficients low, only a very few believe that he actually exists, including Akane. ==Production== The series was directed by Naoyoshi Shiotani, written by Gen Urobuchi and features character designs by [[Reborn!]] manga artist [[Akira Amano]]. It stars [[Tomokazu Seki]] as Shinya Kogami, [[Kana Hanazawa]] as Akane Tsunemori, and [[Takahiro Sakurai]] as Shogo Makishima.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-03-30/psycho-pass-anime-series-coming-to-noitamina-in-october|title=Psycho-pass Anime Series Coming to Noitamina in October|date=March 30, 2012|accessdate=April 1, 2012|publisher=Anime News Network|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331063730/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-03-30/psycho-pass-anime-series-coming-to-noitamina-in-october|archivedate=March 31, 2012|df=}} ''Psycho-Pass'' originated from Production I.G.'s interest in making a successor to [[Mamoru Oshii]]'s ''[[Ghost in the Shell]]'' and ''[[Patlabor]]''; the company hired Katsuyuki Motohiro{{mdash}}who became the series' chief director{{mdash}}and veteran I.G. animator Naoyoshi Shiotani to supervise direction.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/psycho-pass-season-one/blu-ray-complete-collection-premium-edition|title=Psycho-Pass Season One Blu-Ray - Complete Collection Premium Edition|date=April 29, 2014|accessdate=April 29, 2014|publisher=Anime News Network|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429202849/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/psycho-pass-season-one/blu-ray-complete-collection-premium-edition|archivedate=April 29, 2014|df=}} Motohiro wanted to return to making anime after a long hiatus but he needed a charismatic script writer. Motohiro and his staff were surprised with [[Gen Urobuchi]]'s contribution to the highly acclaimed anime series, ''[[Puella Magi Madoka Magica]]''. Motohiro was fascinated by ''Madoka Magica''; he read other works from Urobuchi, which persuaded him to talk to Urobuchi. In early 2011, Motohiro proposed to Urobuchi that the pair should work together.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2012-10-11/psycho-pass-chief-director/word-moe-is-banned-among-staff|title=Psycho-Pass Chief Director: Word 'Moe' Is Banned Among Staff|date=October 11, 2012|accessdate=February 23, 2013|publisher=Anime News Network|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308100027/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2012-10-11/psycho-pass-chief-director/word-moe-is-banned-among-staff|archivedate=March 8, 2013|df=}} Early in the making of the series, Motohiro told Naoyoshi Shiotani not to make anything that could not be adapted into a live-action film.{{cite web |url=http://j-entonline.com/interviews-and-articles/media-qa-psycho-pass/|title=Media Q&A with Executive Director Katsuyuki Motohiro, Director Naoyoshi Shiotani and Producer Joji Wada (of "PSYCHO-PASS") by Dennis A. Amith and Michelle Tymon (J!-ENT Interviews and Articles)|date=May 7, 2013|accessdate=December 30, 2013|publisher=J!-Entoline|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627135814/http://j-entonline.com/interviews-and-articles/media-qa-psycho-pass/|archivedate=June 27, 2013}} Before work on ''Psycho-Pass'' started, Shiotani was busy working on the film ''[[Blood-C: The Last Dark]]''. As soon as his work with the film ended, Shiotani focused on the series' quality. After episode 16, which proved to be the most challenging and popular of the series, the team found themselves "out of stamina". The next two episodes were made by an outside team, which is reflected in several problems with the animation. In response to this, the producer of the episode said that while he expected problems, he worked to make it the best he could. Shiotani also apologized for the episode's quality.{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2013/02/21/urobuchi-supports-psycho-pass-director-on-twitter-spoiler-alert|title=Urobuchi Supports "PSYCHO-PASS" Director On Twitter SPOILER ALERT|publisher=Crunchyroll|accessdate=February 21, 2013|date=October 5, 2012|author=Green, Scott|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225075049/http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2013/02/21/urobuchi-supports-psycho-pass-director-on-twitter-spoiler-alert|archivedate=February 25, 2013|df=}} The original team continued working from episode 19 on until the finale; they decided to remake episodes 17 and 18 for their retail release. The series was first announced in late March 2012 by Fuji TV at its Noitamina press conference.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-03-30/psycho-pass-anime-series-coming-to-noitamina-in-october|title=Psycho-pass Anime Series Coming to Noitamina in October|publisher=Anime News Network|date=March 30, 2012|accessdate=August 22, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140921072121/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-03-30/psycho-pass-anime-series-coming-to-noitamina-in-october|archivedate=September 21, 2014|df=}} In March 2013, Shiotani stated there could be a second season if the show received enough support.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-03-30/funimation-confirms-psycho-pass-home-video-release|title=Funimation Confirms Psycho Pass home video release|publisher=Anime News Network|date=March 30, 2013|accessdate=January 7, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101222601/https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-03-30/funimation-confirms-psycho-pass-home-video-release|archivedate=January 1, 2014|df=}} Once development of the second season started, Shiotani said the new episodes are more difficult to make than those in the first season. He said, "it's more about the show's inflexibility" because the staff have to maintain consistency. For the second season [[Tow Ubukata]] replaced Urobuchi as main writer.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-06-23/psycho-pass-2-scripts-overseen-by-fafner-tow-ubukata/.75843|title=Psycho-Pass 2's Scripts Overseen by Fafner's Tow Ubukata|publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=June 23, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140624144257/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-06-23/psycho-pass-2-scripts-overseen-by-fafner-tow-ubukata/.75843|archivedate=June 24, 2014|df=}} Ubukata mentions he was given the idea of expanding the setting in the form of a sequel. As a result of being given the scenario of the TV series and the film, Ubukata had to write the characters' personalities. Although time of the production was short, he had the time to discuss with the first series' staff. Shiotani aided the team for the final episode which Ubukata was satisfied with.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interview/2015-05-20/tow-ubukata/.87808|title=Interview: Tow Ubukata|author1=Chapman, Hope|author2=Nelkin Sarah|date=May 20, 2015|publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=April 21, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150521013206/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interview/2015-05-20/tow-ubukata/.87808|archivedate=May 21, 2015|df=}} ===Design=== [[File:PsychoPassKogamisketch.jpg|thumb|right|Sketches of Shinya Kogami by Akira Amano. The staff avoided using colors that would stand out.]] When hearing the comments from [[Atsuko Ishizuka]], director of ''[[The Pet Girl of Sakurasou]]'', about the way the characters were designed first, Shiotani realized it was the opposite for his team, who had to create the setting first and then the characters because they "are almost being played by the world". As a result, the characters were designed by [[manga artist]] [[Akira Amano]] to balance them with the dark atmosphere by having them "palatable and very relate-able". The staff avoided using bright colors that would stand out. Akane Tsunemori was created as the most relatable character, who would question the setting from the audience's point of view and as the heroine who would come between the main character, Shinya Kogami, and his main rival, and enemy, Shogo Makishima. Akane's progression from an innocent newcomer to a mature and haunted person was one of the staff's main objectives. Motohiro allowed his team to use very graphic elements, even though they could reduce female viewership. He acknowledges that the series may be too violent for a younger demographic and said that he would not want his son to watch it because of its psychological brutality. He added that the team did not want to make a violent series but an "artistic series that just happened to have some violence included in it". About the amount of violence, Shiotani told Urobuchi, "just let us deal with it". Some of these violent scenes occur off-camera, but whenever a protagonist was involved the moment was developed to be memorable. The team twice had to remake scenes because the television station complained that they went "overboard." Motohiro wanted the series to counter concurrent anime trends. The use of ''[[Moe (slang)|moe]]'' (slang) was banned at staff meetings because they appreciated dramas like ''[[Mobile Suit Gundam]]'' and ''Patlabor'' that focus on conflicts between male characters. As the series was "anti-moe", the team decided to avoid having the female lead character Akane remove her clothes and instead had Kogami do it. Nevertheless, the show attracted a female viewership because the conflict between the male characters appeared to attract the ''[[shonen ai]]'' genre fans. Although Shiotani also wanted the series to avoid romance between male characters, he believed the fight scenes between male characters unintentionally attracted female fans. The staff decided to focus on friendships rather than romantic relationships. ===Influences=== The series was inspired by several Western films, most notably ''[[L.A. Confidential (film)|L.A. Confidential]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interview/2013-07-23/interview-george-wada-producer-of-attack-on-titan|title=Interview: George Wada, Producer of Attack on Titan|date=July 23, 2013|accessdate=July 23, 2013|publisher=Anime News Network|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725042102/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interview/2013-07-23/interview-george-wada-producer-of-attack-on-titan|archivedate=July 25, 2013|df=}} Director Naoyoshi Shiotani cited several other influences, including ''[[Minority Report (film)|Minority Report]]'', ''[[Gattaca]]'', ''[[Brazil (1985 film)|Brazil]]'' and ''[[Blade Runner]]''; the latter of which he compared very closely to ''Psycho-Pass''.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/convention/2013/sakura-con/5|title=Directors's Panel with Katsuyuki Motohiro, Naoyoshi Shiotani, and Atsuko Ishizuka|date=March 30, 2013|accessdate=December 30, 2013|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231145932/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/convention/2013/sakura-con/5|archivedate=December 31, 2013|df=}} Before the making of the series, Urobuchi insisted on using a [[Philip K. Dick]]-inspired, dystopian narrative. The psychological themes were based on the time Shiotani watched ''[[Lupin III]]'' during his childhood because he thought about adding "today's youth trauma" to the series. The rivalry between the main characters was based on the several dramas the staff liked. Other voice actors have been credited in the making of the series because of the ways they added traits to the characters. ===Music=== The staff had problems composing an opening theme for the series until someone provided some music by [[Ling Tosite Sigure]], who was engaged to compose the opening theme. [[Egoist (band)|Egoist]], who composed the ending theme, had debuted on Noitamina with ''[[Guilty Crown]]''. Shiotani said they asked Egoist to record three versions of the ending theme so they could alternate them to match the episode's ending.{{cite web|url=http://otakuusamagazine.com/Anime/News1/Noitamina-Interviews-PsychoPass-Director-5650.aspx |title=Noitamina Interviews Psycho-Pass Director |publisher=Otaku USA |date=May 8, 2014 |accessdate=May 9, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PRvypoid?url=http://otakuusamagazine.com/Anime/News1/Noitamina-Interviews-PsychoPass-Director-5650.aspx |archivedate=May 9, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Across the series, time limits resulted in the ending songs being removed or replaced with instrumental versions to avoid cutting scenes from the episode. When there were concerns from the producers of the songs, Tomohiro and Shiotani discussed this with them. Two ''Psycho-Pass'' CDs were included in the second and fifth Japanese home media release of the series.{{cite web|url=http://psycho-pass.com/bd-dvd/#v2|title=Blu-ray & DVD Series Volume 2|work=Psycho Pass|language=Japanese|accessdate=January 8, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115074642/http://psycho-pass.com/bd-dvd/#v2|archivedate=January 15, 2013|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://psycho-pass.com/bd-dvd/#v5|title=Blu-ray & DVD Series Volume 5|work=Psycho Pass|language=Japanese|accessdate=January 8, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115074642/http://psycho-pass.com/bd-dvd/#v5|archivedate=January 15, 2013|df=}} The ''Psycho Pass'' original soundtrack was released by Sony Music Entertainment on May 29, 2013. It features fifty-five tracks composed by [[Yugo Kanno]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/detailview.html?KEY=SRCL-8291|title="PSYCHO-PASS" Complete Original Soundtrack|publisher=CDJapan|accessdate=December 29, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230233743/http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/detailview.html?KEY=SRCL-8291|archivedate=December 30, 2013|df=}} The second original soundtrack was released on March 18, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/product/SRCL-8753|title=PSYCHO-PASS Complete Original Soundtrack 2 3CD+Blu-ray/Limited Edition|publisher=CDJapan|accessdate=March 31, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402104845/http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/product/SRCL-8753|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=}} A two-volume drama CD called {{nihongo|''Namae no nai kaibutsu''|名前のない怪物||lit. "''The Monster with no Name''"}} based on the prequel novel was released between September 25 and November 27, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/detailview.html?KEY=TBZD-156|title=Drama CD "PSYCHO-PASS (Anime)" Zero Namae no Nai Kaibutsu First Part|publisher=CDJapan|accessdate=December 29, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234816/http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/detailview.html?KEY=TBZD-156|archivedate=December 30, 2013|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/detailview.html?KEY=TBZD-175|title=Drama CD "PSYCHO-PASS (Anime)" Zero Namae no Nai Kaibutsu Last Part Regular Edition|publisher=CDJapan|accessdate=December 29, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235059/http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/detailview.html?KEY=TBZD-175|archivedate=December 30, 2013|df=}} ==Themes== As some critics have noted, ''Psycho-Pass'' explores societal and psychological themes, such as the price of living without stress, and without fear of crime. Indeed, the Sibyl System targets individuals who are considering performing actions that might cause stress to others. But this raises the question of whether it is morally and socially acceptable to charge individuals with crimes they have not yet committed. For example, in the first episode, a woman is kidnapped, and the resultant trauma causes her Psycho-Pass to become clouded. According to Sibyl's instructions, the police are therefore prepared to kill her. But Akane steps in, refusing to accept Sibyl's verdict, and manages to bring the woman's Psycho-Pass level back to the acceptable range by speaking gently to her. Consequently, this challenges the notion that the potential to commit a crime necessarily correlates with actually committing the crime. According to Anime News Network, "We are all capable of doing bad things at times{{mdash}}should we be punished because we thought of hurting someone before we act on it? Or because we were victims? It really all comes back to that first episode and Akane's reaction to the victim who presented as a violent criminal".{{cite web|publisher=Anime News Network|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/psycho-pass/episodes-1|title=Review: Psycho-Pass Episodes 1 - 11 Streaming|date=|accessdate=April 3, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130328220114/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/psycho-pass/episodes-1|archivedate=March 28, 2013|df=}} ''Psycho-Pass'' further suggests that the price of living without stress includes overriding the individual's needs in favor of general social value. It is morally and socially acceptable to kill individuals who may potentially commit crimes, so long as we accept that the harm that a criminal causes to society outweighs the harm we cause to an individual who is falsely charged. In other words, the Sibyl System operates on the principles of opportunity cost and acceptable risk. But relying on the Sibyl System paradoxically creates a society which fears no crime as a whole, but individuals who personally fear the consequences of the Sibyl System's verdicts. As such, Urobuchi himself has said that one of the series' central thematic ideas is "fear" as seen through Shogo Makishima's feeling of being out of place - because the Sibyl System cannot recognize him for what he actually is, he feels displaced and deviant within the structure of society itself.{{cite web|publisher=Anime News Network|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interview/2014-09-17/gen-urobuchi/.78542|title=Interview: Gen Urobuchi|date=September 17, 2014|accessdate=September 17, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140917164359/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interview/2014-09-17/gen-urobuchi/.78542|archivedate=September 17, 2014|df=}} Emotional repression is also explored in ''Psycho-Pass''. The identification of latent criminals is partially based around the avoidance of emotions that society judges to be negative, such as sadness or anger. To avoid being identified as a latent criminal, one must not feel these emotions heavily outside, where their Psycho-Pass can be scanned. Kotaku states, "because of these scans, Psycho-Pass shows an interesting future where 'mental beauty' is as sought after as physical beauty. It is also a future where the police's job is little more than to watch the latent criminals they control—because if they did any real detective work, they might start to think like the criminals they are trying to catch and thus become latent criminals themselves." Many of the main characters feel nostalgia throughout the series. The many references to older literature, philosophy, music and theatre create a "nostalgic world building for a time before psycho-passes". ==Release== {{see also|List of Psycho-Pass episodes|List of Psycho-Pass 2 episodes}} The anime series produced by Production I.G. was broadcast in Japan on [[Fuji TV]]'s [[Noitamina]] programming block between October 12, 2012 and March 22, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.production-ig.co.jp/works/psycho-pass/episodes/01.html#onair_schedule|script-title=ja:第1話「犯罪係数」|publisher=Production I.G|language=Japanese|accessdate=January 7, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PdtqJ49n?url=http://www.production-ig.co.jp/works/psycho-pass/episodes/01.html#onair_schedule|archivedate=May 17, 2014|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.production-ig.co.jp/works/psycho-pass/episodes/22.html#onair_schedule|script-title=ja:第22話「完璧な世界」|publisher=Production I.G|language=Japanese|accessdate=January 7, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Pdw1Ic7M?url=http://www.production-ig.co.jp/works/psycho-pass/episodes/22.html#onair_schedule|archivedate=May 17, 2014|df=}} [[Toho]] started releasing the series on DVD and Blu-ray formats on December 21, 2012. The eighth and final volume was released on July 26, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://psycho-pass.com/bd-dvd/#v1|title=Blu-ray & DVD|work=TVアニメ「PSYCHO-PASS サイコパス」|language=Japanese|publisher=Psycho-Pass|accessdate=February 24, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221195646/http://psycho-pass.com//bd-dvd/#v1|archivedate=February 21, 2013|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://psycho-pass.com/bd-dvd/#v8|title=Blu-ray & DVD|work=TVアニメ「PSYCHO-PASS サイコパス」|language=Japanese|publisher=Psycho-Pass|accessdate=December 29, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230233902/http://psycho-pass.com/bd-dvd/#v8|archivedate=December 30, 2013|df=}} [[Funimation]] has licensed the series in North America and simulcast it on its website, first in Japanese, and later weekly in English. Psycho-Pass was one of three initial shows aired as a Funimation "broadcast dub."{{cite web|url=http://www.funimation.com/blog/2014/10/29/introducing-funimation-broadcast-dubs/|title=Introducing FUNimation Broadcast Dubs|accessdate=January 25, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207151945/http://www.funimation.com/blog/2014/10/29/introducing-funimation-broadcast-dubs/|archivedate=February 7, 2015|df=}} A home media release was planned for March 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-10-09/funimation-streams-code-breaker-kamisama-kiss-jormungand-psycho-pass-robotics-notes-oniai|title=Funimation Streams Code:Breaker, Kamisama Kiss, Jormungand, Psycho-Pass, Robotics;Notes, Oniai|date=October 9, 2012|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011222910/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-10-09/funimation-streams-code-breaker-kamisama-kiss-jormungand-psycho-pass-robotics-notes-oniai|archivedate=October 11, 2012|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://shop.funimation.com/Shop/ShopProductDetail.ss?itemid=83858|title=PSYCHO-PASS Season One - Premium Edition|publisher=Funimation Entertainment|accessdate=January 8, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140321040824/http://shop.funimation.com/Shop/ShopProductDetail.ss?itemid=83858|archivedate=March 21, 2014|df=}} In the United Kingdom, the series is licensed by [[Manga Entertainment]] and in Australia by [[Madman Entertainment]].{{cite press release|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2013-07-30/madman-acquires-attack-on-titan|title=Madman Acquires Attack On Titan|date=July 30, 2012|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151201015353/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2013-07-30/madman-acquires-attack-on-titan|archivedate=December 1, 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-10-29/manga-uk-licenses-live-action-hentai-kamen-film|title=Manga UK Licenses Live-Action Hentai Kamen Film|date=October 29, 2013|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=December 30, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231131330/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-10-29/manga-uk-licenses-live-action-hentai-kamen-film|archivedate=December 31, 2013|df=}} On July 6, 2013, Production I.G. president Mitsuhisa Ishikawa said at [[Anime Expo]] that production on a second season had begun.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-07-06/i.g-head/2nd-psycho-pass-season-is-underway |title=I.G Head: 2nd Psycho-Pass Anime Season Is Underway |publisher=Anime News Network |date=July 6, 2013 |accessdate=July 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708074653/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-07-06/i.g-head/2nd-psycho-pass-season-is-underway |archivedate=July 8, 2013 |df= }} The second season, titled ''Psycho-Pass 2'', began airing in October 2014; the film was released in January 2015. Before the debut broadcast of the second season, the first season{{mdash}}condensed into 11 one-hour episodes{{mdash}} began airing in July 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-03-21/psycho-pass-02-to-debut-october-followed-by-winter-film |publisher=Anime News Network |date=March 21, 2014 |accessdate=March 21, 2014 |title=Psycho-Pass 2 to Debut in October, Followed by Winter Film |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322050705/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-03-21/psycho-pass-02-to-debut-october-followed-by-winter-film |archivedate=March 22, 2014 |df= }} The fourth episode was cancelled due to similarities with a real life murder.{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/anime-episode-resembles-real-life-murder-wont-be-broad-1613841546 |publisher=Kotaku |date=July 31, 2014 |accessdate=July 31, 2014 |title=Anime Episode Resembles Real-Life Murder, Won't Be Broadcasted |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140731223503/http://kotaku.com/anime-episode-resembles-real-life-murder-wont-be-broad-1613841546 |archivedate=July 31, 2014 |df= }} Director Naoyoshi Shiotani apologized for this in his Twitter account. Nevertheless, Funimation streamed the episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-07-31/funimation-streams-cancelled-psycho-pass-episode/.77175|title=Funimation Streams Cancelled Psycho-Pass Episode|publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=July 31, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140802010853/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-07-31/funimation-streams-cancelled-psycho-pass-episode/.77175|archivedate=August 2, 2014|df=}} A Blu-ray box set was announced with a scheduled release on October 15, 2014. This set contains both the original first season broadcast and the edited one-hour rerun episodes.{{cite web|url=http://www.fandompost.com/2014/07/07/noitamina-highlights-psycho-pass-blu-ray-box-set-first-anime-feature/|publisher=The Fandom Post|accessdate=July 8, 2014|title=noitaminA Highlights ‘Psycho-Pass’ Blu-ray Box Set, First Anime Feature|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924025125/http://www.fandompost.com/2014/07/07/noitamina-highlights-psycho-pass-blu-ray-box-set-first-anime-feature/|archivedate=September 24, 2015|df=}} The second series aired on Fuji TV's Noitamina programming block between October 10, 2014 and December 19, 2014.{{cite web |url=https://mediaarts-db.bunka.go.jp/an/anime_series/18967 |title=PSYCHO-PASS 2 |language=Japanese |website=Media Arts Database |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=September 30, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171001031058/https://mediaarts-db.bunka.go.jp/an/anime_series/18967 |archivedate=October 1, 2017 |df= }} The series was collected in a total of five DVD and Blu-ray volumes between December 17, 2014 and April 15, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://anime.webnt.jp/news/view/3565|title=「PSYCHO-PASS 2」BD&DVD第1巻12月17日発売！|publisher=AnimeWebnt|accessdate=October 17, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022092317/http://anime.webnt.jp/news/view/3565|archivedate=October 22, 2014|df=}} ===China ban=== On June 12, 2015, the Chinese Ministry of Culture listed ''Psycho-Pass'' among 38 anime and manga titles banned in [[China]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2015/06/12/china-bans-38-japanese-anime-manga-titles-including-attack-titan |title=China bans 38 anime & manga titles incuding ''Attack on Titan'' |publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service]] |date=2015-06-12 |accessdate=2018-08-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180831174910/https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2015/06/12/china-bans-38-japanese-anime-manga-titles-including-attack-titan# |archive-date=2018-08-31 |dead-url=no |df= }} ==Related media== ===Films=== {{main article|Psycho-Pass: The Movie}} In September 2013, it was announced in the official site of [[Noitamina]] that a second season and a new-original theatrical film project was in development.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-09-06/psycho-pass-anime-gets-new-film-along-with-2nd-season |title=Psycho-Pass Anime Gets New Film Along With 2nd Season |publisher=Anime News Network |date=September 6, 2013 |accessdate=September 8, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130908184645/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-09-06/psycho-pass-anime-gets-new-film-along-with-2nd-season |archivedate=September 8, 2013 |df= }} The film was rated as R15+ due to its strong violence scenes including murder and human body's damage.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/daily-briefs/2014-12-17/psycho-pass-film-given-r15-age-rating/.82267|title=Psycho-Pass Film Given R15+ Age Rating|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]accessdate=January 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170714050720/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/daily-briefs/2014-12-17/psycho-pass-film-given-r15-age-rating/.82267|archivedate=July 14, 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2014/12/17-1/eirin-gives-r15-rating-on-psycho-pass-film|title=Eirin Gives "R15+" Rating on "PSYCHO-PASS" Film|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929183853/http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2014/12/17-1/eirin-gives-r15-rating-on-psycho-pass-film|archivedate=September 29, 2017|df=}} On September 2014, the release date was announced for January 9, 2015, Urobuchi and Makoto Fukami are contributing together as the film's writers.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-09-26/psycho-pass-film-slated-for-january-9-with-gen-urobuchi-makoto-fukami/.79243|title=Psycho-Pass Film Slated for January 9 With Gen Urobuchi, 23, 2017|df=}} A 30-second trailer streamed on [[Nico Nico Douga]] on September 5, 2013, showing Shinya, Akane and Ginoza.{{cite web|url=http://live.nicovideo.jp/gate/lv151221683|title=PSYCHO-PASS サイコパス』プロジェクト重大発表会に潜入捜査！|publisher=[[Nico Nico Douga]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315220215/http://live.nicovideo.jp/gate/lv151221683|archivedate=March 15, 2016|df=}} A 2-minutes trailer, the second promotional video for the film, was released on September 2013, containing footage from the original anime television series.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-09-06/psycho-pass-2nd-season-film-announcement-trailer-streamed|title=Psycho-Pass 2nd Season, Film's Announcement Trailer Streamed|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170720001852/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-09-06/psycho-pass-2nd-season-film-announcement-trailer-streamed|archivedate=July 20, 2017|df=}} On February, 2016, [[Funimation]] released a preview for the Dub version and announced that the film will run over 100 theaters in the United States and Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/02/06-1/video-funimation-previews-psycho-pass-the-movie-dub-and-plans|title=VIDEO: FUNimation Previews "Psycho-Pass - The Movie" Dub And Plans|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170715023751/http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/02/06-1/video-funimation-previews-psycho-pass-the-movie-dub-and-plans|archivedate=July 15, 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-02-05/funimation-announces-psycho-pass-film-theatrical-dates/.98390|title=Funimation Announces Psycho-Pass Film's Theatrical Dates|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170128154636/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-02-05/funimation-announces-psycho-pass-film-theatrical-dates/.98390|archivedate=January 28, 2017|df=}} The theme song was performed by [[Ling Tosite Sigure]].{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-11-23/ling-tosite-sigure-performs-psycho-pass-film-theme-song/.81359|title=Ling Tosite Sigure Performs Psycho-Pass Film's Theme Song|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170117122338/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-11-23/ling-tosite-sigure-performs-psycho-pass-film-theme-song/.81359|archivedate=January 17, 2017|df=}} In March 2018, it was announced in the livestream of [[Fuji TV]] that a three-part theatrical film project is in development, titled ''Psycho-Pass: Sinners of the System''. The first film, titled {{nihongo|''Case.1 Tsumi to Bachi''|Case.1 罪と罰}}, will premiere in January 25, 2019. The second film, titled {{nihongo|''Case.2 First Guardian''}}, will premiere in February 15, 2019. The third film, titled {{nihongo|''Case.3 Onshū no Kanata ni ____''}}, will premiere in March 8, 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-10-27/psycho-pass-ss-anime-film-trilogy-unveils-opening-dates-visuals/.138722|title=Psycho-Pass SS Anime Film Trilogy Unveils Opening Dates, Visuals|date=October 27, 2018|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=October 27, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181027171923/https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-10-27/psycho-pass-ss-anime-film-trilogy-unveils-opening-dates-visuals/.138722#|archive-date=2018-10-27|dead-url=no|df=}} Naoyoshi Shiotani and Yugo Kanno are reprising their roles as the director and music composer, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201805120009.html|title=ANIME NEWS: ‘Psycho-Pass’ film trilogy to hit the big screen from early 2019|publisher=[[Asahi Shimbun]]|accessdate=June 27, 2018|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180512033730/http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201805120009.html|archivedate=May 12, 2018|df= }} Ryō Yoshigami wrote the screenplay for the first film, while Fukami is returning from the anime series to write the screenplays for the second and third films. Production I.G is returning for animation production and [[Toho]] is distributing.{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-10-26/1st-2-psycho-pass-ss-anime-films-reveal-returning-staff-cast/.138651|title=1st 2 Psycho-Pass SS Anime Films Reveal Returning Staff, Cast|date=October 26, 2018|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=October 26, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181026093846/https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-10-26/1st-2-psycho-pass-ss-anime-films-reveal-returning-staff-cast/.138651#|archive-date=2018-10-26|dead-url=no|df=}} A collaboration visual with ''Godzilla: The City Mechanized for the Final Battle'' has also been developed with Akane being the ''Psycho-Pass'' character used.{{cite web|url=https://manga.tokyo/news/godzilla-x-psycho-pass-collaboration-visual-revealed/|title=Godzilla x Psycho Pass Collaboration Visual Revealed|publisher=Manga Tokyo|accessdate=November 8, 2018}} ===Manga=== A [[manga]] adaptation illustrated by Hikaru Miyoshi, titled {{nihongo|''Inspector Akane Tsunemori''|監視官 常守朱|Kanshikan Tsunemori Akane}}, began serialization in [[Shueisha]]'s ''[[Jump Square]]'' magazine from November 2, 2012.{{cite web|title=I.G & Urobuchi's Psycho-Pass Sci-Fi Anime Inspires Manga|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-10-02/i.g-and-urobuchi-psycho-pass-sci-fi-anime-inspires-manga|work=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=February 23, 2012|date=October 2, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004231244/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-10-02/i.g-and-urobuchi-psycho-pass-sci-fi-anime-inspires-manga|archivedate=October 4, 2012|df=}} Its first ''[[tankōbon]]'' volume was released by Shueisha on February 4, 2013.{{cite web|script-title=ja:監視官　常守朱 1|url=http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-870623-8&mode=1|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 24, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224082054/http://books.shueisha.co.jp/CGI/search/syousai_put.cgi?isbn_cd=978-4-08-870623-8&mode=1|archivedate=February 24, 2013|df=}} In November 2013, it was announced that 380,000 copies of the manga were shipped in Japan with three volumes.{{cite web|title=Psycho-Pass Manga About Akane Has 380,000 Copies in Print|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-11-03/psycho-pass-manga-about-akane-has-380000-copies-in-print|work=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=December 30, 2013|date=November 3, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235033/https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-11-03/psycho-pass-manga-about-akane-has-380000-copies-in-print|archivedate=December 30, 2013|df=}} The manga had over 1 million copies in print as of December 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-12-04/psycho-pass-manga-about-akane-ends/.81767|title=Psycho-Pass Manga About Akane Ends|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=December 4, 2014|accessdate=August 8, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171226182230/https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-12-04/psycho-pass-manga-about-akane-ends/.81767|archivedate=December 26, 2017|df=}} Another manga titled {{nihongo|''Psycho-Pass: Inspector Shinya Kogami''|監視官 狡噛 慎也|Kanshikan Kōgami Shinya}} premiered in the August issue of [[Mag Garden]]'s ''[[Monthly Comic Blade]]'' magazine on June 30, 2014. Natsuo Sai is illustrating the series and the story is written by Midori Gotou and Production I.G. The manga is published by [[Dark Horse Comics]] in North America since November 9, 2016.{{cite web|title=Dark Horse Comics to Release Psycho-Pass Prequel Manga About Kogami|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-03-18/dark-horse-comics-to-release-psycho-pass-prequel-manga-about-kogami/.99985|website=Anime News Network|accessdate=19 March 2016|language=English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319015358/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-03-18/dark-horse-comics-to-release-psycho-pass-prequel-manga-about-kogami/.99985|archivedate=19 March 2016|df=}} ===Novels=== A novelization of the series by Makoto Fukami has been published by Mag Garden in two volumes released on February 4 and April 4, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://psycho-pass.com/goods/book_novel1_normal.html|title=PSYCHO-PASS サイコパス (上) 通常版|accessdate=December 31, 2013|language=Japanese|publisher=Psycho Pass|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101131237/http://psycho-pass.com/goods/book_novel1_normal.html|archivedate=January 1, 2014|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://psycho-pass.com/goods/book_novel2_normal.html|title=PSYCHO-PASS サイコパス (下) 通常版|accessdate=December 31, 2013|language=Japanese|publisher=Psycho Pass|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101131233/http://psycho-pass.com/goods/book_novel2_normal.html|archivedate=January 1, 2014|df=}} Shiotani said the novels were more violent than the television series. A prequel titled {{nihongo|''Namae no Nai Kaibutsu''|名前のない怪物||lit. "''The Monster with no Name''"}} was written by Aya Takaba, who worked on the television series. Before the novel was released, it was first published on the "Noitamina Novel" page on Noitamina's official website. The novel was released on February 4, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://animeanime.jp/article/2013/01/13/12667.html|script-title=ja:「標本事件」とは何だったのか？　『サイコパス』スピンオフ小説が、ノイタミナノベル先行掲載決定|date=January 13, 2013|accessdate=December 29, 2013|language=Japanese|publisher=Anime Anime|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20131230190150/http://animeanime.jp/article/2013/01/13/12667.html|archivedate=December 30, 2013|df=}} A new series of novels focusing on four characters by Ryō Yoshigami began publication in the August issue of Hayakawa Publishing's ''S-F Magazine'' on June 25, 2014. After the serialization ends, Hayakawa Bunko JA revised the novels and published them in October 2014. Other stories will focus on Choe Gu-sung, Shusei Kagari, Yayoi Kunizuka and Shion Karanomori. Hayakawa Bunko JA also published the ''Psycho Pass Genesis'' book in December 2014, which revealed the origins of Sybil and Tonomi Masaoka's involvement. ===Video games=== Interactive [[visual novel]]s titled ''Chimi Chara Psycho-Pass'', which feature [[super deformed|chibi]] versions of the series' characters in original stories, were included with Blu-ray Disc volumes of the anime and are playable on any Blu-ray playing device.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-05-21/nitro+/not-involved-in-blu-ray-visual-novels-but-our-staffers-are |title=Nitro+: Not Involved in Blu-ray Visual Novels, But Our Staffers Are - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=July 2, 2013 |accessdate=July 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607043857/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-05-21/nitro+/not-involved-in-blu-ray-visual-novels-but-our-staffers-are |archivedate=June 7, 2013 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2012-10-19/psycho-pass-blu-rays-to-include-mini-adventure-games |title=Psycho-Pass Blu-rays to Include Mini-Adventure Games - Interest |publisher=Anime News Network |date=July 2, 2013 |accessdate=July 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131218132426/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2012-10-19/psycho-pass-blu-rays-to-include-mini-adventure-games |archivedate=December 18, 2013 |df= }} In May 2014, it was announced by Anime News Network that a video game based on the series, named ''[[Psycho-Pass: Mandatory Happiness]]'', was being developed by [[5pb.]] for the [[Xbox One]]; with a [[PlayStation Vita]] and [[PlayStation 4]] port announced in December 2015.Sal Romano. [http://gematsu.com/2015/12/psycho-pass-mandatory-happiness-coming-ps4-ps-vita Psycho-Pass: Mandatory Happiness coming to PS4, PS Vita] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151216154747/http://gematsu.com/2015/12/psycho-pass-mandatory-happiness-coming-ps4-ps-vita |date=2015-12-16 }}, gematsu.com, December 16, 2015. The game features an original story written by Urobuchi, which takes place during the time period of the anime's first six episodes and focuses on a new set of protagonists confronting a new enemy on a remote island.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-05-27/psycho-pass-anime-gets-xbox-one-game-by-5pb/.74937|title=Psycho-Pass Anime Gets Xbox One Game by 5pb.|publisher=Anime News Network|date=May 27, 2014|accessdate=May 27, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527223250/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-05-27/psycho-pass-anime-gets-xbox-one-game-by-5pb/.74937|archivedate=May 27, 2014|df=}}[[Nippon Ichi Software|NIS America]] has localized Psycho-Pass: Mandatory Happiness for the PlayStation 4, Vita and an exclusive PC version via Steam. It was released on September 13, 2016 in North America, and on September 16, 2016 in Europe. The [[Xbox One]] version of the game will not be localized.{{cite web|url=http://gematsu.com/2016/02/psycho-pass-mandatory-happiness-coming-west-ps4-ps-vita-pc-this-fall|title=Psycho-Pass: Mandatory Happiness coming west for PS4, PS Vita, and PC this fall|work=Gematsu|date=February 22, 2016|accessdate=August 9, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809110638/http://gematsu.com/2016/02/psycho-pass-mandatory-happiness-coming-west-ps4-ps-vita-pc-this-fall|archivedate=August 9, 2017|df=}} ==Reception== [[Fuji TV]] producer Akitoshi Mori said ''Psycho-Pass'' was the first work under his control. Early screenings of the series at the Noitamina Shop & Café attracted few viewers, which bothered Mori. However, as the series continued, the quantity of viewers increased. By the final episode, over 1,000 people had queued to watch the finale even though the venue could only accommodate seventy people. This made Mori happy because he realized how many fans were following and supporting the show; he wanted to see a bigger audience at future screenings. DVDs and Blu-ray discs of the series achieved good sales.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-06-25/japan-animation-dvd-ranking-june-17-23 |publisher=Anime News Network |date=June 25, 2013 |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |title=Japan's Animation DVD Ranking, June 17–23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140815104503/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-06-25/japan-animation-dvd-ranking-june-17-23 |archivedate=August 15, 2014 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-06-25/japan-animation-blu-ray-disc-ranking-june-17-23 |publisher=Anime News Network |date=June 25, 2013 |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |title=Japan's Animation Blu-ray Disc Ranking, June 17–23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140406102929/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-06-25/japan-animation-blu-ray-disc-ranking-june-17-23 |archivedate=April 6, 2014 |df= }} In April 2014, the series was nominated for the [[Seiun Award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2014/04/28-1/gargantia-psycho-pass-and-girls-und-panzer-nominated-for-seiun-sci-fi-award|publisher=Crunchyroll|date=April 28, 2014|accessdate=April 28, 2014|title="Gargantia," "Psycho-Pass" and "Girls und Panzer" Nominated for Seiun Sci-Fi Award|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429044641/http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2014/04/28-1/gargantia-psycho-pass-and-girls-und-panzer-nominated-for-seiun-sci-fi-award|archivedate=April 29, 2014|df=}} In the ''[[Newtype]]'' anime awards from 2013, it was voted as fourth best title of the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-10-13/attack-on-titan-wins-top-prizes-in-newtype-anime-awards|title=Attack on Titan Wins Top Prizes in Newtype Anime Awards|publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=June 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121103813/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-10-13/attack-on-titan-wins-top-prizes-in-newtype-anime-awards|archivedate=November 21, 2015|df=}} Episode 11 of the series was awarded "Best Episode" in the Noitamina 10th anniversary fan vote. Shinya Kogami, Akane Tsunemori and Shogo Makishima also appeared in such polls as winners of their own categories.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2014-03-31/winners-of-noitamina-10th-anniversary-fan-vote-announced|title=Winners of Noitamina 10th Anniversary Fan Vote Announced|publisher=Anime News Network|date=March 31, 2013|accessdate=March 31, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140403094009/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2014-03-31/winners-of-noitamina-10th-anniversary-fan-vote-announced|archivedate=April 3, 2014|df=}} [[Anime News Network]] also listed as the fifth most accessible anime series for people who have not watched Japanese animation.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/the-list/2014-08-23/.77834|title=7 "Gateway" Anime Sure to Get Newbies Hooked|publisher=Anime News Network|date=August 23, 2014|author=Lamb, Lynzee|accessdate=August 23, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140825050401/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/the-list/2014-08-23/.77834|archivedate=August 25, 2014|df=}} The first season has garnered critical acclaim.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/love-psycho-pass-the-anime-you-ll-love-psycho-pass-the-1778354245|title=Love Psycho-Pass the Anime? You’ll Love Psycho-Pass the Game|publisher=[[Kotaku]]|last=Eisenbeis|first=Richard|accessdate=July 11, 2017|date=May 24, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170708043718/http://kotaku.com/love-psycho-pass-the-anime-you-ll-love-psycho-pass-the-1778354245|archivedate=July 8, 2017|df=}} Rebecca Silverman from Anime News Network praised the show for its "high level of interest" in depicting its dystopian world. However, she said that its violent scenes were so gruesome they might scare viewers.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/psycho-pass/episodes-12|title=Psycho-Pass episodes 12 - 22 Streaming|date=|publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=December 30, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122172053/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/psycho-pass/episodes-12|archivedate=January 22, 2014|df=}} [[Kotaku]]'s Richard Eisenbeis called it a "compelling cyberpunk mystery", praising the society depicted and the series of murders orchestrated by Shogo Makishima. However, he criticized the use of advanced technology and compared it with other science fiction films despite saying that it handled the themes better whereas Makishima's immunity to it was left unexplained.{{cite web|last=Eisenbeis|first=Richard|title=Psycho Pass is a Compelling Cyberpunk Mystery (And It’s Only Half Done)|url=http://kotaku.com/5973624/psycho-pass-is-a-compelling-cyberpunk-mystery-and-its-only-half-done|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Kotaku]]|accessdate=February 20, 2013|date=January 8, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128062043/http://kotaku.com/5973624/psycho-pass-is-a-compelling-cyberpunk-mystery-and-its-only-half-done|archivedate=January 28, 2013|df=}} [[DVD Talk]] gave high praise to Makishima because of his achievements across the story and his personality.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/63184/psycho-pass-season-1-part-1/|title=Psycho-Pass: Part One (Blu-ray)|publisher=DVDTalk|accessdate=April 18, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418220705/http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/63184/psycho-pass-season-1-part-1/|archivedate=April 18, 2014|df=}} Certain episodes have been referred as "filler" because they are used as a build-up to the climactic ones.{{cite web|url=http://www.fandompost.com/2013/02/07/psycho-pass-episode-15-anime-review/|title=Psycho-Pass Episode #15 Anime Review|publisher=The Fandom Post|accessdate=January 7, 2013|date=October 16, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924010553/http://www.fandompost.com/2013/02/07/psycho-pass-episode-15-anime-review/|archivedate=September 24, 2015|df=}} Bamboo Dong of Anime News Network gave high praise stating that from episode 12, the series was "a real blast to watch" and that she was glad with the development of the protagonist, Akane Tsunemori. However, she severely criticized the plot twist regarding the Sybil System's true identity calling it "one of the stupidest revelations in the history of anime". Thomas Zoth from The Fandom Post praised the show's focus on the relationships between the protagonists and the development from these. Akane's growth across the series earned major praise by multiple reviewers.{{cite web|url=http://www.fandompost.com/2013/01/22/psycho-pass-episode-13-anime-review/|title=Psycho-Pass Episode #13 Anime Review|publisher=The Fandom Post|accessdate=December 31, 2013|date=January 22, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924010550/http://www.fandompost.com/2013/01/22/psycho-pass-episode-13-anime-review/|archivedate=September 24, 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.uk-anime.net/anime/Psycho-Pass_Complete_Season_1_Collection.html|title=ANIME REVIEW: Psycho-Pass Complete Season 1 Collection|publisher=UK Anime Network|author=Hanley, Andy|accessdate=September 7, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140907084557/http://www.uk-anime.net/anime/Psycho-Pass_Complete_Season_1_Collection.html|archivedate=September 7, 2014|df=}} Zoth enjoyed the series' climactic action scenes between Kogami and Makishima, and the scenes portraying the status quo. He said the sixteenth episode is "Urobuchi's masterpiece."{{cite web|url=http://www.fandompost.com/2013/03/21/psycho-pass-episode-21-22-anime-review/|title=Psycho-Pass Episode #21 – 22 Anime Review|publisher=The Fandom Post|accessdate=December 31, 2013|date=March 21, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924010628/http://www.fandompost.com/2013/03/21/psycho-pass-episode-21-22-anime-review/|archivedate=September 24, 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fandompost.com/2013/02/12/psycho-pass-episode-16-anime-review/|title=Psycho-Pass Episode #16 Anime Review|publisher=The Fandom Post|accessdate=December 31, 2013|date=February 12, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924010559/http://www.fandompost.com/2013/02/12/psycho-pass-episode-16-anime-review/|archivedate=September 24, 2015|df=}} Silverman commented on the parallelism between Akane's and Kogami's development, which resulted in an ambiguous ending that should be decided by the viewers. The supporting cast received similar praise by DVD Talk but the reviewer said some were underwhelming and Shion is the least-explored character.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/63192/psycho-pass-season-one-part-two/|title=Psycho-Pass: Part Two (Blu-ray)|date=|publisher=DVDTalk|accessdate=April 18, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418220550/http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/63192/psycho-pass-season-one-part-two/|archivedate=April 18, 2014|df=}} During the streaming of the series, Silverman criticized the animation because of the low lighting levels that might make it hard to understand. Hiroko Yamamura from Japanator noted the series' high budget and praised the animation style and the focus on details and technology. She was attracted by its premise and expected the quality to remain consistent across the entire series.{{cite web|url=http://www.japanator.com/first-impressions-psycho-pass-27060.phtml|title=First Impressions: Psycho-Pass|publisher=Japanator|accessdate=March 21, 2013|date=October 16, 2012|author=Yamamura, Hiroko|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121228172646/http://www.japanator.com/first-impressions-psycho-pass-27060.phtml|archivedate=December 28, 2012|df=}} Similarly, Jacob Hope Chapman from ANN praised the animation for its high quality. Episode 18, which is known for its flawed animation, was improved for the home media release of the series.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/shelf-life/2014-04-14#pp|title=Hal I Met Your Mother|publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=April 14, 2014|date=April 14, 2014|author=Dong, Bamboo|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414232335/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/shelf-life/2014-04-14#pp|archivedate=April 14, 2014|df=}} Feedback to ''Psycho-Pass 2'' has ranged from mixed to negative. Dan Rhodes from UK Anime Network noted that ''Psycho-Pass 2'', while entertaining, lacked the twists of the first season and appeal of Gen Urobuchi's writing.{{cite web|url=http://www.uk-anime.net/anime/Psycho-Pass_2_Collector's_Edition.html|title=ANIME REVIEW: Psycho-Pass 2 Collector's Edition|publisher=UK Anime Network|author=Rhodes, Dan|accessdate=October 1, 2016|date=May 20, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180407170731/http://www.uk-anime.net/anime/Psycho-Pass_2_Collector's_Edition.html|archivedate=April 7, 2018|df=}} Richard Eisenbeis from Kotaku praised the origins of the Sybil System which was unexplained in the first season. While also praising the differences between Akane and the new Inspector, Mika Shimotsuki, Eisenbeis criticized the new antagonist and how much gorier the series was in contrast to the first one.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/psycho-pass-2-is-a-deliciously-dark-and-disturbing-cybe-1674300062|title=Psycho-Pass 2 is a deliciously dark and disturbing cybernetic tale|publisher=Kotaku|author=Eisenbeis, Richard|accessdate=October 16, 2016|date=December 23, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018205551/http://kotaku.com/psycho-pass-2-is-a-deliciously-dark-and-disturbing-cybe-1674300062|archivedate=October 18, 2016|df=}} Nick Creamer from Anime News Network was more negative during his review as he felt the new writer, [[Tow Ubukata]], did not make the anime appealing despite his previous enjoyable works. He went on to say "overall, Psycho-Pass 2 stands as one of the most disappointing works I've ever watched to completion," citing it a failure as both a sequel and an independent series.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/psycho-pass-2/bd-dvd-season-2/.100969|title=Psycho-Pass 2 BD+DVD - Season 2|publisher=Anime News Network|author=Rhodes, Dan|accessdate=October 1, 2016|date=April 12, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010130017/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/psycho-pass-2/bd-dvd-season-2/.100969|archivedate=October 10, 2016|df=}} The first ''Psycho-Pass'' film gathered positive reactions winning the 5th "[[Newtype|Newtype Anime Award]]" and the [[Seiun Award|Japan Sci-Fi Con's Seiun Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-03-29/empire-of-corpses-girls-and-panzer-psycho-pass-nominated-for-japan-sci-fi-con-seiun-awards/.100404|title=Empire of Corpses, Girls & Panzer, Psycho-Pass Nominated for Japan Sci-Fi Con's Seiun Awards|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=March 29, 2016|accessdate=January 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160830025010/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-03-29/empire-of-corpses-girls-and-panzer-psycho-pass-nominated-for-japan-sci-fi-con-seiun-awards/.100404#|archive-date=2016-08-30|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2015-10-10/fate-stay-night-psycho-pass-film-win-top-newtype-awards/.94038|title=Fate/Stay Night, Psycho-Pass Film Win Top Newtype Awards|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=October 10, 2015|accessdate=January 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231070247/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2015-10-10/fate-stay-night-psycho-pass-film-win-top-newtype-awards/.94038#|archive-date=2016-12-31|dead-url=no|df=}} {{main|Cyrtosperma merkusii}} '''Pulaka''', ''[[Cyrtosperma merkusii]]'', or '''swamp taro''', is a [[crop]] grown in [[Tuvalu]] and an important source of [[carbohydrate]]s for the area's inhabitants.<ref>{{cite book|last=Koch|first=Gerd|title=The material culture of Tuvalu|publisher=Institute of Pacific Studies, [[University of the South Pacific]]|origyear=1983|year=1990|page=46|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w7aeiuIXVigC&pg=PA46|accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> It is a "[[swamp]] crop" similar to [[taro]],<ref name="root crop">{{Cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Tuvalu could lose root crop | newspaper = | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[Radio New Zealand]] | date = 17 September 2008 | url = http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=42070 | accessdate = 10 May 2010}}</ref> but "with bigger leaves and larger, coarser roots."<ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Leaflet No. 1 - Revised 1992 - Taro | work = | publisher = [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] | date = | url = http://www.fao.org/WAIRdocs/x5425e/x5425e01.htm | doi = | accessdate = 10 May 2010}}</ref> The same plant is known as [[Babai (Swamp Taro)|babai]] in Kiribati, ''puraka'' in Cook Islands, ''pula’a'' in Samoa, ''via kan'' in Fiji, Pulaka in Tokelau, ''simiden'' in Chuuk, ''swam taro'' in Papua New Guinea, and ''navia'' in Vanuatu.<ref name=fao>{{cite web|title=Pacific Food Security Tookit Module 4 - Pacific Root Crops|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/013/am014e/am014e04.pdf|publisher=[[FAO]]}}</ref>
Pulaka roots need to be cooked for hours to reduce toxicity in the [[corm]]s, but are rich in nutrients, especially [[calcium]].<ref name="un"/> Pulaka is an important part of Tuvalu cultural and culinary tradition, now under threat from rising [[sea level]] and displacement from the growing use of imported food products.
==Cultivation== The crop is grown in pits dug into the [[limestone]] [[atoll]]<ref name="knox"/> and is fertilized by adding leaves from different plants.<ref name="inside">{{cite web|url=http://inside.org.au/tuvalunacy-or-the-real-thing/|title=Tuvalunacy, or the real thing?|last=Corlett|first=David|date=27 November 2008|work=Inside|accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> The plants derive water from the [[Lens (hydrology)|freshwater lens]] found a few meters below the atoll.<ref name="plight">{{cite journal|last=Laban|first=Winnie|date=October 1991|title=The Plight of the Pacific|journal=[[Multinational Monitor]]|volume=12|issue=10|url=http://multinationalmonitor.org/hyper/issues/1991/10/laban.html}}</ref> For this reason the cultivation of pulaka is threatened by rising sea levels caused by [[global warming]]: the plant does not thrive in the salt water which seeps into the pits:<ref name="knox"/> it rots the roots, turns the leaves yellow, and stunts the plant's growth.<ref name="un">{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/webcast/pdfs/unia1234.pdf|title=Tuvalu Food Security|last=Gorišek|first=Saša|date=April 2010|publisher=[[United Nations]]|accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> These saltwater intrusions occur more often now that the high tides have become higher, and more frequently flood the islands.<ref name="inside"/> To alleviate the problem of saltwater pollution, some islanders have begun to line the pits, side and bottom, with cement.<ref name="knox">{{Cite news | last = Knox | first = Angie | coauthors = | title = Sinking feeling in Tuvalu | newspaper = | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 28 August 2002 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/2219001.stm | accessdate = 10 May 2010}}</ref>
==Preparation and preservation== Pulaka makes up the bulk of the islanders' traditional diet; it is usually supplemented by fish.<ref name="koch">{{cite book|last=Koch|first=Gerd|title=The material culture of Tuvalu|publisher=Institute of Pacific Studies, [[University of the South Pacific]]|origyear=1983|year=1990|pages=73–85|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w7aeiuIXVigC&pg=PA73|accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> Since the unprocessed [[corm]]s are toxic, they must always be cooked, usually in an earth oven. Many of the recipes call for the addition of [[coconut cream]] or toddy, or both. On [[Niutao]], coconut cream (''lolo'') is poured over beaten pulp of pulaka, to make a dish called ''tulolo''. A similar dish on [[Nukufetau]], with halved corms, is called ''tulolo pulaka''; with beaten corms the dish is called ''fakapapa''. ''Fekei'' is made on all the islands, and consists of pulaka which is grated (typically this is done by the women) with the aid of limestone with holes drilled in it. The resulting pulp is wrapped in pulaka leaves and steamed, and mixed with coconut cream.<ref name="koch"/>
Preserving any food on the islands is difficult because of the hot climate. Pulaka is usually preserved by burying it in the ground, and it will keep up to three months. Cooks take baked pulaka corms and slice them to dry them in the sun; after six days of drying, the slices (''pulaka valuvalu'') are packed in coconut containers and hung from roof beams, and will keep up to seven years. The dried substance can be cooked in coconut cream and water to create a dish called ''likoliko''. On Nukufetao, ''puatolo'' is a dish made from grated pulaka and toddy, baked in the oven; when dried in the sun it will keep for three months.<ref name="koch"/>
==Cultural significance== The pits are dug and maintained by individual families over generations and have great cultural and personal significance: "The ownership and cultivation of the pulaka pits is an important part of family identity, cultural pride and survival. Encroachment of the salt water into the pulaka pit threatens the future of the people of Tuvalu."<ref name="plight"/> In addition, the secrets of producing the crop are often transferred from father to son, and when a father teaches his son how to plant pulaka, he is "practicing how to live like a man."<ref name="un"/>
Besides rising saltwater levels, "changing lifestyles and eating habits" also threaten the cultivation of the crop,<ref name="root crop"/> a process that began during and after [[World War II]], when American occupying troops supplied the islands with imported foods and many pits were no longer maintained.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Telavi | first = Melei | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Tuvalu - A History | work = | publisher = Institute of Pacific Studies and Extension Services, [[University of the South Pacific]]/Tuvalu Ministry of Social Services | year = 1983 | url = http://www.tuvaluislands.com/ww2/ww2-index.htm | doi = | accessdate = 10 May 2010}}</ref> Imported foods are often high in sugar, leading also to an increase in the need for dental care and diabetes.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Judd | first = Terri | coauthors = | title = Sailing the South Seas | newspaper = [[The Independent]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 15 May 2004 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/ausandpacific/sailing-the-south-seas-563400.html | accessdate = 12 May 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Crops originating from the Pacific]] [[Category:Oceanian culture]] [[Category:Oceanian cuisine]] [[Category:History of Tuvalu]] [[Category:Root vegetables]] [[Category:Leaf vegetables]] [[Category:Tropical agriculture]] [[Category:Staple foods]] [[Category:National dishes]] [[Category:Polynesian cuisine]]

revision.text:
{{see also|Collaborative consumption|Online sharing}} {{Economic systems sidebar}} {{Strategy}} '''Sharing economy''' is an umbrella term with a range of meanings, often used to describe [[economic activity]] involving online transactions.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal|last1=Taeihagh|first1=Araz|title=Crowdsourcing, Sharing Economies, and Development|journal=Journal of Developing Societies|date=19 June 2017|pages=0169796X1771007|doi=10.1177/0169796X17710072}}</ref> Originally growing out of the [[Open-source movement|open-source]] community to refer to [[Social peer-to-peer processes|peer-to-peer]] based sharing of access to goods and services,<ref name="thedefinition">{{cite journal|last=Hamari |first=Juho |last2=Sjöklint |first2=Mimmi |last3=Ukkonen |first3=Antti |date=2016 |title=The Sharing Economy: Why People Participate in Collaborative Consumption |volume=67 |issue=9 |pages=2047–2059|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/255698095_The_Sharing_Economy_Why_People_Participate_in_Collaborative_Consumption |journal=Journal of the Association for Information Science and Technology |doi=10.1002/asi.23552}}</ref> the term is now sometimes used in a broader sense to describe any sales transactions that are done via [[Two-sided market|online market places]], even ones that are business to business ([[B2C|B2B]]), rather than peer-to-peer. For this reason, the term ''sharing economy'' has been criticized as misleading, some arguing that even services that enable peer-to-peer exchange can be primarily profit-driven.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/money/2933937/sharing-economy-airbnb-uber-monkeyparking/|title=Can We Stop Pretending the Sharing Economy Is All About Sharing?|last=Tuttle|first=Brad|website=MONEY.com|access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> However, many commentators assert that the term is still valid as a mean of describing a generally more democratized marketplace, even when it's applied to a broader spectrum of services. Alternatively, collaborative consumption or the sharing economy refers rather to resource circulation systems which allow a consumer two-sided role, in which consumers may act as both providers of resources or obtainers of resources.<ref name="two-sided role">{{cite journal|last=Ertz|first=Myriam|last2=Durif|first2=Fabien|last3=Arcand|first3=Manon|date=2016 |title=Collaborative consumption: Conceptual snapshot at a buzzword|volume=19|issue=9|pages=1–23|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/311611603_Collaborative_Consumption_Conceptual_Snapshot_at_a_Buzzword|journal=Journal of Entrepreneurship Education}}</ref> The exchange may be performed directly on a peer-to-peer basis, or indirectly through a mediator (ex. store, website, app); online or offline; for free or for other compensation (ex. money, points, services, etc.).<ref name="exchange">{{cite journal|last=Ertz|first=Myriam|last2=Durif|first2=Fabien|last3=Arcand|first3=Manon|date=2018 |title=A conceptual perspective on collaborative consumption|journal=Academy of Marketing Science Review|doi=10.1007/s13162-018-0121-3}}</ref> This vision allows for a broader understanding of the sharing economy on the overarching criteria of consumer changing role capacity.<ref name="two-sided role"/><ref name="exchange"/>
Shared Economy is also known as collaborative consumption or collaborative economy or peer economy.<ref name="bibliometrics">{{cite journal|last=Ertz |first=Myriam |last2=Leblanc-Proulx |first2=Sébastien|date=2018|title=Sustainability in the sharing economy: A bibliometric analysis reveals emerging interest |volume=196 |pages=1073–1085|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/325760427_Sustainability_in_the_collaborative_economy_A_bibliometric_analysis_reveals_emerging_interest |journal=Journal of Cleaner Production |doi=10.1016/j.jclepro.2018.06.095}}</ref> It refers to a hybrid market model of a peer-to-peer exchange <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Laurell|first=Christofer|last2=Sandström|first2=Christian|title=The sharing economy in social media: Analyzing tensions between market and non-market logics|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.techfore.2017.05.038|journal=Technological Forecasting and Social Change|language=en|volume=125|pages=58–65|doi=10.1016/j.techfore.2017.05.038}}</ref> Such transactions are often facilitated via community-based online services.<ref name="thedefinition" /><ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f560e5ee-36e8-11e6-a780-b48ed7b6126f |title= Review – 'The Sharing Economy', by Arun Sundararajan|work= [[Financial Times]] |author= Leslie Hook|date= 22 June 2016|accessdate=2016-07-15|format={{registration required}}}}</ref> ''[[Uberisation|Uberization]]'' is also an alternative name for the phenomenon.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cso.com.au/mediareleases/27033/taking-uberization-to-the-field-disruption-is/ | title=Taking uberization to the Field – Disruption is coming for Field Marketing – Media Releases – CSO – The Resource for Data Security Executives | publisher=CSO | accessdate=June 2, 2016}}</ref>
The sharing economy may take a variety of forms, including using [[information technology]] to provide individuals with information that enables the optimization of resources through the mutualization of excess capacity in goods and services.<ref>{{cite web|title=Business Models Shaping New Mobility|url=https://www.wsp.com/en-GL/insights/business-models-shaping-new-mobility|work=January, 2018|publisher=WSP Global|accessdate=9 Jan 2018}}</ref> <ref name="morally"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Sundararajan|first=Arun|title=From Zipcar to the Sharing Economy|url=http://blogs.hbr.org/cs/2013/01/from_zipcar_to_the_sharing_eco.html|work=January 3, 2013|publisher=Harvard Business Review|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref> A common premise is that when information about goods is shared (typically via an [[online marketplace]]), the value of those goods may increase for the business, for individuals, for the community and for society in general.<ref>{{cite news|last=Geron|first=Tomio|title=Airbnb Had $56 Million Impact On San Francisco: Study|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomiogeron/2012/11/09/study-airbnb-had-56-million-impact-on-san-francisco/|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=Forbes|date=November 9, 2012}}</ref>
Collaborative consumption as a phenomenon is a class of economic arrangements in which participants mutualize access to products or services, in addition to finding original ways to individual ownership.<ref name="thedefinition" /><ref name="exchange" /> The phenomenon stems from an increasing consumer desire to be in control of their consumption instead of "passive 'victims' of hyperconsumption".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Botsman|first1=Rachel|last2=Rogers|first2=Roo|title=What's mine is yours : how collaborative consumption is changing the way we live|date=2011|publisher=Collins|location=London|isbn=978-0-00-739591-0|page=51|edition=Rev. and updated}}</ref> The consumer peer-to-peer rental market is valued at $26bn (£15bn), with new services and [[Economic platform|platforms]] emerging frequently.<ref>{{Cite book|title = What's Mine Is Yours: How Collaborative Consumption is Changing the Way We Live|last = Botsman|first = Rachel|publisher = HarperCollins Business|year = 2011|isbn = 0-00-739591-4|location = |pages = |last2 = Rogers|first2 = Roo}}</ref>
The collaborative consumption model is used in online marketplaces such as [[eBay]] as well as emerging sectors such as social lending, peer-to-peer accommodation, peer-to-peer travel experiences,<ref>{{Cite web|title = From homes to meals to cars, 'sharing' has changed the face of travel|url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/travel/sc-trav-1229-sharing-economy-20151216-story.html|website = chicagotribune.com|accessdate = 2015-12-22}}</ref> peer-to-peer task assignments or travel advising, [[carsharing]] or [[commuting|commute]]-bus sharing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hbscny.org/article.html?aid=587 |title=Harvard Business School Club of New York – What's Mine Is Yours: The Rise of Collaborative Consumption |publisher=Hbscny.org |date=2011-06-16 |accessdate=2015-03-13}}</ref>
The ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'', the ''[[Financial Times]]'' and many others have argued that "sharing economy" is a misnomer.
