Harvard Business Review suggested the correct word for the sharing economy in the broad sense of the term is "[[access economy]]". The authors say, "When "sharing" is market-mediated—when a company is an intermediary between consumers who don't know each other—it is no longer sharing at all. Rather, consumers are paying to access someone else's goods or services.".<ref name="Harvard Business Review">{{cite web |url=https://hbr.org/2015/01/the-sharing-economy-isnt-about-sharing-at-all |title= The Sharing Economy Isn't About Sharing at All |publisher=Harvard Business Review |date=2015-01-28 |accessdate=2015-07-11}}</ref>
== Scope == According to sharing economy expert [[Alex Stephany]], it is a mystery as to who first used the term ''sharing economy'', which has left the term "without a guardian and vulnerable to loose definitions".<ref name = "Stephany"> {{cite book |author = Alex Stephany |title=The Business of Sharing: Making it in the New Sharing Economy |chapter= |year= 2015 |isbn=1137376171 |publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]] }}</ref>
A variety of definitions exist. "The people who share" is one of the broadest definitions, which encompasses the [[Access economy|on-demand economy]], the [[gig economy]], [[social media]], and a great deal else.<ref> {{cite web |url= http://www.thepeoplewhoshare.com/blog/what-is-the-sharing-economy/ |title= What is the Sharing Economy? |publisher= The people who share |author=Benita Matofska |quote = "A Sharing Economy enables different forms of value exchange and is a hybrid economy. It encompasses the following aspects: swapping, exchanging, collective purchasing, collaborative consumption, shared ownership, shared value, co-operatives, co-creation, recycling, upcycling, re-distribution, trading used goods, renting, borrowing, lending, subscription based models, peer-to-peer, collaborative economy, circular economy, on-demand economy, gig economy, crowd economy, pay-as-you-use economy, wikinomics, peer-to-peer lending, micro financing, micro-entrepreneurship, social media, the Mesh, social enterprise, futurology, crowdfunding, crowdsourcing, cradle-to-cradle, open source, open data, user generated content (UGC) and public services." |date = 2016-08-01 |accessdate=2016-08-01}} </ref> Academic definitions tend to be narrower, limiting the sharing economy to only peer-to-peer transactions, and sometimes further limiting the definition to only peer-to-peer transactions that relate to the temporary exchange of physical goods.<ref name = "cost of Non-Europe"/> Another set of narrow definitions used by free culture activists, members of the co-operative movement and similar, excludes for-profit companies from the sharing economy, even if they facilitate just peer-to-peer transactions. Sometimes called the "real" or "true" sharing economy, organisations that operate within such definitions are mostly small and localist, run by volunteers on a cooperative basis, though sometimes also by governments and municipal authorities. They can include some organisations that operate without online transactions, such as [[Bicycle cooperative|bike kitchens]]. The "true" sharing economy does include some large internationally available web sites however, such as [[The Freecycle Network|Freecycle]].<ref name = "cost of Non-Europe"> {{cite web |url= http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/STUD/2016/558777/EPRS_STU(2016)558777_EN.pdf |title= The Cost of Non-Europe in the Sharing Economy |publisher= EPRS : European Parliamentary Research Service |author=Pierre Goudin |date = January 2016 |accessdate=2016-08-01}} </ref><ref name = "Digital Matching"> {{cite web |url= http://www.esa.gov/sites/default/files/digital-matching-firms-new-definition-sharing-economy-space.pdf |title= Digital Matching Firms: A New Definition in the "Sharing Economy" Space |publisher= [[United States Department of Commerce]] |author= Rudy Telles Jr |date = June 3, 2016 |accessdate=2016-08-01}} </ref><ref> {{cite web |url= http://www.eastbayexpress.com/oakland/the-true-sharing-economy/Content?oid=4563249 |title= The True Sharing Economy |publisher= East Bay Express |author=Zoe Oja Tucker |date = 8 Nov 2015 |accessdate=2016-08-01}} </ref>
The term ''sharing economy'' has been widely used since about 2010, yet according to a [[Pew Research Center|Pew]] survey taken in winter 2015, only 27% of Americans had heard of the term.<ref name ="Pew"> {{cite web |url= http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/05/20/how-americans-define-the-sharing-economy/ |title= How Americans define the sharing economy |publisher= [[Pew Research Center]] |author= Kenneth Olmstead and Aaron Smith |date = 20 May 2016 |accessdate=2016-07-16}} </ref>
Survey respondents who had heard of the term had divergent views on what it meant, with many thinking it concerned "sharing" in the traditional sense of the term.<ref name ="Pew"/> In 2010 and 2011, many people involved with the sharing economy did indeed consider it to be about sharing in the traditional sense. A commonly used example at the time was the idea of sharing a power drill—a tool that many consumers might use for only a few minutes in their lifetime. Advocates said it made sense for regular consumers not to buy their own power drill, but to borrow from others instead, and that this borrowing could be facilitated by online platforms. Several startups companies were launched to help people share drills and similar goods along these lines. Yet looking back from 2015, it was clear that consumers had generally not been interested in such temporary exchanges, leading to the failure of many startups which aimed to facilitate traditional sharing.<ref>Economic Explanation: From Sharecropping to the Sharing Economy http://econpapers.repec.org/article/bpjmaneco/v_3a3_3ay_3a2016_3ai_3a1_3ap_3a77-96_3an_3a4.htm</ref><ref>What makes Uber and Airbnb flourish while others fail in ‘sharing economy’? http://newsstand.clemson.edu/what-makes-uber-and-airbnb-flourish-while-others-fail-in-sharing-economy/</ref> While some successful platforms such as [[Airbnb]] or CanYa can be described as involving the sharing of a resource, as of 2016 the term ''sharing economy'' has been widely criticised as being misleading.<ref name = "killed"> {{cite web |url= http://www.fastcompany.com/3050775/the-sharing-economy-is-dead-and-we-killed-it |title= The "Sharing Economy" Is Dead, And We Killed It |publisher= [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |author= Sarah Kessler |date = 14 Oct 2015 |accessdate=2016-07-15}} </ref><ref name = "neither">{{Cite news |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/8273edfe-2c9f-11e6-a18d-a96ab29e3c95.html |title= The gig economy is neither 'sharing' nor 'collaborative' |work= [[Financial Times]] |author= Sarah O'Connor |date= 14 June 2016 |accessdate=2016-07-15 |format={{registration required}}}}</ref>
The scope of the sharing economy has been a subject of academic debate. Depending on the criteria used, some platforms would be included within the sharing economy, but not others. For example, going by whether companies self-describe as being part of the sharing economy, [[TaskRabbit]] would be included, but not [[Amazon Mechanical Turk|mechanical Turk]].<ref> {{cite web |url= http://www.greattransition.org/publication/debating-the-sharing-economy |title= Debating the Sharing Economy |publisher= |author= [[Juliet Schor]] |date = October 2014 |accessdate=2016-07-15}} </ref>
Commercial implementations{{r|friedman}} encompass a wide range of structures including mostly for-profit, and, to a lesser extent, co-operative structures.{{r|rosenberg}} The sharing economy provides expanded access to products, services and talent beyond one-to-one or singular ownership, which is sometimes referred to as "disownership".<ref>{{cite web|last=Wang|first=Ray|title=Monday's Musings: Four Elements for A #SharingEconomy Biz Model In #MatrixCommerce|url=http://blog.softwareinsider.org/2013/05/26/mondays-musings-how-the-sharing-economy-impacts-matrix-commerce/|work=May 26, 2013|publisher=Software Insider|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref> individuals actively participate as users, providers, lenders or borrowers in varied and evolving [[peer-to-peer]] exchange schemes which are often [[world Wide Web|web]]-mediated.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Collaborative Economy|url=http://www.slideshare.net/Altimeter/the-collaborative-economy|work=June 4, 2013|publisher=Altimeter Group|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref>
== History == Several key macro developments led to the (re-)emergence of mutualization in consumption. The "sharing economy" results from several deep-seated technological, economic, political, and societal changes:<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ertz|first=Myriam|last2=Durif|first2=Fabien|last3=Arcand|first3=Manon|title=An analysis of the origins of collaborative consumption and its implications for marketing|journal=Academy of Marketing Studies Journal|year=2016|ssrn=2799862|accessdate=}}</ref> * Technological: the Web transformed consumers' relationship to objects. * Economic: austerity and crises, decline of stable and full-time employment as well as of purchasing power. * Political: withering of the State and its increased adjustment to the market ethos. * Social: society views consumption as a central project in their lives.
The term "sharing economy" began to appear in the early 2000s, as new business structures emerged due to the Great Recession, enabling social technologies, and an increasing sense of urgency around global population growth and resource depletion. Professor [[Lawrence Lessig]] was possibly first to use the term in 2008, though others claim the origin of the term is unknown.<ref name = "Stephany"/><ref> {{cite web |url= http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/homestay-is-the-origin-of-sharing-economy-249415791.html |title= Homestay is the origin of Sharing Economy |publisher= [[PR Newswire]] |author= |date = 2014-03-11 |accessdate=2016-07-15}} </ref>
The phenomena of the sharing economy certainly emerged much earlier than 2008 however, even in the sense of exchange co-ordinated by online platforms. One inspiration was the [[tragedy of the commons]], which refers to the idea that when we all act solely in our self-interest, we deplete the shared resources we need for our own quality of life. The Harvard law professor [[Yochai Benkler]], one of the earliest proponents of open source software, posited that network technology could mitigate this issue through what he called '[[commons-based peer production]]', a concept first articulated in 2002.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Benkler|first=Yochai|title=Coase's Penguin, or, Linux and The Nature of the Firm|journal=The Yale Law Journal|year=2002|volume=112|url=http://www.yale.edu/yalelj/112/BenklerWEB.pdf|accessdate=13 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010152105/http://www.yale.edu/yalelj/112/BenklerWEB.pdf|archivedate=10 October 2010|df=}}</ref> Benkler then extended that analysis to "shareable goods" in ''Sharing Nicely: On Shareable goods and the emergence of sharing as a modality of economic production''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Benkler|first=Yochai|title=Sharing Nicely: On Shareable goods and the emergence of sharing as a modality of economic production|journal=The Yale Law Journal|year=2004|volume=114|url=http://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=4058&context=fss_papers|accessdate=9 July 2014}}</ref>
The term "collaborative consumption" was coined by Marcus Felson and Joe L. Spaeth in their paper "Community Structure and Collaborative Consumption: A routine activity approach" published in 1978 in the ''American Behavioral Scientist''.<ref>Felson, Marcus and Joe L. Spaeth (1978), "Community Structure and Collaborative Consumption: A routine activity approach," American Behavioral Scientist, 21 (March–April), 614–24.</ref>
In 2011, collaborative consumption was named one of ''[[TIME]]'' magazine's 10 ideas that will change the world.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2059521_2059717_2059710,00.html | work=Time | title=10 Ideas That Will Change The World | date=March 17, 2011}}</ref>
A recent study,<ref name="bibliometrics"/> using bibliometrics and network analysis, analyzed the evolution of scholarly research on collaborative consumption, and identified that this expression started in 2010 with Botsman and Rogers' (2010) book "What's mine is yours: The rise of collaborative consumption". The number of studies published on the subject then increased exponentially in 2014. Furthermore, there are four clusters of research: 1) exploration and conceptualization of collaborative consumption; 2) consumer behavior and marketing empiricism; 3) mutualization and sharing systems; 4) sustainability in the collaborative economy. The analysis suggests that this last cluster was under-researched in contrast to the three others, but has started to increase in importance since 2017.
=== Developments since 2014 === The UK Government in its 2015 [[Budget#United Kingdom|Budget]] set out objectives to improve economic growth including to make Britain the "...best place in the world to start, invest in, and grow a business, including through a package of measures to help unlock the potential of the sharing economy..."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/416330/47881_Budget_2015_Web_Accessible.pdf|title=Support for the sharing economy|last=|first=|date=|work=H. M. Treasury, Budget 2015, section 1.193|format=PDF|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>{{rp|4}}
Also in 2015, ''The Business of Sharing by Alex Stephany'', CEO of [[JustPark]], was published by Palgrave Macmillan.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thememo.com/2015/05/05/review-the-business-of-sharing | title= Review: The Business Of Sharing | date=May 5, 2015}}</ref> The book features interviews with high-profile entrepreneurs such as [[Martin Varsavsky]] and venture capitalists such as [[Fred Wilson (financier)|Fred Wilson]].
===Size and growth=== The rapid growth of the sharing economy has been frequently remarked on.<ref name="Harvard Business Review"/> Yet according to a report by the [[United States Department of Commerce|United States Department of Commerce in June 2016]], quantitative research on size and growth remains sparse. Such growth estimates as there are can be challenging to evaluate due to different and sometimes unspecified definitions about what sort of activity counts as sharing economy transactions.<ref name = "Digital Matching"/>
The June 2016 report summarised currently available research. This included a 2014 study by [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]], which looked at five components of the sharing economy: travel, car sharing, finance, staffing and streaming. It found that global spending in these sectors totalled about $15 billion in 2014, which was only about 5% of the total spending in those areas. The report also forecasts a possible increase of "sharing economy" spending in these areas to $335 billion by 2025, which would be about 50% of the total spending in said five areas.<ref name = "Digital Matching"/><ref> {{cite web |url= http://www.pwc.co.uk/issues/megatrends/collisions/sharingeconomy/the-sharing-economy-sizing-the-revenue-opportunity.html |title= The sharing economy – sizing the revenue opportunity |publisher= [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]] |author=John Hawksworth and Robert Vaughan |date = 2014 |accessdate=2016-08-01}} </ref> A 2015 PricewaterhouseCoopers study found that nearly one-fifth of American consumers partake in some type of sharing economy activity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pwc.com/us/en/technology/publications/sharing-economy.html|title=The Sharing Economy|last=|first=|date=April 2015|website=www.pwc.com|access-date=2017-10-23}}</ref> A 2017 report by [[Diana Farrell]] and Fiona Greig suggested that at least in the US, sharing economy growth may have peaked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brie.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/PlatformEconomy2DistributeJune21.pdf|title=The platform economy|author=Juliet Schor|date=17 May 2018|publisher=[[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]]|accessdate=July 4, 2018}}</ref>
== Types of collaborative consumption == [[File:One day living with commons-based peer production communities (CBPP).svg|thumb|Examples of [[Commons-based peer production]] (CBPP) communities, aka P2P communities]]
{{Main|Collaborative consumption}}
Originally, Botsman and Rogers (2010) identified three resource circulation systems within collaborative consumption, i.e. the sharing economy: product service systems, redistribution markets and collaborative lifestyles.
=== Product-service systems === {{Main|Product-service system}} Product-service systems refer to commercial peer-to-peer mutualization systems (CPMS), allowing consumers to engage in monetized exchanges through [[Social peer-to-peer processes|peer-to-peer]]-based for temporary access to goods. Goods that are privately owned can be shared or rented out via peer-to-peer marketplaces.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|author1=Rachel Botsman|author2=Roo Rogers |url=http://hbr.org/2010/10/beyond-zipcar-collaborative-consumption/ar/1 |title=Beyond Zipcar: Collaborative Consumption |publisher=Hbr.org |date=1922-01-01 |accessdate=2015-03-13}}</ref> For example, BMW's "[[DriveNow]]" is a car rental service that offers an alternative to owning a car. Users can access a car when and where they need them and pay for their usage by the minute.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.bmwblog.com/2011/03/21/bmw-and-sixt-establish-drivenow-joint-venture-for-premium-car-sharing/|title = DriveNow: BMW and Sixt Joint Venture for premium car sharing|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
=== Redistribution markets === A system of collaborative consumption is based on used or pre-owned goods being passed on from someone who does not want them to someone who does want them. This is another alternative to the more common 'reduce, reuse, recycle, repair' methods of dealing with waste. In some markets, the goods may be free, as on [[The Freecycle Network|Freecycle]], [[Zwaggle]] and [[Kashless.org|Kashless]]. In others, the goods are swapped (as on [[Swap.com]]) or sold for cash (as on eBay, craigslist, and uSell).
=== Collaborative lifestyles === Collaborative lifestyles refer to community-based platforms, allowing consumers to engage in monetized exchanges through [[Social peer-to-peer processes|peer-to-peer]]-based for services or access to resources such as money or skills.<ref name="morally"/> These systems are based on people with similar needs or interests banding together to mutualize and exchange less-tangible assets such as time, space, skills, and money. The growth of mobile technology provides a platform to enable location-based GPS technology and to also provide real-time sharing.<ref>{{cite news|last=Owyang|first=Jeremiah|title=The mobile technology stack for the Collaborative Economy|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/02/17/the-mobile-technology-stack-for-the-collaborative-economy/|accessdate=24 February 2015|publisher=VentureBeat|date=24 February 2015}}</ref>
==Resource circulation systems==
=== Crowdfunding platforms === {{Main|Crowdfunding}} According to some authors, sector-specific models may stand out as specific components of the sharing economy. These models also use a two-sided marketplace to enable individuals to contribute funds to entrepreneurs, artists, civic programs and projects.<ref>{{cite web|author=Karim R. Lakhani |url=http://hbr.org/2013/04/using-the-crowd-as-an-innovation-partner/ |title=Using the Crowd as an Innovation Partner |publisher=Hbr.org |date=1922-01-01 |accessdate=2015-03-13}}</ref>
=== Expert networks === {{Main|Expert network}} These models also use a two-sided marketplace to enable experts to provide on-demand information to consumers.
=== Transparent and open data === Many state, local and federal governments<ref>{{cite news|last=Mazmanian|first=Adam|title=Can open data change the culture of government?|url=http://fcw.com/articles/2013/05/23/digital-government-anniversary.aspx|newspaper=Federal Computer Week|date=May 22, 2013}}</ref> are engaged in [[Open data|Open Data]] initiatives and projects such as data.gov<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.data.gov/ |title=Data.gov |publisher=Data.gov |date= |accessdate=2015-03-13}}</ref> and the London Data Store.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.london.gov.uk/ |title=London Datastore |publisher=Data.london.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-03-13}}</ref> The theory of open or "transparent" access to information enables greater innovation,<ref>{{cite web|last=Hammell|first=Richard|title=Open Data: Driving Growth, Ingenuity and Innovation|url=http://www.deloitte.com/assets/dcom-unitedkingdom/local%20assets/documents/market%20insights/deloitte%20analytics/uk-insights-deloitte-analytics-open-data-june-2012.pdf|publisher=Deloitte Consulting|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref> and makes for more efficient use of products and services, and thus supporting resilient communities.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brindley|first=William|title=How Open Data can Save Lives|url=http://forumblog.org/2013/01/how-open-data-can-save-lives/|publisher=World Economic Forum|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref>
=== Trust === The Sharing Economy relies on the will of the users to share, but in order to make an exchange, users have to be trustworthy and trust each other. Sharing economy organizations say they are committed to building and validating trusted relationships between members of their community, including producers, suppliers, customers or participants.<ref>{{cite news|last=Charles|first=Green|title=Trusted and Being Trusted in the Sharing Economy|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/trustedadvisor/2012/05/02/trusting-and-being-trusted-in-the-sharing-economy/2/|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=Forbes|date=May 2, 2012}}</ref> Beyond trusting others (i.e., the peers), the users of a Sharing Economy platform also have to trust the platform itself as well as the product at hand.<ref name="trustppp">{{cite journal|last=Hawlitschek|first=Florian|last2=Teubner|first2=Timm|last3=Weinhardt|first3=Christof|date=2016 |title=Trust in the Sharing Economy|journal=Swiss Journal of Business Research and Practice|volume= 70|issue=1 |pages= 26–44 |doi=10.5771/0042-059X-2016-1-26}}</ref>
=== Unused value is wasted value === Unused value refers to the time over which products, services and talents lay idle. This idle time is wasted value that business models and organizations that are based on sharing can potentially utilize. The classic example is that the average car is unused 92% of the time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://energyseminar.stanford.edu/node/425 |title=Car Sharing and Pooling: Reducing Car Over-Population and Collaborative Consumption | Energy Seminar |publisher=Energyseminar.stanford.edu |date=2012-04-09 |accessdate=2015-03-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141123161330/http://energyseminar.stanford.edu/node/425 |archivedate=2014-11-23 |df= }}</ref> This wasted value can be a significant resource, and hence an opportunity, for sharing economy car solutions. There is also significant unused value in "wasted time", as articulated by [[Clay Shirky]] in his analysis of power of "crowds" connected by information technology. Many people have unused capacity in the course of their day. With social media and information technology, such people can donate small slivers of time to take care of simple tasks that others need doing. Examples of these [[Crowdsourcing|crowd sourced]] solutions<ref>{{cite web|last=Boudreau|first=Kevin|title=Using the Crowd as an Innovation Partner|url=http://hbr.org/2013/04/using-the-crowd-as-an-innovation-partner/|work=April 2013|publisher=Harvard Business Review|author2=Karim R. Lakhani }}</ref> include the for-profit [[Amazon Mechanical Turk]] and the non-profit [[Ushahidi]].
=== Waste as food === Waste is commonly considered as something that is no longer wanted and needs to be discarded. The challenge with this point of view is that much of what we define as waste still has value that, with proper design and distribution, can safely serve as "nutrients" for follow-on processes, unlocking new levels of value in increasingly scarce and expensive resources. One example is "[[Machine quilting#Heirloom machine quilting|heirloom design]]"<ref>{{cite news|last=Bloyd-Peshkin|first=Sharon|title=Built to Trash|url=http://inthesetimes.com/article/5023/|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=In These Times|date=October 21, 2009}}</ref> as articulated by physicist and inventor [[Saul Griffith]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Griffith|first=Saul|title=Everyday Inventions|url=http://www.ted.com/talks/saul_griffith_on_everyday_inventions.html|publisher=TED|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref>
== Driving forces == The driving forces behind the rise of sharing economy organizations and businesses include:
* '''Information technology and social media:''' A host of enabling technologies has reached the mainstream, making it easy for networks of people and organizations to transact directly and to scale the business.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Frey|first=Alexander|last2=Trenz|first2=Manuel|last3=Veit|first3=Daniel|date=2017|title=The Role of Technology for Service Innovation in Sharing Economy Organizations – a Service-Dominant Logic Perspective|url=http://aisel.aisnet.org/ecis2017_rp/121|journal=Proceedings of the 25th European Conference on Information Systems (ECIS)|language=en|volume=|pages=1885–1901|via=AISeL}}</ref> These include; open data,<ref>{{cite web|title=Open Data Handbook|url=http://opendatahandbook.org/en/what-is-open-data/|work=2011, 2012|publisher=Open Knowledge Foundation|accessdate=13 June 2013}}</ref> the ubiquity and low-cost of mobile phones,<ref>{{cite web|title=ICT Facts and Figures, 2013|url=http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Documents/facts/ICTFactsFigures2013.pdf|work=2013|publisher=International Telecommunications Union|accessdate=13 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512042553/http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Documents/facts/ICTFactsFigures2013.pdf|archivedate=12 May 2013|df=}}</ref> and social media.<ref>{{cite news|last=Parr|first=Ben|title=What the F**k is Social Media?|url=http://mashable.com/2009/08/03/what-is-social-media/|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=Mashable|date=August 3, 2009}}</ref> These technologies dramatically reduce the friction of share-based business and organizational models. * '''[[Social commerce]]:''' The notion that commerce is facilitated by social networking. It has contributed to the emergence of the sharing economy. People are more likely to buy products because of the "social influence exerted by peers on purchasing decisions".<ref>Hamari, Juho, Mimmi Sjöklint, and Antti Ukkonen. "The sharing economy: Why people participate in collaborative consumption." Journal of the Association for Information Science and Technology (2015).</ref> The involvement of social media encourages and promotes the sharing economy and social commerce because it not only encourages people buy similar products and try similar things, but it also encourages people to look for group deals on these similar products as well. Group deals are proliferated by companies like [[Groupon]]. "Social commerce is moving beyond individual enjoyment and centering on economic concern. For instance, a pertinent form of social commerce is the consumer self-coordination of group deals for pursuit of economic gains."<ref>Wang, C., & Zhang, P. (2012). The evolution of social commerce: The people, management, technology, and information dimensions. Communications of the Association for Information Systems, 31(1), 105–127.</ref> "The results show that participation in sharing economy is motivated by many factors such as its sustainability, enjoyment of the activity as well as economic gains."<ref>Hamari, Juho, Mimmi Sjöklint, and Antti Ukkonen. "The Sharing Economy: Why People Participate in Collaborative Consumption." Journal of the Association for Information Science and Technology, 02 June 2015. Web. 02 Mar. 2017.</ref> * '''Urban lifestyle:''' The congested urban setting creates a new series of problems that can be addressed by the sharing economy. "Unlike earlier generations of information or technology-based enterprises, sharing enterprises rely on a critical mass of providers and consumers who are sufficiently close to each other or to other amenities to make their platforms work, often finding value in the very fact of the beneficial spillovers from proximity."<ref>Davidson, Nestor M. and John J. Infranca. "The Sharing Economy as an Urban Phenomenon." Yale Law & Policy Review, vol. 34, no. 2, Spring2016, pp. 215-279. EBSCOhost, http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=118436221&site=eds-live.</ref> [[Uber (company)|Uber]], for example, takes people who live in one common area and transports them to another area. However, to make the initial pick up the Uber driver must be relatively close to the passenger. Urban settings inherently force people to live and work in close proximity. This means that the number of people going to and from similar destinations is going to increase. Uber realized this and created a business format to take advantage of this new urban setting. [[Airbnb]] is another example of a company that solves a problem created by the centralized urban setting. In urban settings where there is limited space for housing, people are always hard pressed to find cheaper housing and rental options when moving from city to city. AirBNB realized this and was able to take advantage of people who had space they aren’t using and rent it out at cheaper costs to the people who need a place to stay for shorter amounts of time. * '''Increasing volatility in cost of natural resources:''' Rising prosperity across the developing world coupled with population growth is putting greater strain on natural resources and has caused a spike in costs and market volatility. This has been increasing pressure on traditional manufacturers to seek design, production and distribution alternatives that will stabilize costs and smooth projected expenditures. In this context, the [[circular economy]] approach has been gaining interest among many global corporate actors. While a handful of pioneering companies are leading the way, wider adoption will rely on mesh economy skills such as the collection and sharing of data, the spread of best practices, and increased collaboration.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sharing brings major benefits to new mobility|url=https://www.wsp.com/en-GL/insights/sharing-brings-major-benefits-to-new-mobility|work=January, 2018|publisher=WSP Global|accessdate=9 Jan 2018}}</ref> An example of this could be taken from an interview by Arun Sundararajan with Ola CEO Bhavish Aggarwal suggesting that India’s rising middle class might ‘leap-frog’ car ownership all together and shift to ride-sharing given car ownerships large inefficiencies in the United States.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Sharing Economy: The End of Employment and the Rise of Crowd-Based Capitalism|last=Sundararajan|first=Arun|publisher=The MIT Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=116}}</ref> *'''Rising Costs:''' Once the increased costs of natural resources has been passed onto consumers they also begin to look for solutions within the sharing economy. Communities and companies like Visitours<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.visitours.io|title=Visitours|website=www.visitours.io|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref> look to reduce the costs of acquiring resources through sharing those resources with other whilst they're in use. Akin to reducing transaction costs as detailed [[Michael Munger]] in Tomorrow 3.0,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://doi.org/10.1017/9781108602341|title=Tomorrow 3.0|last=Munger|first=Michael C.|date=2018-03-07|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781108602341|language=en|doi=10.1017/9781108602341}}</ref> Visitours<ref name=":7" /> allows travellers to use the same resources but splits the fixed costs of doing so by sharing them. Unlike Uber or Airbnb, this type of collaborative consumption reduces the amount of excess capacity in the economy without commoditising the assets that it relies on.
''Forbes'' estimates the revenue flowing through the shared economy would surpass $3.5 billion in 2013, with growth exceeding 25%.<ref>{{cite news|last=Geron|first=Tobio|title=Airbnb and the Unstoppable Rise of the Share Economy|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomiogeron/2013/01/23/airbnb-and-the-unstoppable-rise-of-the-share-economy/|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=Forbes|date=January 23, 2013}}</ref>
== Benefits == {{multiple issues|section=y|{{NPOV section|date=May 2016}} {{advert section|date=May 2016}} {{Refimprove section|date=May 2016}}}} Suggested benefits of the sharing economy include: * Reducing negative environmental impacts through decreasing the amount of goods needed to be produced, cutting down on industry pollution (such as reducing the [[carbon footprint]] and overall consumption of resources)<ref>{{cite news|last1=Brady|first1=Diane|title=The Environmental Case for the Sharing Economy|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/articles/2014-09-24/the-environmental-case-for-the-sharing-economy|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=10 July 2015|date=24 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=rudenko>{{cite web|last1=Rudenko|first1=Anna|title=The collaborative consumption on the rise: why shared economy is winning over the "capitalism of me"|url=http://popsop.com/2013/08/the-collaborative-consumption-sharing-wins-over-ownership/|accessdate=10 July 2015|date=16 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=parsons>{{cite web|last1=Parsons|first1=Adam|title=The sharing economy: a short introduction to its political evolution|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/transformation/adam-parsons/sharing-economy-short-introduction-to-its-political-evolution|website=opendemocracy.net|accessdate=10 July 2015|date=5 March 2014}}</ref> * Strengthening communities{{dubious|date=May 2016}}<ref name=rudenko /> * Lowering consumer costs by borrowing and recycling items<ref name=rudenko /> * Providing people with access to goods who can't afford buying them{{dubious|date=May 2016}}<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bradshaw|first1=Della|title=Sharing economy benefits lower income groups|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/7afde9b0-d95a-11e4-a8f1-00144feab7de.html|website=FT.com|accessdate=10 July 2015|date=22 April 2015}}{{unreliable source?|date=May 2016}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=May 2016}} or have no interest in long-term usage * Increased independence, flexibility and [[Self-sufficiency|self-reliance]] by [[decentralization]], the abolition of monetary entry-barriers, and [[self-organization]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Williams-Grut|first1=Oscar|title=Silicon Round-up: Blockchain banking to be on the slate for new regulator?|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/business/business-news/silicon-roundup-blockchain-banking-to-be-on-the-slate-for-new-regulator-10123119.html|publisher=London Evening Standard|accessdate=10 July 2015|date=20 March 2015}}{{unreliable source?|date=May 2016}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=May 2016}} * Increased [[participatory democracy]]{{dubious|date=May 2016}}<ref name=parsons /> * Accelerating [[sustainable consumption]] and production patterns in cities around the globe{{clarify|date=May 2016}}<ref name="sharing cities">{{cite journal|last= Cohen |first= Boyd |last2= Muñoz |first2= Pablo | date=2015 | title= Sharing cities and sustainable consumption and production: towards an integrated framework | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959652615010641 | journal= Journal of Cleaner Production|doi=10.1016/j.jclepro.2015.07.133}} {{Closed access}} | [http://eprints.whiterose.ac.uk/89480/ Post-print version] {{Open access}}</ref> * Increased quality of service through rating systems provided by companies involved in the sharing economy<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fpf.org/2015/06/08/user-reputation-building-trust-and-addressing-privacy-issues-in-the-sharing-economy/|title=User Reputation: Building Trust and Addressing Privacy Issues in the Sharing Economy|last=Jerome|first=Joseph|date=2015-06-08|website=Future of Privacy Forum|publisher=|access-date=2016-12-05}}</ref> * Increased flexibility of work hours and wages for independent contractors of the sharing economy<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomiogeron/2013/01/23/airbnb-and-the-unstoppable-rise-of-the-share-economy/#1d9a41026790|title=Airbnb And The Unstoppable Rise Of The Share Economy|last=Geron|first=Tomio|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2016-12-05}}</ref> * Increased quality of service provided by incumbent firms that work to keep up with sharing firms like Uber and Lyft<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wallsten|first=S.|date=1 June 2017|title=The Competitive Effects of the Sharing Economy: How is Uber Changing Taxis?|url=https://techpolicyinstitute.org/policy_paper/the-competitive-effects-of-the-sharing-economy-how-is-uber-changing-taxis/|journal=Technology Policy Institute|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Encompassing many of the listed benefits of the sharing economy is the idea of the freelance worker. Through monetizing unused assets, such as renting out a spare guest room on Airbnb, or providing personal services to others, such as becoming a driver with Uber, people are in effect becoming freelance workers. Freelance work entails better opportunity for employment, as well as more flexibility for workers, as people have the ability to pick and choose the time and place of their work. As freelance workers, people can plan around their existing schedules and maintain multiple jobs if needed. Evidence of the appeal to this type of work can be seen from a survey conducted by the Freelancers Union, which shows that around 34% of the U.S. population is involved in freelance work.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/07/20/uber-and-the-sharing-economy/|title=3 reasons to cheer Uber and the sharing economy|last=Kumar|first=S.|date=July 20, 2015|website=Fortune|access-date=2017-05-30}}</ref>
According to an article by Margarita Hakobyan, freelance work can also be beneficial for small businesses. During their early developmental stages, many small companies can’t afford or aren’t in need of full-time departments, but rather require specialized work for a certain project or for a short period of time. With freelance workers offering their services in the sharing economy, firms are able to save money on long-term labor costs, and increase marginal revenue from their operations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.business.com/articles/how-to-use-the-sharing-economy-to-benefit-your-business/|title=The Sharing Economy Benefits Business|last=Hakobyan|first=Margarita|date=February 22, 2017|work=Business.com|access-date=2017-05-30}}</ref>
Researcher Christopher Koopman, an author of a{{which|date=May 2016}} study by [[George Mason University]] economists, said the sharing economy "allows people to take idle capital and turn them into revenue sources." He has stated, "People are taking spare bedroom[s], cars, tools they are not using and becoming their own entrepreneurs."<ref>{{cite news|author=Afp |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-2939000/Sharing-economy-reshapes-markets-complaints-rise.html |title='Sharing economy' reshapes markets, as complaints rise | Daily Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2015-02-03 |accessdate=2015-03-13 |location=London}}</ref> [[Arun Sundararajan]], a New York University economist who studies the sharing economy, told a congressional hearing that "this transition will have a positive impact on economic growth and welfare, by stimulating new consumption, by raising productivity, and by catalyzing individual innovation and entrepreneurship".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stern.nyu.edu/experience-stern/news-events/prof-arun-sundararajan-s-congressional-testimony-sharing-economy-cited |title=Uber Said to Seek $1.5 Billion in Funds at $50 Billion Valuation |publisher=Bloomberb Business |date=2015-05-19 |accessdate=2015-07-09}}{{unreliable source?|date=May 2016}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=May 2016}}
A study in Intereconomics / The Review of European Economic Policy noted that the sharing economy has the potential to bring many benefits for the economy, while noting that this presupposes that the success of sharing economy services reflects their business models rather than 'regulatory arbitrage' from avoiding the regulation that affects traditional businesses.<ref>Munkoe, M. (2017) Regulating the European Sharing Economy: State of Play and Challenges. Intereconomics / The Review of European Economic Policy. Volume 52, January/February 2017, Number 1 | pp. 38-44</ref>
One benefit of sharing economy is that it can help us in some specific scenes. For example, when your phone has less 20% battery, you may need a sharing charger. The power bank-sharing concept works as follows: Through an app, users locate a shared-charger station, scan a QR code, pay a deposit, and borrow a power bank. The battery packs can be returned to any charging station. In the case of LeDian, the company allowed customers to use the power banks free of charge for the first 24 hours after paying a 50-yuan ($7.60) deposit. After the first day, users were charged 2 yuan per day for the service.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sixthtone.com/news/1000996/shared-charger-startup-pulls-plug|title=Shared-Charger Startup Pulls Plug|last=Tone|first=Sixth|date=12 October 2017|work=Sixth Tone|access-date=2018-11-23}}</ref>
An independent data study conducted by [[Busbud]] compared the average price of hotel rooms with the average price of Airbnb listings in thirteen major cities in the United States. The research concluded that in nine of the thirteen cities, Airbnb rates were lower than hotel rates by an average price of $34.56.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.busbud.com/blog/airbnb-vs-hotel-rates/|title=Comparing Airbnb and Hotel Rates Around the Globe {{!}} Busbud blog|date=2016-02-18|newspaper=Busbud blog|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-05}}</ref> A further study conducted by Busbud compared the average hotel rate with the average Airbnb rate in eight major European cities. The research concluded that the Airbnb rates were lower than the hotel rates in six of the eight cities by a factor of $72.<ref name=":2" /> Data from a separate study shows that with Airbnb's entry into the market in Austin, Texas hotels were required to lower prices by 6 percent to keep up with Airbnb's lower prices.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zervas, G., Proserpio, D., & Byers, J. W|first=|date=2017|title=The Rise of the Sharing Economy: Estimating the Impact of Airbnb on the Hotel Industry|url=http://journals.ama.org/doi/abs/10.1509/jmr.15.0204?code=amma-site|journal=Journal of Marketing Research|volume=54 |issue=5|pages=687–705|via=}}</ref>
== Transport == {{further|Uber (company)|Lyft}} Using a personal car to transport passengers or deliveries requires payment, or sufferance, of [[cost]]s for fees deducted by the dispatching company, fuel, wear and tear, depreciation, interest, taxes, as well as adequate insurance. The driver is typically not paid for driving to an area where fares might be found in the volume necessary for high earnings, or driving to the location of a pickup or returning from a drop-off point.<ref name=Philly5715>{{cite news|author1=Emily Guendelsberger|title=I was an undercover Uber driver|url=http://citypaper.net/uberdriver/|accessdate=May 10, 2015|work=Philadelphia Citypaper|date=May 7, 2015}}</ref> [[Mobile app]]s have been written that help a driver be aware of and manage such costs has been introduced.<ref name=NYT5915>{{cite news|author1=Natasha Singer and Mike Isaac|title=An App That Helps Drivers Earn the Most From Their Trips|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/10/technology/a-dashboard-management-consultant.html|accessdate=May 10, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=May 9, 2015|quote=At first I thought I was earning money}}</ref>
Uber, Airbnb, and other companies have had drastic effects on infrastructures such as road congestion and housing. Major cities such as San Francisco and New York City have become even more congested due to ride sharing. According to transportation analyst Charles Komanoff, "Uber-caused congestion has reduced traffic speeds in downtown Manhattan by around 8 percent".<ref name=":0" />
''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that there was a recent corporate decision by Uber which aimed at lowering its fare rates by 15% in over 100 cities in the United States.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/02/nyregion/uber-drivers-in-new-york-city-protest-fare-cuts.html | title = Uber Drivers in New York City Protest Fare Cuts | last = Santora | first = Marc | date = 2016-02-01 | last2 = Surico | first2 = John | newspaper = The New York Times | issn = 0362-4331 | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref> This decision caused many Uber employee drivers to assemble and express their disagreement with the recent pay cut. Uber made a statement claiming that when it cut prices previously, "the amount of time drivers spent waiting for fares fell, meaning drivers did more business and ultimately earned more money".<ref name=":1" />
A number of academics recently demonstrated that in 2015, Uber generated $6.8 billion of consumer welfare in the United States.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2016-09-08/computing-the-social-value-of-uber-it-s-high|title=Computing the Social Value of Uber. (It's High.)|last=Cowen|first=Tyler|date=2016-09-08|newspaper=Bloomberg View|access-date=2017-02-07}}</ref>
===Local delivery=== The sharing economy model of Uber has been replicated in other similar areas. Ride sharing economy gave birth to food and grocery delivery systems. Uber launched a food-ordering app called UberEATS which not only allows users to order food, but also enables users to register to be UberEATS drivers. Similar to Uber drivers, UberEATS drivers get paid for delivering food.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ridesharingdriver.com/driving-for-ubereats-what-its-like-delivering-food-for-uber/|title=Driving for UberEats: What it’s like delivering food for Uber|date=29 March 2016|publisher=}}</ref> An example of grocery delivery in sharing economy is Instakart. It has the same business model as that of sharing economy based companies like Uber, Airbnb, or CanYa.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/22/technology/personaltech/online-grocery-start-up-takes-page-from-sharing-services.html|title=Grocery Deliveries in Sharing Economy|first=Farhad|last=Manjoo|date=21 May 2014|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> Instacart uses resources that are readily available, and the shoppers shop at existing grocery shops. The contract workers use their personal vehicles to deliver groceries to customers. Instacart manages to keep its cost low as it does not require any infrastructure to store goods. In addition to having contract workers, Instacart allows signing up to be a "personal shopper" for Instacart through its official web page.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/06/22/technology/instacart-employee-option/index.html|title=The Uber effect: Instacart shifts away from contract workers|last=O'Brien|first=Sara Ashley|date=2015-06-22|website=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/30/technology/personaltech/instacarts-bet-on-online-grocery-shopping.html|title=Instacart’s Bet on Online Grocery Shopping|last=Manjoo|first=Farhad|date=2015-04-29|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-02|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
== Criticism and controversies == The ''Harvard Business Review'' argues that "sharing economy" is a misnomer, and that the correct word for this activity is [[access economy]]. The authors say, "When "sharing" is market-mediated—when a company is an intermediary between consumers who don't know each other—it is no longer sharing at all. Rather, consumers are paying to access someone else's goods or services."<ref name="Harvard Business Review" /> The article goes on to show that companies (such as Uber) who understand this, and whose marketing highlights the financial benefits to participants, are successful, while companies (such as Lyft) whose marketing highlights the social benefits of the service are less successful.
The notion of "sharing economy" has often been considered as an oxymoron, and a misnomer for actual commercial exchanges.<ref>{{Cite book|title = What's yours is mine|last = Slee|first = Tom|publisher = OR Books|year = 2015|isbn = 1-68219-022-6|location = New York|pages = 216}}</ref> Arnould and Rose<ref name="Mutuality: Critique and substitute for Belk's sharing">{{cite journal|last=Arnould|first=Eric. J. |last2=Rose|first2=Alexander S.|date=2016|title=Mutuality: Critique and substitute for Belk's sharing|url=http://mtq.sagepub.com/content/16/1/75 |journal=Marketing Theory|volume=16|pages=75 |number=1|doi=10.1177/1470593115572669}}</ref> proposed to replace the misleading concept of "sharing" by that of [[Mutualism (economic theory)|mutuality]] or [[mutualization]]. A distinction can therefore be made between free mutualization such as genuine sharing and for-profit mutualization in the likes of Uber, Airbnb, or Taskrabbit.<ref name="two-sided role"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Ertz|first=Myriam |last2=Durif|first2=Fabien|last3=Arcand|first3=Manon|date=2016 |title=Collaborative consumption or the rise of the two-sided consumer|ssrn=2799886 |journal=International Journal of Business and Management|volume=6|number=6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Laurell|first=Christofer|last2=Sandström|first2=Christian|date=June 2016|title=Analysing Uber in social media – disruptive technology or institutional disruption?|url=http://www.worldscientific.com/doi/pdf/10.1142/S1363919616400132|journal=International Journal of Innovation Management|volume=20|issue=5|pages=1640013|doi=10.1142/S1363919616400132|pmid=|access-date=28 June 2016}}</ref> To Ritzer,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ritzer|first=George|title=Prosumption: Evolution, revolution, or eternal return of the same?|journal=Journal of Consumer Culture|year=2014|volume=14|number=1|url=http://joc.sagepub.com/content/14/1/3|accessdate=24 June 2016}}</ref> this current trend towards increased consumer input in commercial exchanges refers to the notion of [[prosumption]], which, as such, is not new. The mutualization of resources is for example well known in [[business-to-business]] (B2B) like heavy machinery in [[agriculture]] and [[forestry]] as well as in business-to-consumer (B2C) like [[Self-service laundry|self-service laundries]]. But three major drivers enable consumer-to-consumer (C2C) mutualization of resources for a broad variety of new goods and services as well as new industries. First, customer behaviour for many goods and services changes from ownership to sharing. Second, online social networks and electronic markets more easily link consumers. And third, mobile devices and electronic services make the use of shared goods and services more convenient (e.g. smartphone app instead of physical key).<ref>{{Cite book|title = Du Web 2.0 a la seconde vie des objets: Le role de la technologie internet|last = Ertz|first = Myriam|publisher = GRIN Verlag|year = 2015|isbn = 3-668-04210-1|location = Munich|pages = 52}}</ref>
''Salon'' writes that "the sharing economy ... [is] not the Internet '[[gift economy]]' as originally conceived, a utopia in which we all benefit from our voluntary contributions. It's something quite different—the relentless co-optation of the gift economy by market capitalism. The sharing economy, as practiced by Silicon Valley, is a betrayal of the gift economy. The [[potlatch]] has been paved over, and replaced with a digital shopping mall."<ref>[[Andrew Leonard]], [http://www.salon.com/2014/03/14/sharing_economy_shams_deception_at_the_core_of_the_internets_hottest_businesses/ "Sharing economy" shams: Deception at the core of the Internet's hottest businesses], ''[[Salon.com]]'', 2014.03.14</ref><ref>[[Andrew Leonard]], [http://www.salon.com/2014/02/17/youre_not_fooling_us_uber_8_reasons_why_the_sharing_economy_is_all_about_corporate_greed/ You're not fooling us, Uber! 8 reasons why the "sharing economy" is all about corporate greed], ''[[Salon.com]]'', 2014.02.17</ref><ref>Tom Slee, [http://www.salon.com/2014/01/28/the_big_business_behind_the_sharing_economy_partner/ The secret libertarianism of Uber & Airbnb], ''[[Salon.com]]'', 2014.01.28</ref><ref>[[Anya Kamenetz]], [http://www.salon.com/2013/09/30/airbnb_wins_new_york_court_victory_newscred/ AirBnb wins New York court victory, but the city still present challenges for the popular room-finding site], ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'' and ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'', 2013.09.30</ref>
Oxford Internet Institute, Economic Geographer, Graham has argued that key parts of the sharing economy impose a new balance of power onto workers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newint.org/blog/2016/05/25/digital-work-marketplaces-impose-a-new-balance-of-power/|title=Digital work marketplaces impose a new balance of power|last=Graham|first=Mark|website=New Internationalist|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref> By bringing together workers in low- and high-income countries, gig economy platforms that are not geographically-confined can bring about a 'race to the bottom' for workers.
=== Relationship to job loss === ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'' wrote that the sharing economy has succeeded in large part because the real economy has been struggling. Specifically, in the magazine's view, the sharing economy succeeds because of a depressed labor market, in which "lots of people are trying to fill holes in their income by monetizing their stuff and their labor in creative ways", and in many cases, people join the sharing economy because they've recently lost a full-time job, including a few cases where the pricing structure of the sharing economy may have made their old jobs less profitable (e.g. full-time taxi drivers who may have switched to [[Lyft]] or [[Uber (company)|Uber]]). The magazine writes that "In almost every case, what compels people to open up their homes and cars to complete strangers is money, not trust. ... Tools that help people trust in the kindness of strangers might be pushing hesitant sharing-economy participants over the threshold to adoption. But what's getting them to the threshold in the first place is a damaged economy, and harmful public policy that has forced millions of people to look to odd jobs for sustenance."<ref>Kevin Roose, [http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2014/04/sharing-economy-is-about-desperation.html The Sharing Economy Isn't About Trust, It's About Desperation] (2014-04-24), ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]''</ref><ref>Kevin Roose, [http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2014/09/silicon-valleys-contract-worker-problem.html Does Silicon Valley Have a Contract-Worker Problem?] (2014-09-18), ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]''</ref><ref>[http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2014-10-02/a-secret-of-uber-s-success-struggling-workers A Secret of Uber's Success: Struggling Workers] (2014-10-02), ''[[Bloomberg.com]]''</ref>
According to [[CBS News]] there is also Uber's "audacious plan to replace human drivers"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ubers-audacious-plan-to-replace-human-drivers/|title=Uber's audacious plan to replace human drivers|publisher=}}</ref> Once companies like Uber replace human drivers with driverless cars, further job loss will occur as even freelance driving will be replaced by automation.
However, [[Carl Benedikt Frey]] found that while the introduction of Uber had not led to jobs being lost, but had caused a reduction in the incomes of incumbent taxi drivers of almost 10 percent.<ref>[https://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/publications/view/2387 ''Drivers of Disruption? Estimating the Uber Effect'']</ref>
''[[HuffPost]]'' wrote that some people believe the [[Great Recession|recent recession]] led to the expansion of the sharing economy because people could easily employ themselves through the services that these companies offer. However, this concept is only hiding the fact that such employment is only a new face for contractual work and temporary employment that doesn't provide the necessary safeguards for modern living. When companies use contract based employment, the "advantage for a business of using such non-regular workers is obvious: It can lower labor costs dramatically, often by 30 percent, since it is not responsible for health benefits, social security, unemployment or injured workers' compensation, paid sick or vacation leave and more. Contract workers, who are barred from forming unions and have no grievance procedure, can be dismissed without notice".<ref name=":0">{{Cite web | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/steven-hill/sharing-economy-american-workers_b_9018724.html | title = How the Sharing Economy Screws American Workers | website = The Huffington Post | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref>
=== Circumventing labor protection law === [[Xconomy]] wrote about the debate over the status of the workers within the sharing economy, whether they should be treated as [[Independent contractor|contract workers]] or [[Employment|employees]] of the companies. This issue seems to be most relevant among sharing economy companies such as Uber. The reason this has become such a big issue is that the two types of workers are treated very differently. Contract workers are not guaranteed any benefits and pay can be below average. However, if they are employees, they are granted access to benefits and pay is generally higher. The State of California is trying to go after Uber and make them pay a fine to compensate workers fairly. The [[California Public Utilities Commission]] was working on a case that "addresses the same underlying issue seen in the contract worker controversy—whether the new ways of operating in the sharing economy model should be subject to the same regulations governing traditional businesses".<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.xconomy.com/san-francisco/2015/07/17/sharing-economy-companies-sharing-the-heat-in-contractor-controversy/ | title = Sharing Economy Companies Sharing the Heat In Contractor Controversy {{!}} Xconomy | website = Xconomy
| access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref> Like Uber, Instakart too had to face similar lawsuits. In 2015, a lawsuit was filed against Instakart alleging the company misclassified a person who buys and delivers groceries as independent contractor.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-himi-apoorva-mehta-20170105-story.html|title=Apoorva Mehta had 20 failed start-ups before Instacart|date=2017-01-27|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-04-02|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> Instakart had to eventually make all such people as part-time employees and had to accord benefits such as health insurance to those qualifying. This led to Instakart having thousands of employees overnight from zero.<ref name=":3" />
On the other hand, a 2015 article by economists at George Mason University argued that many of the regulations circumvented by sharing economy businesses are exclusive privileges lobbied for by interest groups.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Koopman|first=Christopher|last2=Mitchell|first2=Matthew D.|last3=Thierer|first3=Adam D.|date=2015-05-15|title=The Sharing Economy and Consumer Protection Regulation: The Case for Policy Change|ssrn=2535345|journal=The Journal of Business, Entrepreneurship & the Law|volume=8|pages=530–545|via=}}</ref> Workers and entrepreneurs not connected to the interest groups engaging in this rent-seeking behavior are thus restricted from entry into the market. For example, taxi unions lobbying a city government to restrict the number of cabs allowed on the road prevents larger numbers of drivers from entering in the marketplace.
The same research finds that while sharing economy workers do lack the protections that exist in the traditional economy,<ref name=":6" /> many of them cannot actually find work in the traditional economy.<ref name=":4" /> In this sense, they are taking advantage of opportunities which the traditional regulatory framework has not been able to provide for them. As the sharing economy grows, governments at all levels are reevaluating how to adjust their regulatory schemes to accommodate these workers.
Research by [[Carl Benedikt Frey]] found that the "sharing economy" has had substantial negative impacts on workers wages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/downloads/academic/Uber_Drivers_of_Disruption.pdf|title=Drivers of Disruption|last=Frey|first=Carl Benedikt|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Benefits not accrued evenly === [[Andrew Leonard]],<ref>[http://www.salon.com/2013/09/20/millennials_will_not_be_regulated/ Millennials will not be regulated], [[Andrew Leonard]], ''[[Salon.com]]'', 2013.09.20</ref><ref>[http://www.salon.com/2013/09/17/the_sharing_economy_muscles_up/ The sharing economy muscles up], [[Andrew Leonard]], ''[[Salon.com]]'', 2013.09.17</ref><ref>[http://www.salon.com/2014/06/27/libertarians_anti_government_crusade_now_theres_an_app_for_that/ Libertarians' anti-government crusade: Now there's an app for that] (2014-06-27), [[Andrew Leonard]], ''[[Salon.com|Salon]]''</ref> [[Evgeny Morozov]],<ref>[[Evgeny Morozov]]. [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/sep/28/sharing-economy-internet-hype-benefits-overstated-evgeny-morozov Don't believe the hype, the 'sharing economy' masks a failing economy] (September 2014), ''[[The Guardian (UK)]]''</ref> Bernard Marszalek,<ref>[http://www.counterpunch.org/2014/05/26/the-sharing-economy-brand-yourself/ The New Boss – You – Just Like the Old Boss: The Sharing Economy = Brand Yourself] (2014.05.26), BERNARD MARSZALEK, ''[[CounterPunch]]''</ref> [[Dean Baker]],<ref>[http://www.counterpunch.org/2014/05/28/the-downside-of-the-sharing-economy/ How AirBnB and Uber Cab are Facilitating Rip-Offs: The Downside of the Sharing Economy] (2014.05.28), [[Dean Baker]], ''[[CounterPunch]]''</ref><ref>[http://www.counterpunch.org/2015/02/12/how-uber-distrupts-the-taxi-market/ How Uber Disrupts the Taxi Market] (2015.02.12), [[Dean Baker]], ''[[CounterPunch]]''</ref> and [[Andrew Keen]]<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8lV3YRJKLq8 The Internet is not the Answer], an interview with [[Andrew Keen]] at the ''[[Digital Life Design]] (DLD)'' 2015 Annual Conference. Posted on the official You Tube Channel of ''DLD''</ref> criticized the for-profit sector of the sharing economy, writing that sharing economy businesses "extract" profits from their given sector by "successfully [making] an end run around the existing costs of doing business" - taxes, regulations, and insurance. Similarly, In the context of online freelancing marketplaces, there have been worries that the sharing economy could result in a 'race to the bottom' in terms or wages and benefits: as millions of new workers from low-income countries come online.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newint.org/blog/2016/05/25/digital-work-marketplaces-impose-a-new-balance-of-power/|title=Digital work marketplaces impose a new balance of power|last=Graham|first=Mark|date=2016|work=New Internationalist|access-date=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://usilive.org/opinions/organising-in-the-digital-wild-west-can-strategic-bottlenecks-help-prevent-a-race-to-the-bottom-for-online-workers/|title=Organising in the "digital wild west": can strategic bottlenecks help prevent a race to the bottom for online workers?|last=Graham|first=Mark|date=2016|work=Union Solidarity International|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
[[Susie Cagle]] wrote that the benefits big sharing economy players might be making for themselves are "not exactly" trickling down, and that the sharing economy "doesn't build trust" because where it builds new connections, it often "replicates old patterns of privileged access for some, and denial for others".<ref>[https://medium.com/the-nib/the-case-against-sharing-9ea5ba3d216d The Case Against Sharing: On access, scarcity, and trust] (2014-05-28), [[Susie Cagle]], ''[[Medium (service)|Medium.com]]''</ref> William Alden wrote that "The so-called sharing economy is supposed to offer a new kind of capitalism, one where regular folks, enabled by efficient online platforms, can turn their fallow assets into cash machines ... But the reality is that these markets also tend to attract a class of well-heeled professional operators, who outperform the amateurs—just like the rest of the economy".<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/30/magazine/the-business-tycoons-of-airbnb.html?action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=c-column-middle-span-region&region=c-column-middle-span-region&WT.nav=c-column-middle-span-region The Business Tycoons of Airbnb], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref>
The local economic benefit of the sharing economy is offset by its current form, which is that huge tech companies reap a great deal of the profit in many cases. For example, Uber, which is estimated to be worth $50B as of mid-2015,<ref>{{cite news|author=Afp |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-09/uber-said-to-seek-1-5-billion-in-funds-at-50-billion-valuation |title='Sharing economy' reshapes markets, as complaints rise | Daily Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2015-02-03 |accessdate=2015-03-13}}</ref> takes up to 30% commission from the gross revenue of its drivers,<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/ellenhuet/2015/05/18/uber-new-uberx-tiered-commission-30-percent/ |title= Uber Tests Taking Even More From Its Drivers With 30% Commission |publisher=Forbes |date=2015-05-18 |accessdate=2015-07-09 |first=Ellen |last=Huet}}</ref> leaving many drivers making less than minimum wage.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/a-philadelphia-journalist-went-undercover-as-an-uber-driver-%E2%80%94-heres-how-much-she-made/ar-BBjuRkA|title= A Philadelphia journalist went undercover as an Uber driver — here's how much she made|publisher=MSN |date=2015-05-09 |accessdate=2015-07-09}}</ref> This is reminiscent of a peak [[Rentier state]] "which derives all or a substantial portion of its national revenues from the rent of indigenous resources to external clients".
=== Other issues === ''[[Business Insider]]'' wrote that companies such as Airbnb and [[Uber (company)|Uber]] do not share their reputation data with the very users who it belongs to. This is an issue since no matter how well people behave on any one platform, their reputation doesn't travel with them. This fragmentation has some negative consequences, such as the Airbnb squatters who had previously deceived Kickstarter users to the tune of $40,000.<ref>Kevin Montgomery, [http://valleywag.gawker.com/airbnb-squatters-are-also-kickstarter-swindlers-1612099912 Airbnb Squatters Also Swindled $40,000 From Kickstarter], 2014-07-28</ref> Sharing data between these platforms could have prevented the repeat incident. Business Insider's view is that since the sharing economy is in its infancy, this has been accepted. However, as the industry matures, this will need to change.<ref>Patrick J. Stewart, [http://www.businessinsider.com/reputation-and-the-sharing-economy-2014-10 Reputation And The Sharing Economy] (2014-10-23), "[[Business Insider]]</ref>
Giana Eckhardt and Fleura Bardhi say that the sharing economy promotes and prioritizes cheap fares and low costs rather than personal relationships, which is tied to similar issues in crowdsourcing. For example, Zipcar is advertised as a ride-sharing service, but it's been brought into consideration that the consumers reap similar benefits from Zipcar as they would from, say, a hotel. In this example, there is minimal social interaction going on and the primary concern is the low cost. Other examples many include myriad other sharing economies such as AirBnB or Uber. Because of this, the "sharing economy" may not be about sharing but rather about access. Giana Eckhardt and Fleura Bardhi say the "sharing" economy has taught people to prioritize cheap and easy access over interpersonal communication, and the value of going the extra mile for those interactions has diminished.<ref>Giana Eckhardt and Fleura Bardhi, [https://hbr.org/2015/01/the-sharing-economy-isnt-about-sharing-at-all The Sharing Economy isn't About Sharing at All] (2015-02-09), ''[[Harvard Business Review]]''</ref> In light of the discussion on sharing economy versus access economy, the business models of the sharing economy platforms are also under examination. The escrow-like model practiced by several of the largest sharing economy platforms, in which they facilitate and handle contracting and payments on behalf of their subscribers, further underlines an emphasis on access and transaction rather than on sharing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.perfectklik.com/en/blog/post/1|title=The PerfectKLIK Way - Blog - PerfectKLIK|last=PerfectKLIK|website=www.perfectklik.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-10}}</ref>
The sharing economy has also caused many issues as it often becomes ambiguous as to what the workers' roles are inside of these gig companies. For example, Uber has had many issues over the debate about if their drivers are considered registered taxi drivers or independent contractors.<ref name="Malhotra 24–27">{{Cite journal|last=Malhotra|first=Arvind|date=November 2014|title=The Dark Side of the Sharing Economy...and How to Lighten It.|url=|journal=Communications of the ACM|volume=57|pages=24–27|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> This debate has caused Uber to have to remove their presence in several locations such as Alaska. Uber stirred up a large controversy in Alaska because if Uber drivers were considered registered taxi drivers, that would mean they would be entitled to receiving workers' compensation insurance. However, if they were considered independent contractors they would not receive these same benefits. Due to all of the disputes, Uber decided to pull their services from the Alaskan market.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/uber-ban-countries-where-world-taxi-app-europe-taxi-us-states-china-asia-legal-a7707436.html|title=These are all the places in the world that have banned Uber|last=Rhodes|first=Anna|date=2017-04-28|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-05-30|language=en-GB}}</ref> In addition, ride-share drivers’ status continues to be ambiguous when it comes to legal matters. On New Year’s Eve in 2013, an off-duty driver for Uber killed a pedestrian while looking for a rider. Since the driver was considered a contractor, Uber would not compensate the victim’s family. The contract states that the service is a matching platform and “the company does not provide transportation services, and … has no liability for services... provided by third parties.”<ref name="Malhotra 24–27"/>
It has been discovered that sharing firms have used their power over consumers and labor for unethical business practices. In March 2017, it was shown that Uber used its platform to target regulatory officials. By using software named 'Greyball', Uber was able to make it difficult for officials to get rides on the application. Other schemes implemented by Uber include using its application to show 'phantom' cars nearby to consumers on the app, implying shorter pick-up times than could actually be expected. Uber also changes its contracts and commission clauses so much that it confuses drivers as to their terms of employment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Calo, R. & Rosenblat, A.|first=|date=October 2017|title=The Taking Economy: Uber, Information, and Power|jstor=44392959|journal=Columbia Law Review|volume=117 |issue=6|pages=1629–1631}}</ref>
The sharing economy has also caused issues because many companies have skyrocketed in this new economy and have almost completely replaced the traditional companies that came before them, that offered the same services. Regulations that cover traditional taxi companies but not ride sharing services can put taxis at a competitive disadvantage.<ref name="Malhotra 24–27"/> Returning to the Uber example, Uber has faced many problems worldwide due to the fact that it has taken a large chunk of customers away from traditional taxi companies. Uber has also been banned from several countries or districts including China, Taiwan, Italy, and many others. This is mainly due to the fact that countries saw the company as an unfair competition to taxi services and created laws and regulations against Uber to help benefit taxi companies.<ref name=":5" />
====Theft==== A sharing service, named ''Sharing E Umbrella'' was started in 11 cities across China in 2017 lost almost all of the 300,000 [[umbrellas]] placed out for sharing purposes during the first few weeks.<ref>{{cite news |last=He |first=Huifeng |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/2101722/chinese-umbrella-sharing-firm-remains-upbeat-despite-losing-most |title=Chinese umbrella-sharing firm remains upbeat despite losing most of its 300,000 brollies |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |date=2017-07-07 |accessdate=2017-07-11 }}</ref>
===Justifications=== The disintermediation and informal nature of community-based platforms such as Uber and Airbnb (from the collaborative economy), may exacerbate old problems and spawn new challenges. Such platforms may indeed be ethically and morally questionable and thus constitute controversial consumption schemes. Henceforth, a study<ref name="morally">{{cite journal|last=Ertz|first=Myriam |last2=Lecompte|first2=Agnes|last3=Durif|first3=Fabien|date=2016 |title=It's not my fault, I am in the right: Exploration of neutralization in the justification of the support and use of a controversial technological collaborative consumption service|volume=134|pages=254–264|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Myriam_Ertz/publication/326046153_It%27s_not_my_fault_I_am_in_the_right_Exploration_of_neutralization_in_the_justification_of_the_support_and_use_of_a_controversial_technological_collaborative_consumption_service/links/5b6453cd0f7e9b00b2a33445/Its-not-my-fault-I-am-in-the-right-Exploration-of-neutralization-in-the-justification-of-the-support-and-use-of-a-controversial-technological-collaborative-consumption-service.pdf|journal=Technological Forecasting & Social Change|doi=10.1016/j.techfore.2018.06.032}}</ref> used Sykes and Matza's (1957) classic neutralization theory, from the field of criminology to identify how supporters and users of community-based platforms justify the existence of controversial consumption systems such as community-based platforms.<ref name="morally"/> Interestingly, to justify these platforms, suppors and users both tend to depend heaily on neutralization techniques such as appealing to higher loyalty (e.g., the good for society, the free and fair competition), condemnation of condemners (e.g. Taxi drivers in the case of Uber, hotel chains in the case of Airbnb), denial of victims (i.e., taxi drivers and hotel employees are not victims), denial of responsibility (i.e., Uber and Airbnb are not to blame, the State is), and invokation of normalcy (i.e., these platforms are going to become the norm anyway, or it is the norm in other cities or countries). Also, these techniques are used in conjunction with non-neutralization techniques to defend controversial collaborative services such as Uber.<ref name="morally"/>
== Types of sharing ==
{{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} '''Agriculture''' * [[Garden sharing]] * [[Heifer International]] * [[Seed swap]] '''Finance''' * [[Crowd funding]] * [[Peer-to-peer banking]] * [[Peer-to-peer lending]] * [[Virtual economy|Virtual currency]] '''Food''' * [[Cafeteria]] * [[Food bank]] * [[Social dining]] '''Travel''' * [[Doerz]] * [[ToursByLocals]] * [[Visitours]] '''Real estate''' * [[Airbnb]] * [[Co-housing]] * [[Coliving]] * [[Collaborative workspace]] * [[Couchsurfing]] * [[Emergencybnb]] * [[Home exchange]] * [[Peer-to-peer property rental]] * [[HomeAway]] * [[Vacasa]] {{Col-break}} '''Labor''' * [[Open Innovation]] * [[Open source product development]] * [[Coworking]] * [[Freelance marketplace]] * [[LETS]] * [[Time banks]] '''Property''' * [[Bartering]] * [[Book swapping]] * [[Borrowing center]] * [[Clothes swapping]] * [[Fractional ownership]] * [[Give-away shop|Free store]] * [[Freecycling]] * [[Peer-to-peer renting]] * [[List of tool-lending libraries]] * [[Toy library]] '''Transportation''' * [[Bike sharing system]] * [[Carpool]] * [[Carsharing]] and [[peer-to-peer carsharing]] * [[Cycling]] * [[Flight sharing]] * [[Real-time ridesharing]] * [[Share taxi]] * [[Transportation network company]] {{Col-break}} '''Governance''' * [[Algorithmic regulation]] '''Business''' * [[Product service system]] '''Technology''' * [[Cloud computing]] * [[GNU Project]] * [[Open-source software]] * [[Volunteer computing]] * [[WiFi Master Key]] '''Digital rights''' * [[Copyleft]] * [[Free art license]] * [[Open content]] '''Other''' * [[Club theory]] * [[Wikimedia movement]] * [[Wikipedia]] {{col-end}}
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=16em}} * [[Co-creation]] * [[Collaborative finance]] * [[Collaborative innovation network]] * [[Cooperative]] * [[Creative Commons]] * [[Cryptocurrency]] * [[Digital collaboration]] * [[Internet of Services]] * [[Internet of things]] * [[Online platforms for collaborative consumption]] * [[Open Knowledge Foundation]] * [[Open source]] * [[P2P Foundation]] * [[Peer-to-peer (meme)]] * [[Recommerce]] * [[Reputation capital]] * [[Reputation systems]] * [[Secondhand good]] * [[Social collaboration]] * [[Social commerce]] * [[Social peer-to-peer processes]] * [[Solidarity economy]] * [[The Third Industrial Revolution]] * [[Two-sided market]] {{div col end}}
== Notes and references == {{Reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=rosenberg>{{cite news|last=Rosenberg|first=Tina|title=It's Not Just Nice to Share, It's the Future|url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/06/05/its-not-just-nice-to-share-its-the-future/|newspaper=The New York Times|date=5 June 2013}}</ref>
<ref name=friedman>{{cite news|last=Friedman|first=Thomas|title=Welcome to the Sharing Economy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/21/opinion/sunday/friedman-welcome-to-the-sharing-economy.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=25 July 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=20 July 2013}}</ref> }}
== Further reading == {{Wiktionary}} * [http://www.spur.org/publications/urbanist-article/2012-10-09/policy-agenda-sharing-economy A Policy Agenda for the Sharing Economy], The Urbanist, October 2012 * Kostakis, V., and Bauwens, M. (2014) [http://p2pfoundation.net/Network_Society_and_Future_Scenarios_for_a_Collaborative_Economy Network Society and Future Scenarios for a Collaborative Economy].
